title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: George's mother said:

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: Bark, George.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: George went: Meow.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: No, George, said George's mother.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: Cats go meow.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: Dogs go arf.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: Now, bark, George.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: George went: Quack-quack.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: No, George, said George's mother.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: Ducks go quack-quack

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: Dogs go arf.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: Now, bark, George.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: George went: Oink.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: No, George, said George's mother.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: Pigs go oink.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: Dogs go arf.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: Now, bark, George.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: George went: Moo.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: George's mother took George to the vet.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: I'll soon get to the bottom of this, said the vet.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: Please bark, George.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: George went: Meow.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: The vet reached deep down inside of George . . .

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: And pulled out a cat.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: Bark again, George.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: George went: Quack-quack.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: The vet reached deep down inside of George . . .

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: And pulled out a duck.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: Bark again, George.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: George went: Oink.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: The vet reached deep down inside of George . . .

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: And pulled out a pig.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: Bark again, George.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: George went: Moo.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: The vet put on his longest latex glove . . .

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: Then he reached deep, deep, deep, deep, deep, deep, deep, deep, deep, deep, deep, down inside of George . . .

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: And pulled out a cow.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: Bark again, George.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: George went: arf

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: George's mother was so thrilled that she kissed the vet . . .

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: And the cat.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: And the duck.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: And the pig.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: And the cow.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: On the way home, she wanted to show George off to everyone on the street.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: So she said, Bark, George.

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: And George went:

title: BARK, GEORGE
author: JULES FEIFFER
text: Hello

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: One day, Little Sal went with her mother to Blueberry Hill to pick blueberries.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Little Sal brought along her small tin pail and her mother brought her large tin pail to put berries in.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: We will take our berries home and can them, said her mother.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Then we will have food for the winter.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Little Sal picked three berries and dropped them in her little tin pail . . . Kuplink, kuplank, kuplunk!

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: She picked three more berries and ate them.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Then she picked more berries and dropped one in the pail - kuplunk!

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: And the rest she ate.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Then Little Sal ate all four blueberries out of her pail!

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Her mother walked slowly through the bushes, picking blueberries as she went and putting them in her pail.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Little Sal struggled along behind, picking blueberries and eating every single one.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Little Sal hurried ahead and dropped a blueberry in her mother's pail.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: It didn't sound kuplink! because the bottom of the pail was already covered with berries.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: She reached down inside to get her berry back.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Though she really didn't mean to, she pulled out a large handful, because there were so many blueberries right up close to the one she had put in.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Her mother stopped picking and said, Now, Sal, you run along and pick your own berries.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Mother wants to take her berries home and can them for next winter.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Her mother went back to her picking, but Little Sal, because her feet were tired of standing and walking, sat down in the middle of a large clump of bushes and ate blueberries.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: On the other side of Blueberry Hill, Little Bear came with his mother to eat blueberries.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Little Bear, she said, eat lots of berries and grow big and fat.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: We must store up food for the long, cold winter.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Little Bear followed behind his mother as she walked slowly through the bushes eating berries.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Little Bear stopped now and then to eat berries.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Then he had to hustle along to catch up!

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Because his feet were tired of hustling, he picked out a large clump of bushes and sat down right in the middle and ate blueberries.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Over on the other side of the hill, Little Sal ate all of the berries she could reach from where she was sitting, then she started out to find her mother.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: She heard a noise from around a rock and thought, That is my mother walking along!

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: But it was a mother crow and her children, and they stopped eating berries and flew away, saying Caw, Caw, Caw.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Then she heard another noise in the bushes and thought, That is surely my mother and I will go that way.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: But it was Little Bear's mother instead.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: She was tramping along, eating berries, and thinking about storing up food for the winter.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Little Sal tramped right along behind.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: By this time, Little Bear had eaten all the berries he could reach without moving from his clump of bushes.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Then he hustled off to catch up with his mother.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: He hunted and hunted but his mother was nowhere to be seen.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: He heard a noise from over a stump and thought, That is my mother walking along.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: But it was a mother partridge and her children.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: They stopped eating berries and hurried away. Then he heard a noise in the bushes and thought, That is surely my mother.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Then he heard a noise in the bushes and thought, That is surely my mother.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: I will hustle that way!

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: But it was Little Sal's mother instead!

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: She was walking along, picking berries, and thinking about canning them for next winter.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Little Bear hustled right along behind.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Little Bear and Little Sal's mother and Little Sal and Little Bear's mother were all mixed up with each other among the blueberries on Blueberry Hill.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Little Bear's mother heard Sal walking along behind and thought it was Little Bear and she said, Little Bear, munch, munch, Eat all you -  gulp, can possibly hold! swallow.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Little Sal said nothing.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: She picked three berries and dropped them, kuplink, kuplank, kuplunk, in her small tin pail.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Little Bear's mother turned around to see what on earth could make a noise like kuplunk!

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Grumph! she cried, choking on a mouthful of berries, This is not my child!

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Where is Little Bear?

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: She took one good look and backed away.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: (She was old enough to be shy of people, even a very small person like Little Sal.)

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Then she turned around and walked off very fast to hunt for Little Bear.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Little Sal's mother heard Little Bear tramping along behind and thought it was Little Sal.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: She kept right on picking and thinking about canning blueberries for next winter.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Little Bear padded up and peeked into her pail.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Of course, he only wanted to taste a few of what was inside, but there were so many and they were so close together, that he tasted a Tremendous Mouthful by mistake.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Now, Sal, said Little Sal's mother without turning around, you run along and pick your own berries.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Mother wants to can these for next winter.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Little Bear tasted another Tremendous Mouthful, and almost spilled the entire pail of blueberries!

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Little Sal's mother turned around and gasped, My Goodness, you are not Little Sal!

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Where, oh where, is my child?

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Little Bear just sat munching and munching and swallowing and licking his lips.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Little Sal's mother slowly backed away.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: (she was old enough to be shy of bears, even very small bears like Little Bear.)

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Then she turned and walked away quickly to look for Little Sal.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: She hadn't gone very far before she heard a kuplink! kuplank! kuplunk!

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: She knew just what made that kind of a noise!

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Little Bear's mother had not hunted very long before she heard a hustling sound that stopped now and then to munch and swallow.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: She knew just what made that kind of a noise!

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Little Bear and his mother went home down one side of Blueberry Hill, eating blueberries all the way, and full of food stored up for next winter.

title: BLUEBERRIES FOR SAL
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: And Little Sal and her mother went down the other side of Blueberry Hill, picking berries all the way, and drove home with food to can for next winter - a whole pail of blueberries and three more besides.

title: BROWN BEAR, BROWN BEAR, WHAT DO YOU SEE?
author: BILL MARTIN JR
text: Brown Bear, Brown Bear, What do you see?

title: BROWN BEAR, BROWN BEAR, WHAT DO YOU SEE?
author: BILL MARTIN JR
text: I see a red bird looking at me.

title: BROWN BEAR, BROWN BEAR, WHAT DO YOU SEE?
author: BILL MARTIN JR
text: Red Bird, Red Bird, What do you see?

title: BROWN BEAR, BROWN BEAR, WHAT DO YOU SEE?
author: BILL MARTIN JR
text: I see a yellow duck looking at me.

title: BROWN BEAR, BROWN BEAR, WHAT DO YOU SEE?
author: BILL MARTIN JR
text: Yellow Duck, Yellow Duck,  What do you see?

title: BROWN BEAR, BROWN BEAR, WHAT DO YOU SEE?
author: BILL MARTIN JR
text: I see a blue horse looking at me.

title: BROWN BEAR, BROWN BEAR, WHAT DO YOU SEE?
author: BILL MARTIN JR
text: Blue Horse, Blue Horse,  What do you see?

title: BROWN BEAR, BROWN BEAR, WHAT DO YOU SEE?
author: BILL MARTIN JR
text: I see a green frog looking at me.

title: BROWN BEAR, BROWN BEAR, WHAT DO YOU SEE?
author: BILL MARTIN JR
text: Green Frog, Green Frog,  What do you see?

title: BROWN BEAR, BROWN BEAR, WHAT DO YOU SEE?
author: BILL MARTIN JR
text: I see a purple cat looking at me.

title: BROWN BEAR, BROWN BEAR, WHAT DO YOU SEE?
author: BILL MARTIN JR
text: Purple Cat, Purple Cat,  What do you see?

title: BROWN BEAR, BROWN BEAR, WHAT DO YOU SEE?
author: BILL MARTIN JR
text: I see a white dog looking at me.

title: BROWN BEAR, BROWN BEAR, WHAT DO YOU SEE?
author: BILL MARTIN JR
text: White Dog, White Dog, What do you see?

title: BROWN BEAR, BROWN BEAR, WHAT DO YOU SEE?
author: BILL MARTIN JR
text: I see a black sheep looking at me.

title: BROWN BEAR, BROWN BEAR, WHAT DO YOU SEE?
author: BILL MARTIN JR
text: Black Sheep, Black Sheep,  What do you see?

title: BROWN BEAR, BROWN BEAR, WHAT DO YOU SEE?
author: BILL MARTIN JR
text: I see a goldfish looking at me.

title: BROWN BEAR, BROWN BEAR, WHAT DO YOU SEE?
author: BILL MARTIN JR
text: Goldfish, Goldfish,  What do you see?

title: BROWN BEAR, BROWN BEAR, WHAT DO YOU SEE?
author: BILL MARTIN JR
text: I see a teacher looking at me.

title: BROWN BEAR, BROWN BEAR, WHAT DO YOU SEE?
author: BILL MARTIN JR
text: Teacher, Teacher, What do you see?

title: BROWN BEAR, BROWN BEAR, WHAT DO YOU SEE?
author: BILL MARTIN JR
text: I see children looking at me.

title: BROWN BEAR, BROWN BEAR, WHAT DO YOU SEE?
author: BILL MARTIN JR
text: Children, Children,  What do you see?

title: BROWN BEAR, BROWN BEAR, WHAT DO YOU SEE?
author: BILL MARTIN JR
text: We see a brown bear, a red bird, a green frog, a black sheep, a goldfish, a yellow duck, a blue horse, a purple cat, a white dog and a teacher looking at us.

title: BROWN BEAR, BROWN BEAR, WHAT DO YOU SEE?
author: BILL MARTIN JR
text: That's what we see.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Farmer Brown has a problem.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: His cows like to type.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: All day long he hears

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Click, clack, moo.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Click, clack, moo.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Click, clack, moo.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: At first, he couldn't believe his ears.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Cows that type?

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Impossible!

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Click, clack, moo.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Click, clack, moo.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Click, clack, moo.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Then, he couldn't believe his eyes.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Dear Farmer Brown,

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: The barn is very cold at night.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: We'd like some electric blankets.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Sincerely, The Cows

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: It was bad enough the cows had found the old typewriter in the barn, now they wanted electric blankets!

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: No way, saud Farmer Brown.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: No electric blankets.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: So the cows went on strike.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: The left a note on the barn door.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Sorry.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: We're closed.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: No milk today.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: No milk today! cried Farmer Brown.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: In the background, he heard the cows busy at work:

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Click, clack, moo.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Click, clack, moo.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Click, clack, moo.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: The next day, he got another note:

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Dear Farmer Brown,

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: The hens are cold too.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: They'd like electric blankets.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Sincerely, The Cows

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: The cows were growing impatient with the farmer.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: They left a new note on the barn door.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Closed.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: No milk.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: No eggs.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: No eggs! cried Farmer Brown.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: In the background he heard them.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Click, clack, moo.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Click, clack, moo.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Click, clack, moo.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Cows that type.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Hens on strike!

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Whoever heard of such a thing?

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: How can I run a farm with no milk and no eggs!

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Farmer Brown was furious.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Farmer Brown got out his own typewriter.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Dear Cows and Hens:

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: There will be no electric blankets.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: You are cows and hens.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: I demand milk and eggs.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Sincerely, Farmer Brown

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Duck was a neutral party, so he brought the ultimatium to the cows.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: The cows held an emergency meeting.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: All the animals gathered around the barn to snoop, but none of them could understand Moo.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: All night long, Farmer Brown waited for an answer.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Duck knocked on the door early the next morning.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: He handed Farmer Brown a note:

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Dear Farmer Brown,

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: We will exchange our typewriter for electric blankets.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Leave them outside the barn door and we will send Duck over with the typewriter.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Sincerely, The Cows

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Farmer Brown decided this was a good deal.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: He left the blankets next to the barn door and waited for Duck to come with the typewriter.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: The next morning he got a note:

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Dear Farmer Brown,

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: The pond is quite boring.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: We'd like a diving board.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Sincerely, The Ducks

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Click, clack, quack.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Click, clack, quack.

title: CLICK, CLACK, MOO COWS THAT TYPE
author: DOREEN CRONIN
text: Click, clack, quack.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: We were all sitting around the big kitchen table.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: It was Saturday morning.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Pancake morning.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Mom was squeezing oranges for juice.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Henry and I were betting on how many pancakes we each could eat.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: And grandpa was doing the flipping.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Seconds later, something flew through the air headed toward the kitchen ceiling . . . and landed right on Henry.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: After we realized that the flying object was only a pancake, we all laughed, even Grandpa.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Breakfast continued quite uneventfully.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: All the other pancakes landed in the pan.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: And all of them were eaten, even the one that landed on Henry.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: That night, touched off by the pancake incident at breakfast, Grandpa told us the best tall-tale bedtime story he'd ever told.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Across an ocean, over lots of huge bumpy mountains, across three hot deserts, and one smaller ocean . . . there lay the tiny town of Chewandswallow.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: In most ways, it was very much like any other tiny town.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: It had a Main Street lined with stores, houses with trees and gardens around them, a schoolhouse, about three hundred people, and some assorted cats and dogs.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: But there were no food stores in the town of Chewandswallow.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: They didn't need any.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: The sky supplied all the food they could possibly want.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: The only thing that was really different about Chewandswallow was its weather.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: It came three times a day, at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Everything that everyone ate came from the sky.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Whatever the weather served, that was what they ate.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: But it never rained rain.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: It never snowed snow.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: And it never blew just wind.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: It rained things like soup and juice.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: It snowed mashed potatoes and green peas.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: And sometimes the wind blew in storms of hamburgers.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: The people could watch the weather report on television in the morning and they would even hear a prediction for the next day's food.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: When the townspeople went outside, they carried their plates, cups, glasses, forks, spoons, knives and napkins with them.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: That way they would always be prepared for any kind of weather.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: If there were leftovers, and there usually were, the people took them home and put them in their refrigerators in case they got hungry between meals.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: The menu varied.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: By the time they woke up in the morning, breakfast was coming down.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: After a brief shower of orange juice, low clouds of sunny-side up eggs moved in followed by pieces of toast.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Butter and jelly sprinkled down for the toast.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: And most of the time it rained milk afterwards.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: For lunch one day, frankfurters, already in their rolls, blew in from the northwest at about five miles an hour.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: There were mustard clouds nearby.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Then the wind shifted to the east and brought in baked beans.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: A drizzle of soda finished off the meal.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Dinner one night consisted of lamb chops, becoming heavy at times, with occasional ketchup.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Periods of peas and baked potatoes were followed by gradual clearing, with a wonderful Jell-O setting in the west.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: The Sanitation Department of Chewandswallow had a rather unusual job for a sanitation department.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: It had to remove the goods that fell on the houses and sidewalks and lawns.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: The workers cleaned things up after every meal and fed all the dogs and cats.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Then they emptied some of it into the surrounding oceans for the fish and turtles and whales to eat.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: The rest of the food was put back into the earth so that the soil would be richer for the people's flower gardens.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Life for the townspeople was delicious until the weather took a turn for the worse.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: One day there was nothing but Gorgonzola cheese all day long.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: The next day there was only broccoli, all overcooked.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: And the next day there were brussel sprouts and peanut butter with mayonnaise.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Another day there was a pea soup fog.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: No one could see where they were going and they could barely find the rest of the meal that got stuck in the fog.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: The food was getting larger and larger, and so were the portions.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: The people were getting frightened.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Violent storms blew up frequently.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Awful things were happening.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: One Tuesday there was a hurricane of bread and rolls all day long and into the night.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: There were soft rolls and hard rolls, some with seeds and some without.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: There was white bread and rye and whole wheat toast.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Most of it was larger than they had ever seen bread and rolls before.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: It was a terrible day.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Everyone had to stay indoors.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Roofs were damaged, and the Sanitation Department was beside itself.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: The mess took the workers four days to clean up, and the sea was full of floating rolls.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: To help out, the people piled up as much bread as they could in their backyards.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: The birds picked at it a bit, but it just stayed there and got staler and staler.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: There was a storm of pancakes one morning and a downpour of maple syrup that nearly flooded the town.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: A huge pancake covered the school.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: No one could get it off because of its weight, so they had to close the school.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Lunch one day brought fifteen-inch drifts of cream cheese and jelly sandwiches.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Everyone ate themselves sick and the day ended with a stomachache.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: There was an awful salt and pepper wind accompanied by an even worse tornado.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: People were sneezing themselves silly and running to avoid the tomatoes.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: The town was a mess.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: There were seeds and pulp everywhere.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: The sanitation department gave up.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: The job was too big.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Everyone feared for their lives.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: They couldn't go outside most of the time.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Many houses had been badly damaged by giant meatballs, stores were boarded up and there was no more school for the children.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: So a decision was made to abandon the town of Chewandswallow.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: It was a matter of survival.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: The people glued together giant pieces of stale bread sandwich-style with peanut butter . . . took the absolute necessities with them, and set sail on their rafts for a new land.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: After being afloat for a week, they finally reached a small coastal town, which welcomed them.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: The bread had held up surprisingly well, well enough for them to build temporary houses for themselves out of it.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: The children began school again, and the adults all tried to find places for themselves in the new land.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: The biggest change they had to make was getting used to buying food at a supermarket.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: The found it odd that food was kept on shelves, packaged in boxes, cans and bottles.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Meat that had to be cooked was kept in large refrigerators.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Nothing came down from the sky except rain and snow.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: The clouds above their heads were not made of fried eggs.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: No one ever got hit by a hamburger again.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: And nobody dared to go back to Chewandswallow to find out what had happened to it.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: They were too afraid.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: Henry and I were awake until the very end of Grandpa's story.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: I remember his goodnight kiss.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: The next morning we woke up to see snow falling outside our window.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: We ran downstairs for breakfast and ate it a little faster than usual so we could go sledding with Grandpa.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: It's funny, but even as we were sliding down the hill we thought we saw a giant pat of butter at the top, and we could almost smell the mashed potatoes.

title: CLOUDY WITH A CHANCE OF MEATBALLS
author: JUDI BARRETT
text: The End

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Corduroy is a bear who once lived in the toy department of a big store.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Day after day he waited with all the other animals and dolls for somebody to come along and take him home.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: The store was always filled with shoppers buying all sorts of things, but no one ever seemed to want a small bear in green overalls.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Then one morning a little girl stopped and looked straight into Corduroy's bright eyes.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Oh, Mommy! she said.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Look! There's the very bear I've always wanted.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Not today, dear.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Her mother sighed.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: I've spent too much already.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Besides, he doesn't look new.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: He's lost the button to one of his shoulder straps.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Corduroy watched them sadly as they walked away.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: l didn't know I'd lost a button, he said to himself.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Tonight I'll go and see if I can find it.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Late that evening, when all the shoppers had gone and the doors were shut and locked, Corduroy climbed carefully down from his shelf and began searching everywhere on the floor for his lost button.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Suddenly he felt the floor moving under him!

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Quite by accident he had stepped onto an escalator- and up he went!

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Could this be a mountain? he wondered.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: I think I've always wanted to climb a mountain.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: He wandered around admiring the furniture.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: This must be a bed, he said.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: I've always wanted to sleep in a bed.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: And up he crawled onto a large, thick mattress.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: All at once he saw something small and round.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Why, here's my button! he cried.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: And he tried to pick it up.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: But, like all the other buttons on the mattress, it was tied down tight.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: He yanked and pulled with both paws until pop!

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Off came the button - and off the mattress Corduroy toppled, bang into a tall floor lamp.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Over it fell with a crash!

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Corduroy didn't know it, but there was someone else awake in the store.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: The night watchman was doing his rounds on the floor above.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: When he heard the crash he came dashing down the escalator.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Now who in the world did that! he exclaimed.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Somebody must be hiding around here!

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: He flashed his light under and over sofas and beds until he came to the biggest bed of all.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: And there he saw two fuzzy brown ears sticking up from under the cover.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Hello! he said.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: How did you get upstairs?

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: The watchman tucked Corduroy under his arm and carried him down the escalator and set him on the shelf in the toy department with the other animals and dolls.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Corduroy was just waking up when the first customers came into the store in the morning.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: And there, looking at him with a wide, warm smile, was the same little girl he'd seen only the day before.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: I'm Lisa, she said, and you're going to be my very own bear.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Last night I counted what I've saved in my piggy bank and my mother said I could bring you home.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Shall I put him in a box for you? the saleslady asked.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Oh, no thank you, Lisa answered.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: And she carried Corduroy home in her arms.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: She ran all the way up four flights of stairs, into her family's apartment, and straight to her own room.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Corduroy blinked.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: There was a chair and a chest of drawers, and alongside a girl-size bed stood a little bed just the right size for him.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: The room was small, nothing like that enormous palace in the department store.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: This must be home, he said.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: I know I've always wanted a home!

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Lisa sat down with Corduroy on her lap and began to sew a button on his overalls.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: I like you the way you are, she said, but you'll be more comfortable with your shoulder strap fastened.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: You must be a friend, said Corduroy.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: I've always wanted a friend.

title: CORDUROY
author: DON FREEMAN
text: Me too! said Lisa, and gave him a big hug.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: This is George.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He lived in Africa.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He was a good little monkey and always very curious.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: One day George saw a man.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He had on a large yellow straw hat.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The man saw George too.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: What a nice little monkey, he thought.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: I would like to take him home with me.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He put his hat on the ground and, of course, George was curious.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He came down from the tree to look at the large yellow hat.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The hat had been on the man's head.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George thought it would be nice to have it on his own head.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He picked it up and put it on.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The hat covered George's head.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He couldn't see.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The man picked him up quickly and popped him into a bag.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George was caught.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The man with the big yellow hat put George into a little boat, and a sailor rowed them both across the water to a big ship.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George was sad, but he was still a little curious.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: On the big ship, things began to happen.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The man took off the bag.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George sat on a little stool and the man said, George, I am going to take you to a big Zoo in a big city.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: You will like it there.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Now run along and Play, but don't get into trouble'

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George promised to be good.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: But it is easy for little monkeys to forget.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: On the deck he found some sea gulls.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He wondered how they could fly.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He was very curious.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Finally he HAD to try.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: It looked easy.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: But -

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: oh, what happened!

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: First this - and then this!

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: WHERE IS GEORGE?

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The sailors looked and looked.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: At last they saw him struggling in the water, and almost all tired out.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Man overboard! the sailors cried as they threw him a lifebelt.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George caught it and held on.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: At last he was safe on board.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: After that George was more careful to be a good monkey, until, at last, the long trip was over.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George said good-bye to the kind sailors, and he and the man with the yellow hat walked off the ship on to the shore and on into the city to the man's house.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: After a good meal and a good pipe George felt very tired.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He crawled into bed and fell asleep at once.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The next morning the man telephoned the Zoo.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George watched him.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He was fascinated.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Then the man went away.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George was curious.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He wanted to telephone, too.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: One, two, three, four, five, six, seven.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: What fun!

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: DING-A-LING-A-LING!

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: GEORGE HAD TELEPHONED THE FIRE STATION!

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The firemen rushed to the telephone.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Hello! Hello! they said.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: But there was no answer.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Then they looked for the signal on the big map that showed where the telephone call had come from.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: They didn't know it was GEORGE.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: They thought it was a teal fire.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Hurry!

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Hurry!

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Hurry!

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The firemen jumped on to the fire engines and on to the hook- and-ladders.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Ding-dong-ding-dong.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Everyone out of the way!

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Hurry!

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Hurry!

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Hurry!

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The firemen rushed into the house.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: They opened the door.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: NO FIRE!

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: ONLY a naughty little monkey.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Oh, catch him, catch him, they cried.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George tried to run away.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He almost did, but he got caught in the telephone wire, and – a thin fireman caught one arm and a fat fireman caught the other.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: You fooled the fire department, they said.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: We will have to shut you up where you can't do any more harm.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: They took him away and shut him in a prison.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George wanted to get out.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He climbed up to the window to try the bars.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Just then the watchman came in.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He got on the wooden bed to catch George.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: But he was too big and heavy.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The bed tipped up, the watchman fell over, and, quick as lightning, George ran out through the open door.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He hurried through the building and out on to the roof.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: And then he was lucky to be a monkey: out he walked on to the telephone wires.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Quickly and quietly over the guard's head, George walked away.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He was free!

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Down in the street outside the Prison wall, stood a balloon man.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: A little girl bought a balloon for her brother.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George watched.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He was curious again.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He felt he MUST have a bright red balloon.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He reached over and tried to help himself, but – instead of one balloon, the whole bunch broke loose.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: In an instant the wind whisked them all away and, with them, went George, holding tight with both hands.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Up, up he sailed, higher and higher.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The houses looked like toy houses and the people like dolls.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George was frightened.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He held on very tight.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: At first the wind blew in great gusts.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Then it quieted.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Finally it stopped blowing altogether.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George was very tired.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Down, down he went - bump, on to the top of a traffic light.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: Everyone was surprised.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The traffic got all mixed up.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George didn't know what to do, and then he heard someone call, GEORGE!

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: He looked down and saw his friend, the man with the big yellow hat!

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George was very happy.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: The man was happy roo.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: George slid down the post and the man with the big yellow hat put him under his arm, Then he paid the balloon man for all the balloons.

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: And then George and the man climbed into the car and at last, away they went to the ZOO!

title: CURIOUS GEORGE
author: H.A. REY
text: What a nice place for George to live!

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: A mother held her new baby and very slowly rocked him back and forth, back and forth, back and forth.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: And while she held him, she sang: I'll love you forever, I'll like you for always, as long as I'm living my baby you'll be.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: The baby grew.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: He grew and he grew and he grew.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: He grew until he was two years old, and he ran all around the house.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: He grew until he was two years old, and he ran all around the house.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: He pulled all the food out of the refrigerator and he took his mother's watch and flushed it down the toilet.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: Sometimes his mother would say, This kid is driving me CRAZY!

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: But at night time, when that two-year old was quiet, she opened the door to his room, crawled across the floor, looked up over the side of his bed; and if he was really asleep she picked him up and rocked him back and forth, back and forth, back and forth.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: While she rocked him she sang: I'll love you forever, I'll like you for always, as long as I'm living my baby you'll be.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: The little boy grew.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: He grew and he grew and he grew.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: He grew until he was nine years old.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: And he never wanted to come in for dinner, he never wanted to take a bath, and when grandma visited he always said bad words.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: Sometimes his mother wanted to sell him to the zoo!

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: But at nighttime, when he was asleep, the mother quietly opened the door to his room, crawled across the floor and looked up over the side of the bed.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: If he was really asleep, she picked up that nine-year-old boy and rocked him back and forth, back and forth, back and forth.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: And while she rocked him, she sang: I'll love you forever, I'll like you for always, as long as I'm living my baby you'll be.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: The boy grew.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: He grew and he grew and he grew.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: He grew until he was a teenager.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: He had strange friends and he wore strange clothes and he listened to strange music.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: Sometimes the mother felt like she was in a zoo!

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: But at nighttime, when that teenager was asleep, the mother opened the door to his room, crawled across the floor and looked up over the side of the bed.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: If he was really asleep she picked up that great big boy and rocked him back and forth, back and forth, back and forth.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: While she rocked him she sang: I'll love you forever, I'll like you for always, as long as I'm living my baby you'll be.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: That teenager grew.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: He grew and he grew and he grew.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: He grew until he was a grown-up man.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: He left home and got a house across town.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: But sometimes on dark nights the mother got into her car and drove across town.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: If all the lights in her son's house were out, she opened his bedroom window, crawled across the floor, and looked up over the side of his bed.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: If that great big man was really asleep she picked him up and rocked him back and forth, back and forth, back and forth.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: And while she rocked him she sang: I'll love you forever, I'll like you for always, as long as I'm living my baby you'll be.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: Well, that mother, she got older.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: She got older and older and older.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: One day she called up her son and said, You'd better come see me because I'm very old and sick.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: So her son came to see her.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: When he came in the door she tried to sing the song.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: She sang: I'll love you forever; I'll like you for always. . .

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: But she couldn't finish because she was too old and sick.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: The son went to his mother.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: He picked her up and rocked her back and forth, back and forth, back and forth.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: And he sang this song: I'll love you forever, I'll like you for always, as long as I'm living my Mommy you'll be.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: When the son came home that night, he stood for a long rime at the top of the stairs.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: Then he went into the room where his very new baby daughter was sleeping.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: He picked her up in his arms and very slowly rocked her back and forth, back and forth, back and forth.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: And while he rocked her he sang.

title: LOVE YOU FOREVER
author: ROBERT MUNSCH
text: I'll love you forever, I'll like you for always, as long as I'm living my baby you'll be.

title: THE CARROT SEED
author: RUTH KRAUSS
text: A little boy planted a carrot seed.

title: THE CARROT SEED
author: RUTH KRAUSS
text: His mother said, I'm afraid it won't come up.

title: THE CARROT SEED
author: RUTH KRAUSS
text: His father said, Im afraid it won't come up.

title: THE CARROT SEED
author: RUTH KRAUSS
text: And his big brother said, It won't come up

title: THE CARROT SEED
author: RUTH KRAUSS
text: Every day the little boy pulled up the weeds around the seed and sprinkled the ground with water.

title: THE CARROT SEED
author: RUTH KRAUSS
text: But nothing came up.

title: THE CARROT SEED
author: RUTH KRAUSS
text: And nothing came up.

title: THE CARROT SEED
author: RUTH KRAUSS
text: Everyone kept saying it wouldn't come up.

title: THE CARROT SEED
author: RUTH KRAUSS
text: But he still pulled up the weeds around it every day and sprinkled the ground with water.

title: THE CARROT SEED
author: RUTH KRAUSS
text: Ande then one day, a carrot came up just as the little boy had known it would.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: One winter morning Peter woke up and looked out the window.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: Snow had fallen during the night.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: It covered everything as far as he could see.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: After breakfast he put on his snowsuit and ran outside.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: The snow was piled up very high along the street to make a path for walking.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: Crunch, crunch, crunch, his feet sank into the snow.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: He walked with his toes pointing out, like this:

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: He walked with his toes pointing in like that:

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: Then he dragged his feet s-l-o-w-l-y to make tracks.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: And he found something sticking out of the snow that made a new track.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: I was a stick- a stick that was just right for smacking a snow-covered tree

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: Down fell the snow - plop! - on top of Peter's head.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: He thought it would be fun to join the big boys in their snowball fight, but he knew he wasn't old enough- not yet.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: So he made a smiling snowman and he made angels.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: He pretended he was a mountain-climber.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: He climbed up a great big tall heaping mound of snow- and slid all the way down.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: He picked up a handful of snow- and another, and still another.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: He packed it round and firm and put the snowball in his pocket for tomorrow.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: Then he went into his warm house.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: He told his mother all about his adventures while she took off his wet socks.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: And he thought and thought and thought about them.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: Before he got into bed he looked in his pocket.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: His pocket was empty.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: The snowball wasn't there.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: He felt very sad.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: While he slept, he dreamed that the sun had melted all the snow away.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: But when he woke up his dream was gone.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: The snow was still everywhere.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: New snow was falling.

title: THE SNOWY DAY
author: EZRA JACK KEATS
text: After breakfast he called to his friend from across the hall, and they went out together into the deep, deep snow.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: Once there was a peddler who sold caps.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: But he was not like an ordinary peddler carrying his wares on his back.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: He carried them on top of his head.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: First he had on his own checked cap, then a bunch of gray caps, then a bunch of brown caps, then a bunch of blue caps, and on the very top a bunch of red caps.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: He walked up and down the streets, holding himself very straight so as not to upset his caps.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: As he went along he called, Caps!

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: Caps for sale!

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: Fifty cents a cap!

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: One morning he couldn't sell any caps.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: He walked up the street and he walked down the street calling, Caps!

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: Caps for sale.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: Fifty cents a cap.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: But nobody wanted any caps that morning.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: Nobody wanted even a red cap.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: He began to feel very hungry, but he had no money for lunch.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: I think I'll go for a walk in the country, said he.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: And he walked out of town - slowly, slowly, so as not to upset his caps.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: He walked for a long time until he came to a great big tree.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: That's a nice place for a rest, thought he.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: And he sat down very slowly, under the tree and leaned hack little by little against the tree-trunk so as not to disturb the caps on his head.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: Then he put up his hand to feel if they were straight - first his own checked cap, then the gray caps, then the brown caps, then the blue caps, then the red caps on the very top.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: They were all there.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: So he went to sleep.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: He slept for a long time.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: When he woke up he was refreshed and rested.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: But before standing up he felt with his hand to make sure his caps were in the right place.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: All he felt was his own checked cap!

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: He looked to the right of him.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: No Caps.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: He looked to the left of him.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: No caps.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: He looked in back of him.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: No caps.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: He looked behind the tree.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: No caps.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: Then he looked up into the tree.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: And what do you think he saw?

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: On every branch sat a monkey.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: On every monkey was a gray, or a brown, or a blue, or a red cap!

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: The peddler looked at the monkeys.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: The monkeys looked at the peddler.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: He didn't know what to do.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: Finally he spoke to them.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: You monkeys, you, he said, shaking a finger at them, you give me back my caps.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: But the monkeys only shook their fingers back at him and said, Tsz, tsz, tsz.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: This made the peddler angry, so he shook both hands at them and said, You monkeys, you!

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: You give me back my caps.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: But the monkeys only shook both their hands back at him and said, Tsz, tsz, tsz.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: Now he felt quite angry.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: He stamped his foot, and he said, You monkeys, you!

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: You better give me back my caps!

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: But the monkeys only stamped their feet back at him and said, Tsz, tsz, tsz.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: By this time the peddler was really very, very angry.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: He stamped both his feet and shouted, You monkeys, you!

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: You must give me back my caps!

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: But the monkeys only stamped both their feet back at him and said, Tsz, tsz, tsz.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: At last he became so angry that he pulled off his own cap, threw it on the ground, and began to walk away.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: But then, each monkey pulled off his cap. . .  and all the gray caps, and all the brown caps, and all the blue caps, and all the red caps came flying down out of the tree.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: So the peddler picked up his caps and put them back on his head – first his own checked cap, then the gray caps, then the brown caps, then the blue caps, then the red caps on the very top.

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: And slowly, slowly, he walked back to town calling, Caps!

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: Caps for sale!

title: CAPS FOR SALE
author: ESPHYR SLOBODKINA
text: Fifty cents a cap!

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: Little Nutbrown Hare, who was going to bed, held on tight to Big Nutbrown Hare's very long ears.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: He wanted to be sure that Big Nutbrown Hare was listening.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: Guess how much I love you, he said.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: Oh, I don't think I could guess that, said Big Nutbrown Hare.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: This much, said Little Nutbrown Hare, stretching out his arms as wide as they could go.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: Big Nutbrown Hare had even longer arms.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: But I love you this much, he said.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: Hmm, that is a lot, thought Little Nutbrown Hare.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: I love you as high as I can reach, said Little Nutbrown Hare.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: I love you as high as I can reach, said Big Nutbrown Hare.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: That is very high thought Little Nutbrown Hare, I wish I had arms like that.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: Then Little Nutbrown Hare had a good idea.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: He tumbled upside down and reached up the tree trunk with his feet.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: I love you all the way up to my toes! he said.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: And, I love you all the way up to your toes, said Big Nutbrown Hare, swinging him up over his head.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: I love you as high as I can hop! laughed Little Nutbrown Hare, bouncing up and down.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: But I love you as high as I can hop, smiled Big Nutbrown Hare - and he hopped so high that his ears touched the branches above.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: That's good hopping, thought Little Nutbrown Hare.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: I wish I could hop like that.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: I love you all the way down the lane as far as the river, cried Little Nutbrown Hare.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: I love you across the river and over the hills, said Big Nutbrown Hare.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: That's very far, thought Little Nutbrown Hare.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: He was almost too sleepy to think anymore.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: Then he looked beyond the thornbushes, out into the big dark night.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: Nothing could be farther than the sky.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: I love you right up to the moon he said, and closed his eyes.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: Oh, that's far, said Big Nutbrown Hare.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: That is very, very far.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: Big Nutbrown Hare settled Little Nutbrown Hare into his bed of leaves.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: He leaned over and kissed him good night.

title: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOU
author: SAM MCBRATNEY
text: Then he lay down close by and whispered with a smile, I love you right up to the moon and back.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: One evening, after thinking it over for some time, Harold decided to go for, a walk in the moonlight.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: There wasn't any moon, and Harold needed a moon for a walk in the moonlight.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: And he needed something to walk on.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: He made a long straight path so he wouldn't get lost.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: And he set off on his walk, taking his big purple crayon with him.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: But he didn't seem to be getting anywhere on the long straight path.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: So he left the path for a short cut across a field.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: And the moon went with him.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: The short cut led right to where Harold thought a forest ought to be.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: He didn't want to get lost in the woods.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: So he made a very small forest, with just one tree in it.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: It turned out to be an apple tree.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: The apples would be very tasty, Harold thought, when they got red.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: So he put a frightening dragon under the tree to guard the apples.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: It was a terribly frightening dragon.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: It even frightened Harold.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: He backed away.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: His hand holding the purple crayon shook.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: Suddenly he realized what was happening.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: But by then Harold was over his head in an ocean.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: He came up thinking fast.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: And in no time he was climbing aboard a trim little boat.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: He quickly set sail.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: And the moon sailed along with him.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: After he had sailed long enough, Harold made land without much trouble.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: He stepped ashore on the beach, wondering where he was.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: The sandy beach reminded Harold of picnics.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: And the thought of picnics made him hungry.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: So he laid out a nice simple picnic lunch.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: There was nothing but pie.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: But there were all nine kinds of pie that Harold liked best.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: When Harold finished his picnic there was quite a lot left.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: He hated to see so much delicious pie go to waste.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: So Harold left a very hungry moose and a deserving porcupine to finish it up.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: And, off he went, looking for a hill to climb, to see where he was.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: Harold knew that the higher up he went the farther he could see.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: So he decided to make the hill into a mountain.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: If he went high enough, he thought, he could see the window of his bedroom.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: He was tired and he felt he ought to be getting to bed.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: He hoped he could see his bedroom window from the top of the mountain.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: But as he looked down over the other side he slipped –

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
