author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: And there wasn't any other side of the mountain.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: He was falling, in thin air.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: But, luckily, he kept his wits and his purple crayon.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: He made a balloon and he grabbed on to it.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: And he made a basket under the balloon big enough to stand in.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: He had a fine view from the balloon but he couldn't see his window.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: He couldn't even see a house.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: So he made a house, with windows.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: And he landed the balloon on the grass in the front yard.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: None of the windows was his window.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: He tried to think where his window ought to be.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: He made some more windows.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: He made a big building full of windows.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: He made lots of building full of windows.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: He made a whole city full of windows.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: But none of the windows was his window.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: He couldn't think where it might be.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: He decided to ask a policeman.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: The policeman pointed the way Harold was going anyway.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: But Harold thanked him.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: And he walked along with the moon, wishing he was in his room and in bed.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: Then, suddenly, Harold remembered.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: He remembered where his bedroom window was, when there was a moon.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: It was always right around the moon.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: And then Harold made his bed.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: He got in it and drew up the covers.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: The purple crayon dropped on the floor. And Harold dropped off to sleep.

title: HAROLD AND THE PURPLE CRAYON
author: CROCKETT JOHNSON
text: And Harold dropped off to sleep.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: When my Great Gramma Anna came to America, she wore the same thick overcoat and big boots he had worn for farm work.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: But her family weren't dirt farmers anymore.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: In New York City her father's work was hauling things on a wagon, and the rest of the family made artificial flowers all day.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: Everyone was in a hurry, and it was so crowded, not like in backhome Russia.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: But all the same it was their home, and most of their neighbors were just like them.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: When Anna went to school, English sounded to her like pebbles dropping into shallow water.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: Shhhhhh.. . .  Shhhhhh.. . .  Shhhhhh.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: In six months she was speaking English.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: Her parents almost never learned, so she spoke English for them, too.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: The only things she had left of backhome Russia were her dress and the babushka she liked to throw up into the air when she was dancing.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: And her dress was getting too small.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: After her mother had sewn her a new one, she took her old dress and babushka.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: Then from a basket of old clothes she took Uncle Vladimir's shirt, Aunt Havalah's nightdress, and an apron of Aunt Natasha's.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: We will make a quilt to help us always remember home, Anna's mother said.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: It will be like having the family in backhome Russia dance around us at night.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: And so it was.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: Anna's mother invited all the neighborhood ladies.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: They cut out animals and flowers from the scraps of clothing.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: Anna kept the needles threaded and handed them to the ladies as they needed them.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: The border of the quilt was made of Anna's babushka.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: On Friday nights Anna's mother would say the prayers that started the Sabbath.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: The family ate challah and chicken soup.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: The quilt was the tablecloth.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: Anna grew up and fell in love with Great-Grandpa Sasha.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: To show he wanted to be her husband, he gave Anna a gold coin, a dried flower, and a piece of rock salt, all tied into a linen handkerchief.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: The gold was for wealth, the flower for love, and the salt so their lives would have flavor.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: She accepted the hankie.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: They were engaged.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: Under the wedding huppa, Anna and Sasha promised each other love and understanding.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: After the wedding, the men and women celebrated separately.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: When my Grandma Carle was born, Anna wrapped her daughter in the quilt to welcome her warmly into the world.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: Carle was given a gift of gold, flower, salt, and bread.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: Gold so she would never know poverty, a flower so she would always know love, salt so her life would always have flavor, and bread so that she would never know hunger.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: Carle learned to keep the Sabbath and to cook and clean and do washing.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: Married you'll be someday, Anna told Carle, and. . .

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: again the quilt became a wedding huppa, this time for Carle's wedding to Grandpa George.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: Men and women celebrated together, but they still did not dance together.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: In Carle's wedding bouquet was a gold coin, bread, and salt.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: Carle and George moved to a farm in Michigan and Great-Gramma Anna came to live with them.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: The quilt once again wrapped a new little girl, Mary Ellen.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: Mary Ellen called Anna, Lady Gramma.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: She had grown very old and was sick a lot of the time.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: The quilt kept her legs warm.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: On Anna's ninety-eighth birthday, the cake was a kulich, a rich cake with raisins and candied fruit in it.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: When Great-Gramma Anna died, prayers were said to lift her soul to heaven.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: My mother Mary Ellen was now grown up.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: When Mary Ellen left home, she took the quilt with her.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: When she became a bride, the quilt became her huppa.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: For the first time, friends who were not Jews came to the wedding.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: My mother wore a suit, but in her bouquet were gold, bread, and salt.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: The quilt, welcomed me, Patricia, into the world. . .

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: And it was the tablecloth for my first birthday party.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: At night I would trace my fingers around the edges of each animal on the quilt before I went to sleep.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: I told my mother stories about the animals on the quilt.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: She told me whose sleeve had made the horse, whose

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: apron had made the chicken, whose dress had made the flowers and whose babushka went around the edge of the quilt.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: The quilt was a pretend cape when I was in the bullring, or sometimes a tent in the steaming Amazon jungle.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: At my wedding to Enzo-Mario, men and women danced together.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: In my bouquet were gold, bread, and salt-and a sprinkle of wine, so I would always know laughter.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: Twenty years ago I held Traci Denise in the quilt for the first time.

title: THE KEEPING QUILT
author: PATRICIA POLACCO
text: Someday she, too, will leave home and she will take the quilt with her.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: That summer the fence that stretched through our town seemed bigger.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: We lived in a yellow house on one side of it.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: White people lived on the other.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: And Mama said, Don't climb over that fence when you play.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: She said it wasn't safe.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: That summer there was a girl who wore a pink sweater.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: Each morning she climbed up on the fence and stared over at our side.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: Sometimes I stared back.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: She never sat on that fence with anybody, that girl didn't.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: Once, when we were jumping rope, she asked if she could play.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: And my friend Sandra said no without even asking the rest of us.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: I don't know what I would have said.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: Maybe yes.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: Maybe no.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: That summer everyone and everything on the other side of that fence seemed far away.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: When I asked my mama why, she said, Because that's the way things have always been.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: Sometimes when me and Mama went into town, I saw that girl with her mama.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: She looked sad sometimes, that girl did.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: Don't stare, my mama said. It's not polite.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: It rained a lot that summer.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: On rainy days that girl sat on the fence in a raincoat.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: She let herself get all wet and acted like she didn't even care.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: Sometimes I saw her dancing around in puddles, splashing and laughing.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: Mama wouldn't let me go out in the rain.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: That's why I bought you rainy-day toys, my mama said.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: You stay inside here-where it's warm and safe and dry.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: But every time it rained, I looked for that girl.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: And I always found her.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: Somewhere near the fence.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: Someplace in the middle of the summer, the rain stopped.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: When I walked outside, the grass was damp and the sun was already high up in the sky.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: And I stood there with my hands up in the air.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: I felt brave that day.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: I felt free.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: I got close to the fence and that girl asked me my name.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: Clover I said.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: My name's Annie, she said.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: Annie Paul.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: I live over yonder, she said, by where you see the laundry.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: That's my blouse hanging on the line.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: She smiled then.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: She had a pretty smile.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: And then I smiled. And we stood there looking at each other, smiling.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: lt's nice up on this fence, Annie said.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: You can see all over.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: I ran my hand along the fence.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: I reached up and touched the top of it.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: A fence like this was made for sitting on, Annie said.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: She looked at me sideways.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: My mama Says I shouldn't go on the other side, I said.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: My mama says the same thing. But she never said nothing about sitting on it.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: Neither did mine, I said.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: That summer me and Annie sat together on that fence.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: And when Sandra and them looked at me funny, I just made believe I didn't care.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: Some mornings my mama watched us.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: I waited for her to tell me to get down from that fence before I break my neck or something.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: But she never did.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: l see you made a new friend, she said one morning.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: And I nodded and Mama smiled.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: That summer me and Annie sat on that fence and watched the whole wide world around us.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: One day Sandra and them were jumping rope near the fence and we asked if we could play.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: I don't care, Sandra said.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: And when we jumped, Sandra and me were partners, the way we used to be.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: When we were too tired to jump anymore, we sat up on the fence, all of us in a long line.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: Someday somebody's going to come along and knock this old fence down, Annie said.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: And I nodded.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: Yeah, I said.

title: THE OTHER SIDE
author: JACQUELINE WOODSON
text: Someday.

title: GOOD NIGHT GORILLA
author: PEGGY RATHMAN
text: Good night, Gorilla.

title: GOOD NIGHT GORILLA
author: PEGGY RATHMAN
text: Good night, Elephant.

title: GOOD NIGHT GORILLA
author: PEGGY RATHMAN
text: Good night, Lion.

title: GOOD NIGHT GORILLA
author: PEGGY RATHMAN
text: Good night, Hyena.

title: GOOD NIGHT GORILLA
author: PEGGY RATHMAN
text: Good night, Giraffe.

title: GOOD NIGHT GORILLA
author: PEGGY RATHMAN
text: Good night, Armadillo.

title: GOOD NIGHT GORILLA
author: PEGGY RATHMAN
text: Good night, dear.

title: GOOD NIGHT GORILLA
author: PEGGY RATHMAN
text: Good night.

title: GOOD NIGHT GORILLA
author: PEGGY RATHMAN
text: Good night.

title: GOOD NIGHT GORILLA
author: PEGGY RATHMAN
text: Good night.

title: GOOD NIGHT GORILLA
author: PEGGY RATHMAN
text: Good night.

title: GOOD NIGHT GORILLA
author: PEGGY RATHMAN
text: Good night.

title: GOOD NIGHT GORILLA
author: PEGGY RATHMAN
text: Good night.

title: GOOD NIGHT GORILLA
author: PEGGY RATHMAN
text: Good night.

title: GOOD NIGHT GORILLA
author: PEGGY RATHMAN
text: Good night, zoo.

title: GOOD NIGHT GORILLA
author: PEGGY RATHMAN
text: Good night, dear.

title: GOOD NIGHT GORILLA
author: PEGGY RATHMAN
text: Good night.

title: GOOD NIGHT GORILLA
author: PEGGY RATHMAN
text: Good night, Gorilla.

title: GOOD NIGHT GORILLA
author: PEGGY RATHMAN
text: Zzzz.

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: In an old house in Paris that was covered with vines lived twelve little girls in two straight lines.

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: In two straight lines they broke their bread and brushed their teeth and went to bed.

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: The smiled at the good and frowned at the bad and sometimes they were very sad.

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: The left the house at half past nine in two straight lines in rain or shine - the smallest one was Madeline.

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: She was not afraid of mice - she loved winter, snow, and ice.

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: To the tiger at the zoo Madeline just said, Pooh-pooh, and nobody knew so well how to frighten Miss Clavel.

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: In the middle of one night Miss Clavel turned on her light and said, Something is not right!

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: Little Madeline sat in bed, cried and cried; her eyes were red.

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: And soon after Dr. Cohn came, he rushed out to the phone and he dialed: DANton-tex-six - Nurse, he said, it's an appendix!

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: Everybody had to cry - not a single eye was dry.

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: Madeline was in his arm in a blanket safe and warm.

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: In a car with a red light they drove into the night.

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: Madeline woke up two hours later, in a room with flowers.

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: Madeline soon ate and drank.

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: On her bed there was a crank, and a crack on the ceiling had the habit of sometimes looking like a rabbit.

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: Outside were birds, trees, and sky - and so ten days passed quickly by.

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: one nice morning Miss Clavel said - Isn't this a fine - day to visit Madeline.

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: VISITORS FROM TWO TO FOUR read a sign outside her door.

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: Tiptoeing with solemn face, with some flowers and a vase, in they walked then said, Ahhh, when they saw the toys and candy and the dollhouse from Papa.

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: But the biggest surprise by far - on her stomach was a scar!

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: Good-by, they said, we'll come again, and the little girls left in the rain.

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: They went home and broke their bread brushed their teeth and went to bed.

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: In the middle of the night Miss Clavel turned on the light and said, Something is not right!

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: And afraid of a disaster Miss Clavel ran fast and faster, and she said, Please children do - tell me what is troubling you?

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: And all the little girls cried, Boohoo, we want our appendix out, too!

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: Good night, little girls!

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: Thank the lord you are well!

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: And now go to sleep! said Miss Clavel.

title: MADELINE
author: LUDWIG BEMELMANS
text: And she turned out the light - and closed the door - and that's all there is - there isn't any more.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Mr. and Mrs. Mallard were looking for a place to live.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: But every time Mr. Mallard saw what looked like a nice place, Mrs. Mallard said it was no good.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: There was sure to be foxes in the woods or turtles in the water, and she was not going to raise a family where there might be foxes or turtles.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: So the flew on and on.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: When they got to Boston, they felt too tired to fly any further.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: There was a nice pond in the Public Garden, with a little island on it.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: The very place to spend the night, quacked Mr. Mallard.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: So down they flapped.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Next morning they fished for their breakfast in the mud at the bottom on the pond.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: But they didn't find much.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Just as they were getting ready to start on their way, a strange enormous bird came by.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: It was pushing a boat full of people, and there was a man sitting on its back.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Good morning, quacked Mr. Mallard, being polite.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: The big bird was too proud to answer.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: But the people on the boat threw peanuts into the water, so the Mallards followed them all round the pond and got another breakfast, better than the first.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: I like this place, said Mrs. Mallard as they climbed out on the bank and waddled along.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Why don't we build a nest and raise our ducklings right in this pond?

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: There are no foxes and no turtles, and the people feed us peanuts.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: What could be better?

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Good, said Mr. Mallard, delighted that at last Mrs. Mallard had found a place that suited her.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: But – Look out! squawked Mrs. Mallard, all of a dither.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: You'll get run over!

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: And when she got her breath she added: This is no place for babies, with all those horrid things rushing about.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: We'll have to look somewhere else.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: So they flew over Beacon Hill and round the State House, but there was no place there.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: They looked in Louisburg Square, but there as no water to swim in.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Then they flew over the Charles River.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: This is better, quacked Mr. Mallard.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: That island looks like a nice quiet place, and it's only a little way from the Public Garden.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Yes, said Mrs. Mallard, remembering the peanuts.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: That looks like just the right place to hatch ducklings.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: So they chose a cozy spot among the bushes near the water and settled down to build their nest.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: And only just in time, for now they were beginning to molt.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: All their old wing feathers started to drop out, and they would not be able to fly again until the new ones grew in.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: But of course they could swim, and one day they swam over to the park on the river bank, and they met a policeman called Michael.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Michael fed them peanuts, and after that the Mallards called on Michael every day.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: After Mrs. Mallard had laid eight eggs in the nest she couldn't go visit Michael any more, because she had to sit on the eggs and keep them warm.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: She moved off the nest only to get a drink of water, or to have her lunch, or to count the eggs and make sure they were all there.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: One day the ducklings hatched out.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: First came Jack, then Kack, and then Lack, then Mack and Nack and Ouach and Pack and Quack.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Mr. and Mrs. Mallard were bursting with price.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: It was a great responsibility taking care of so many ducklings, and it kept them very busy.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: One day Mr. Mallard decided he'd like to take a trip to see what the rest of the river was like, further on.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: So off he set.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: I'll meet you in a week, in the Public Garden, he quacked over his shoulder.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Take care of the ducklings.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Don't you worry, said Mrs. Mallard.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: I know all about bringing up children.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: And she did.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: She taught them how to swim and dive.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: She taught them to walk in a line, to come when they were called, and to keep a safe distance from bikes and scooters and other things with wheels.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: When at last she felt perfectly satisfied with them, she said one morning: Come along children.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Follow me.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Before you could wink and eyelash, Jack, Kack, Mack, Nack, Ouack, Pack and Quack fell into line, just as they had been taught.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Mrs. Mallard led the way into the water and they swam behind her to the opposite bank.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: There they waded ashore and waddled along till they came to the highway.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Mrs. Mallard stepped out to cross the road.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Honk, honk! went the horns on the speeding cars.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Qua-a-ack! went Mrs. Mallard as she tumbled back again.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Quack! Quack! Quack! Quack! went Jack, Kack, Mack, Nack, Ouack, Pack and Quack, just as loud as their little quackers could quack.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: The cars kept speeding by and honking, and Mrs. Mallard and the ducklings kept right on quack-quack-quacking.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: They made such a noise that Michael came running, waving his arms and blowing his whistle.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: He planted himself in the center of the road, raised one hand to stop the traffic, and then beckoned with the other, the way policemen do, for Mrs. Mallard to cross over.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: As soon as Mrs. Mallard and the ducklings were safe on the other side and on their way down Mount Vernon Street, Michael rushed back to his police booth.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: He called Clancy at headquarters and said: There's a family of ducks walkin' down the street!

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Clancy said: Family of what?

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Ducks! yelled Michael.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Send a police car, quick!

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Meanwhile, Mrs. Mallard had reached the Corner Book Shop and turned into Charles Street, with Jack, Kack, Mack, Nack, Ouack, Pack and Quack all marching in line behind her.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Everyone stared.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: An old lady from Beacon Hill said: Isn't it amazing! and a man who swept the streets said: Well, now, ain't that nice! and when Mrs. Mallard heard them she was so proud she tipped her nose in the air and walked along with and extra swing in her waddle.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: When they came to the corner of Beacon Street, there was the police car with four policemen that Clancy had sent from headquarters.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: The policemen held back the traffic so Mrs. Mallard and the ducklings could march across the street, right on into the Public Garden.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: Inside the gate they all turned round to say thank you to the policemen.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: The policemen smiled and waved good-by.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: When they reached the pond and swam across to the little island, there was Mr. Mallard waiting for them, just as he had promised.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: The ducklings liked the new island so much that they decided to live there.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: All day long they follow the swan boats and eat peanuts.

title: MAKE WAY FOR DUCKLINGS
author: ROBERT MCCLOSKEY
text: And when night falls they swim to their little island and go to sleep.

title: NO, DAVID!
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: David's mom always said. . . No, David!

title: NO, DAVID!
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: No, David!

title: NO, DAVID!
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: No, David, no!

title: NO, DAVID!
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: No! No! No!

title: NO, DAVID!
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Come back here, David!

title: NO, DAVID!
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: David!

title: NO, DAVID!
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Be quiet!

title: NO, DAVID!
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Don't play with your food!

title: NO, DAVID!
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: That's enough, David!

title: NO, DAVID!
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Go to your room!

title: NO, DAVID!
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Settle down!

title: NO, DAVID!
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Stop that this instant!

title: NO, DAVID!
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Put your toys away!

title: NO, DAVID!
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Not in the house, David!

title: NO, DAVID!
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: I said no, David!

title: NO, DAVID!
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Davey, come here.

title: NO, DAVID!
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Yes, David. . . I love you!

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: It was late one winter night, long past my bedtime, when Pa and I went owling.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: There was no wind.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: The trees stood still as giant statues.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: And the moon was so bright the sky seemed to shine.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: Somewhere behind us a train whistle blew, long and low, like a sad, sad song.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: I could hear it through the woolen cap Pa had pulled down over my ears.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: A farm dog answered the train, and then a second dog joined in.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: They sang out, trains and dogs, for a real long time.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: And when their voices faded away it was as quiet as a dream.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: We walked on toward to woods, Pa and I.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: Our feet crunched over the crisp snow and little gray footprints followed us.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: Pa made a long shadow, but mine was short and round.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: I had to run after him every now and then to keep up, and my short, round shadow bumped after me.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: But I never called out.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: If you go owling you have to be quiet, that's what Pa always says.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: I had been waiting to go owling with Pa for a long, long time.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: We reached the line of pine trees, black and pointy against the sky, and Pa held up his hand.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: I stopped right where I was and waited.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: He looked up, as if searching the stars, as if reading a map up there.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: The moon made his face into a silver mask.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: Then he called: Whoo-whoo-who-who-who-whoooooooo, the sound of a Great Horned Owl.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: Whoo-whoo-who-who-who-whoooooooo.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: Again he called out.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: And then again.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: After each call he was silent and for a moment we both listened.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: But there was no answer.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: Pa shrugged and I shrugged.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: I was not disappointed.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: My brothers all said sometimes there's an owl and sometimes there isn't.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: We walked on.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: I could feel the cold, as if someone's icy hand was palm-down on my back.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: And my nose and the tops of my cheeks felt cold and hot at the same time.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: But I never said a word.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: If you go owling, you have to be quiet and make your own heat.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: We went into the woods.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: The shadows were the blackest things I had ever seen.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: They stained the white snow.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: My mouth felt furry, for the scarf over it was wet and warm.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: I didn't ask what kinds of things hide behind black trees in the middle of the night.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: When you go owling you have to be brave.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: Then we came to a clearing in the dark woods.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: The moon was high above us.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: It seemed to fit exactly over the center of the clearing and the snow below it was whiter than the milk in a cereal bowl.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: I sighed and Pa held up his hand at the sound.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: I put my mittens over the scarf over my mouth and listened hard.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: And then Pa called: Whoo-whoo-who-who-who-whoooooooo. Whoo-whoo-who-who-who-whoooooooo.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: I listened and looked so hard my ears hurt and my eyes got cloudy with the cold.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: Pa raised his face to call out again, but before he could open his mouth an echo came threading its way through the trees.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: Whoo-whoo-who-who-who-whoooooooo.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: Pa almost smiled.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: Then he called back: Whoo-whoo-who-who-who-whoooooooo, just as if he and the owl were talking about supper or about the woods or the moon or the cold.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: I took my mitten off the scarf off my mouth, and I almost smiled, too.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: The owl's call came closer, from high up in the trees on the edge of the meadow.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: Nothing in the meadow moved.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: All of a sudden an owl shadow, part of the big tree shadow, lifted off and flew right over us.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: We watched silently with the heat of our mouths, the heat of all those words we had not spoken.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: The shadow hooted again.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: Pa turned on his big flashlight and caught the owl just as it was landing on a branch.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: For one minute, three minutes, maybe even a hundred minutes, we stared at one another.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: Then the owl pumped its great wings and lifted off the branch like a shadow without sound.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: It flew back into the forest.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: Time to go home, Pa said to me.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: I knew then I could talk, I could even laugh out loud.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: But I was a shadow as we walked home.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: When you go owling you don't need words or warm or anything but hope.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: That's what Pa says.

title: OWL MOON
author: JANE YOLEN
text: The kind of hope that flies on silent wings under a shining Owl Moon.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: In a warm and sultry forest far, far away, there once lived a mother fruit bat and her new baby.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Oh, how Mother Bat loved her soft tiny baby.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: I'll name you Stellaluna, she crooned.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Each night, Mother Bat would carry Stellaluna clutched to her breast as she flew out to search for food.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: One night, as Mother Bat followed the heavy scent of ripe fruit, an owl spied her.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: On silent wings the powerful bird swooped down upon the bats.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Dodging and shrieking, Mother Bat tried to escape, but the owl struck again and again, knocking Stellaluna into the air.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Her baby wings were as limp and useless as wet paper.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Down, down she went, faster and faster, into the forest below.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: The dark leafy tangle of branches caught Stellaluna as she fell.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: One twig was small enough for Stellaluna's tiny feet.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Wrapping her wings about her, she clutched the thin branch, trembling with cold and fear.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Mother, Stellaluna squeaked.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Where are you?

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: By drybreak, the baby bat could hold on no longer.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Down, down again she dropped.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Flump!

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Stellaluna landed headfirst in a soft downy nest, startling the three baby birds who lived there.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Stellaluna quickly clambered from the nest and hung out of sight below it.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: She listened to the babble of the three birds.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: What was that? cried Flap.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: I don't know but it's hanging by its feet, chirped Flitter.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Shhh! Here comes Mama, hissed Pip.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Many, many times that day Mama Bird flew away, always returning with food for her babies.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Stellaluna was terribly hungry- but not for the crawly things Mama Bird brought.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Finally, though, the little bat could bear it no longer.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: She climbed into the nest, closed her eyes, and opened her mouth.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Plop!

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: In dropped a big green grasshopper!

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Stellaluna learned to be like the birds.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: She stayed awake all day and slept at night.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: She ate bugs even though they tasted awful.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Her bat ways were quickly disappearing.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Except for one thing: Stellaluna still liked to sleep hanging by her feet.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Once, when Mama was away, the curious baby birds decided to try it, too.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: When Mama Bird came home she saw eight tiny feet gripping the edge of the nest.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Eeeek! she cried.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Get back up here this instant!

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: You're going to fall and break your necks!

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: The birds clambered back into the nest, but Mama Bird stopped Stellaluna.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: You are teaching my children to do bad things.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: I will not let you back into this nest unless you promise to obey all the rules of this house.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Stellaluna promised.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: She ate bugs without making faces.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: She slept in the nest at night.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: And she didn't hang by her feet.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Stellaluna behaved as a good bird should.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: All the babies grew quickly.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Soon the nest became crowded.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Mama Bird told them it was time to learn to fly.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: One by one, Pip, Flitter, Flap, and Stellaluna jumped from the nest.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Their wings worked!

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: I'm just like them, thought Stellaluna.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: I can fly, too.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Pip, Flitter, and Flap landed gracefully on a branch.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Stellaluna tried to do the same.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: How embarrassing!

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: I will fly all day, Stellaluna told herself.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Then no one will see how clumsy I am.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: The next day, Pip, Flitter, Flap, and Stellaluna went flying far from home.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: They flew for hours, exercising their new wings.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: The sun is setting, warned Flitter.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: We had better go home or we will get lost in the dark, said Flap.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: But Stellaluna had flown far ahead and was nowhere to be seen.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: The three anxious birds went home without her.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: All alone Stellaluna flew and flew until her wings ached and she dropped into a tree.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: I promised not to hang by my feet, Stellaluna sighed.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: So she hung by her thumbs and soon fell asleep.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: She didn't hear the soft sound of wings coming near.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Hey! a loud voice said.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Why are you hanging upside down?

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Stellaluna's eyes opened wide.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: She saw a most peculiar face.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: I'm not upside down, you are! Stellaluna said.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Ah, but you're a bat.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Bats hang by their feet.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: You are hanging by your thumbs, so that makes you upside down!the creature said.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: I'm a bat.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: I am hanging by my feet.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: That makes me right side up!

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Stellaluna was confused.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Mama Bird told me I was upside down.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: She said I was wrong . . .

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Wrong for a bird, maybe, but not for a bat.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: More bats gathered around to see the strange young bat who behaved like a bird.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Stellaluna told them her story.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: You ate b-bugs? stuttered one.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: You slept at night? gasped another.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: How very strange, they all murmured.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Wait! Wait! Let me look at this child.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: A bat pushed through the crowd.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: An owl attacked you? she asked.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Sniffing Stellaluna's fur, she whispered, You are Stellaluna.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: You are my baby.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: You escaped the owl? cried Stellaluna.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: You survived?

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Yes, said Mother Bat as she wrapped her wings around Stellaluna. Come with me and I'll show you where to find the most delicious fruit.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: You'll  never have to eat another bug as long as you live.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: But it's nighttime, Stellaluna squeaked.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: We can't fly in the dark or we will crash into trees.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: We're bats, said Mother Bat.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: We can see in darkness.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Come with us.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Stellaluna was afraid, but she let go of the tree and dropped into the deep blue sky.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Stellaluna could see.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: She felt as though rays of light shone from her eyes.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: She was able to see everything in her path.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Soon the bats found a mango tree and stellaluna ate as much of the fruit as she could hold.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: I'll never eat another bug as long as I live, cheered Stellaluna as she stuffed herself full.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: I must tell Pip, Flitter and Flap!

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: The next day Stellaluna went to visit the birds.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Come with me and meet my bat family, said Stellaluna.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Okay, let's go, agreed Pip.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: They hang by their feet and they fly at night and they eat the best food in the world, Stellaluna explained to the birds on the way.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: As the birds flew among the bats, Flap said, I feel upside down here.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: So the birds hung by their feet.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Wait until dark, Stellaluna said excitedly.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: We will fly at night.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: When night came Stellaluna flew away.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Pip, Flitter, and Flap leapt from the tree to follow her.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: I can't see a thing! yelled Pip.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Neither can I, howled Flitter.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Aaeee! shrieked Flap.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: They're going to crash, gasped Stellaluna.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: I must rescue them!

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Stellaluna swooped about, grabbing her friends in the air.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: She lifted them to a tree, and the birds grasped a branch.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Stellaluna hung from the limb above them.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: We're safe, said Stellaluna.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Then she sighed. I wish you could see in the dark, too.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: We wish you could land on your feet, Flitter replied.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Pip and Flap nodded.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: They perched in silence for a long time.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: How can we be so different and feel so much alike? mused Flitter.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: And how can we feel so different and be so much alike? wondered Pip.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: I think this is quite a mystery Flap chirped.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: I agree, said Stellaluna. But we're friends.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: And that's a fact.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: BAT NOTES

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Of the nearly 4,000 species of mammals on Earth, almost one quarter are bats, the only mammals capable of powered flight.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: The scientific name for bats in Chiroptera, hand-wing, because the skeleton that supports the wing is composed on the animal's elongated finger bones.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: The majority of bats are classified as Microchiroptera, small hand-wing.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Nearly 800 varieties fill special niches in every climate around the world except the polar zones.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: The lifestyles and food preferences of Microchiroptera vary wildly.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Many eat insects, while others catch fish, amphibians, and reptiles.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Finally, there is the famous vampire, of which there are only three species, ranging from Mexico to Argentina.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: The vampire's victims are mostly domestic cattle and native mammals and birds.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: The other 170 or so species of bats are the fruit bats, otherwise known as Megachiroptera, or large hand-wing.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: As their name implies, they are the largest bats, some types boasting wingspans of six feet.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Fruit bats generally have long muzzles, large eyes, pointy ears, and furry bodies, which is why they are often called flying foxes.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Unlike Microchiroptera, who travel by echolocation, fruit bats depend on their keen vision and sense of smell to navigate.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: They live in tropical and subtropical climates that provide year-round supplies of their favorite fruit, flowers, and nectar.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Some fruit bats, as they forage for nectar, are responsible for pollination of many types of night-blooming trees and plants.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Others eat whole fruits, seeds and all, and distribute the seeds over the forest floor in their droppings.

title: STELLALUNA
author: JANELL CANNON
text: Regeneration of tropical forests depends greatly on bats.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Sylvester Duncan lived with his mother and father at Acorn Road in Oatsdale.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: One of his hobbies was collecting pebbles of unusual shape and color.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: On a rainy Saturday, during vacation he found a quite extraordinary one.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: It was flaming red, shiny, and perfectly round, like a marble.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: As he was studying this remarkable pebble, he began to shiver, probably from excitement, and the rain felt cold on his back.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: I wish it would stop raining, he said.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: To his great surprise the rain stopped.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: It didn't stop gradually as rains usually do.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: It CEASED.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: The drops vanished on the way down, the clouds disappeared, everything was dry, and the sun was shining as if rain had never existed.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: In all his young life Sylvester had never had a wish gratified so quickly.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: It struck him that magic must be at work, and he guessed that the magic must be in the remarkable-looking red pebble.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: (Where indeed it was.)

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: To make a test, he put the pebble on the ground and said, I wish it would rain again.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Nothing happened.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: But when he said the same thing holding the Pebble in his hoof, the sky turned black, there was lightning and a clap of thunder, and the rain came shooting down.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: What a lucky day this is! thought Sylvester.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: From now on I can have anything I want.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: My father and mother can have anything they want.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: My relatives, my friends, and anybody at all can have everything anybody wants!

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: He wished the sunshine back in the sky, and he wished a wart on his left hind fetlock would disappear, and it did, and he started home, eager to amaze his father and mother with his magic pebble.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: He could hardly wait to see their faces.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Maybe they wouldn't even believe him at first.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: As he was crossing strawberry Hill, thinking of some of the many, many things he could wish for, he was startled to see a mean, hungry lion looking right at him from behind some tall grass.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: He was frightened.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: If he hadn't been so frightened, he could have made the lion disappear, or he could have wished himself safe at home with his father and mother.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: He could have wished the lion would turn into a butterfly or a daisy or a gnat.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: He could have wished many things, but he panicked and couldn't think carefully.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: I wish I were a rock, he said, and he became a rock.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: The lion came bounding over, sniffed the rock a hundred times, walked around and around it, and went away confused, perplexed, puzzled, and bewildered.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: I saw that little donkey as clear as day.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Maybe I'm going crazy, he muttered.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: And there was Sylvester, a rock on Strawberry Hill, with the magic pebble lying right beside him on the ground, and he was unable to pick it up.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Oh, how I wish I were myself again, he thought, but nothing happened.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: He had to be touching the pebble to make the magic work, but there was nothing he could do about it.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: His thoughts began to race like mad.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: He was scared and worried.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Being helpless, he felt hopeless.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: He imagined all the possibilities, and eventually he realized that his only chance of becoming himself again was for someone to find the red pebble and to wish that the rock next to it would be a donkey.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Someone would surely find the red pebble – it was so bright and shiny - but what on earth would make them wish that a rock were a donkey?

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: The chance was one in a billion at best.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Sylvester fell asleep.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: What else could he do?

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Night came with many stars.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Meanwhile, back at home, Mr. and Mrs. Duncan paced the floor, frantic with worry.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Sylvester had never come home later than dinner time.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Where could he be?

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: They stayed up all night wondering what had happened, expecting that Sylvester would surely turn up by morning.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: But he didn't, of course.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Mrs. Duncan cried a lot and Mr. Duncan did his best to soothe her.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Both longed to have their dear son with them.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: I will never scold Sylvester again as long as I live, said Mrs. Duncan, no matter what he does.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: At dawn, they went about inquiring of all the neighbors.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: They talked to all the children - the puppies, the kittens, the colts, the piglets.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: No one had seen Sylvester since the day before yesterday.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: They went to the police.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: The police could not find their child.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: All the dogs in Oatsdale went searching for him.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: They sniffed behind every rock and tree and blade of grass, into every nook and gully of the neighborhood and beyond, but found not a scent of him.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: They sniffed the rock on strawberry Hill, but it smelled like a rock.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: It didn't smell like Sylvester.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: After a month of searching the same places over and over again, and inquiring of the same animals over and over again, Mr. and Mrs. Duncan no longer knew what to do.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: They concluded that something dreadful must have happened and that they would probably never see their son again.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: (Though all the time he was less than a mile away.)

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: They tried their best to be happy, to go about their usual ways.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: But their usual ways included Sylvester and they were always reminded of him.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: They were miserable.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Life had no meaning for them any more.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Night followed day and day followed night over and over again.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Sylvester on the hill woke up less and less often.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: When he was awake, he was only hopeless and unhappy.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: He felt he would be a rock forever and he tried to get used to it.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: He went into an endless sleep.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: The days grew colder.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Fall came with the leaves changing color.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Then the leaves fell and the grass bent to the ground.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Then it was winter.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: The winds blew, this way and that.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: It snowed.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Mostly, the animals stayed indoors, living on the food they had stored up.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: One day a wolf sat on the rock that was Sylvester and howled and howled because he was hungry.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Then the snows melted.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: The earth warmed up in the spring sun and things budded.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Leaves were on the trees again.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Flowers showed their young faces.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: One day in May, Mr. Duncan insisted that his wife go with him on a picnic.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Let's cheer up, he said.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Let us try to live again and be happy even though Sylvester, our angel, is no longer with us.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: They went to Strawberry Hill.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Mrs. Duncan sat down on the rock.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: The warmth of his own mother sitting on him woke Sylvester up from his deep winter sleep.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: How he wanted to shout, Mother! Father!

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: It's me, Sylvester, I'm right here!

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: But he couldn't talk.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: He had no voice.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: He was stone-dumb.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Mr. Duncan walked aimlessly about while Mrs. Duncan set out the picnic food on the rock - alfalfa sandwiches, pickled oats, sassafras salad, timothy compote.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Suddenly Mr. Duncan saw the red pebble.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: What a fantastic pebble! he exclaimed.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Sylvester would have loved it for his collection.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: He put the pebble on the rock.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: They sat down to eat.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Sylvester was now as wide awake as a donkey that was a rock could possibly be.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Mrs. Duncan felt some mysterious excitement.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: You know, Father, she said suddenly, I have the strangest feeling that our dear Sylvester is still alive and not far away.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: I am, I am! Sylvester wanted to shout, but he couldn't.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: If only he had realized that the pebble resting on his back was the magic pebble!

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Oh, how I wish he were here with us on this lovely May day, said Mrs. Duncan.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Mr. Duncan looked sadly at the ground.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Don't you wish it too, Father? she said.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: He looked at her as if to say, How can you ask such a question?

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Mr. and Mrs. Duncan looked at each other with great sorrow.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: I wish I were myself again, I wish I were my real self again! thought Sylvester.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: And in less than an instant, he was!

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: You can imagine the scene that followed - the embraces, the kisses, the questions, the answers, the loving looks, and the fond exclamations!

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: When they had eventually calmed down a bit, and had gotten home, Mr. Duncan put the magic pebble in an iron safe.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: Some day they might want to use it, but really, for now, what more could they wish for?

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: They all had all that they wanted.

title: SYLVESTER AND THE MAGIC PEBBLE
author: WILLIAM STEIG
text: The End

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: Once there was a tree . . . and she loved a little boy.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: And every day the boy would come and he would gather her leaves and make them into crowns and play king of the forest.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: He would climb up her trunk and swing from her branches and eat apples.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: And they would play hide-and-go-seek.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: And when he was tired, he would sleep in her shade.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: And the boy loved the tree . . . very much.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: And the tree was happy.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: But time went by.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: And the boy grew older.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: And the tree was often alone.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: Then one day the boy came to the tree and the tree said, Come, Boy, come and climb up my trunk and swing from my branches and eat apples and play in my shade and be happy.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: I am too big to climb and play, said the boy.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: I want to buy things and have fun.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: I want some money.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: Can you give me some money?

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: I'm sorry, said the tree, but I have no money.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: I have only leaves and apples.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: Take my apples, Boy, and sell them in the city.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: Then you will have money and you will be happy.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: And so the boy climbed up the tree and gathered her apples and carried them away.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: And the tree was happy.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: But the boy stayed away for a long time. . . and the tree was sad.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: And then one day the boy came back and the tree shook with joy and she said, Come, Boy, climb up my trunk and swing from my branches and be happy.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: I am too busy to climb trees, said the boy.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: I want a house to keep me warm, he said.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: I want a wife and I want children, and so I need a house.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: Can you give me a house?

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: I have no house, said the tree.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: The forest is my house, but you may cut off my branches and build a house.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: Then you will be happy.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: And so the boy cut off her branches and carried them away to build his house.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: And the tree was happy.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: But the boy stayed away for a long time.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: And when he came back, the tree was so happy she could hardly speak.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: Come, Boy, she whispered, come and play.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: I am too old and sad to play, said the boy.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: I want a boat that will take me far away from here.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: Can you give me a boat?

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: Cut down my trunk and make a boat, said the tree.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: Then you can sail away . . . and be happy.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: And so the boy cut down her trunk and made a boat and sailed away.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: And the tree was happy . . . but not really.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: And after a long time the boy came back again.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: I am sorry, Boy, said the tree, but I have nothing left to give you-

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: My apples are gone.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: My teeth are too weak for apples, said the boy.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: My branches are gone, said the tree.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: You cannot swing on them-

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: I am too old to swing on branches, said the boy.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: My trunk is gone, said the tree.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: You cannot climb-

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: I am too tired to climb, said the boy.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: I am sorry, sighed the tree.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: I wish that I could give you something . . . but I have nothing left.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: I am just an old stump.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: I am sorry- . . .

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: I don't need very much now, said the boy, just a quiet place to sit and rest.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: I am very tired.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: Well, said the tree, straightening herself up as much as she could, well, an old stump is good for sitting and resting.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: Come, Boy, sit down.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: Sit down and rest.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: And the boy did.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: And the tree was happy.

title: THE GIVING TREE
author: SHEL SILVERSTEIN
text: The End

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: On Christmas eve, many years ago, I lay quietly in my bed.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: I did not rustle the sheets.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: I breathed slowly and silently.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: I was listening for a sound - a sound a friend had told me I'd never hear - the ringing bells of Santa's sleigh.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
