text: There is no Santa, my friend has insisted but I knew he was wrong.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Late that night I did hear sounds, though not of ringing bells.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: From outside came the sounds of hissing steam and squeaking metal.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: I looked through my window and saw a train standing perfectly still in front of my house.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: It was wrapped in an apron of  steam.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Snowflakes fell lightly around it.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: A conductor  stood at the open door of  one of the  cars.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: He took a large pocket watch from  his vest, then looked up at my window.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: I put on my slippers and robe.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: I tiptoed downstairs and out the door.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: All aboard, the conductor cried out.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: I ran up to him.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Well, he said, are you coming?

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Where? I asked.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Why, to the North Pole of course, was his answer.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: This is the Polar Express.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: I took his outstretched hand and he pulled me aboard.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: The train was filled with other children, all in their pajamas and nightgowns.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: We sang Christmas carols and ate candies with nougat  centers as white as snow.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: We drank hot cocoa as thick and rich as melted chocolate  bars.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Outside the lights of towns and villages flickered in the distance as the Polar Express raced northward.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Soon there were no more lights to be seen.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: We traveled through cold, dark forests, where lean wolves roamed and white-tailed rabbits hid from our train as it thundered through the quiet wilderness.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: We climbed mountains so high it seemed as if we would  scrape the moon.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: But the Polar Express never slowed down.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Faster and faster we ran along, rolling over peaks and through valleys like a  car on a roller coaster.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: The mountains turned into hills, the hills to snow-covered plains.'

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: We crossed a barren desert of ice - the Great Polar Ice Cap.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Lights appeared in the distance.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: They looked like the lights of a strange ocean liner sailing on a frozen sea.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: 'There, said the conductor, is the North Pole.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: The North Pole.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: It was a huge city standing alone at the top of the world, filled with factories where  every Christmas toy  was made.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: At first we saw no elves.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: They are gathering at the center of the city, the conductor told us.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: That is where Santa will give the first gift of Christmas.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Who receives the first gift? we all asked.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: The conductor answered.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: He will choose one of you.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Look, shouted one of the children, the elves.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Outside we saw hundreds of elves.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: As our train drew closer to the center of the North Pole, we slowed to a crawl, so crowded were the streets with Santa's helpers.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: When the Polar Express could go no farther, we stopped and the conductor led us outside.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: We pressed through the crowd to the edge of a large, open circle.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: In front of us stood Santa's sleigh.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: The reindeer were excited.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: They pranced and paced, ringing the silver sleigh bells that hung from their harnesses.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: It was a magical sound, like nothing I'd ever heard.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Across the circle, the elves moved apart and Santa Claus appeared.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: The elves cheered wildly.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: He marched over to us and, pointing to me, said, Let's have this fellow here.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: He jumped into his sleigh.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: The conductor handed me up.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: I sat on Santa's knee and he asked, Now, what would you like for Christmas?

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: I knew that I could have any gift I could imagine.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: But the thing I wanted most for Christmas was not inside Santa's giant bag.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: What I wanted more than anything was one silver bell from Santa's sleigh.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: When I asked, Santa smiled.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Then he gave me a hug and told an elf to cut a bell from a reindeer's harness.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: The elf tossed it up to Santa.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: He stood, holding the bell high above him, and called out, The first gift of Christmas!

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: A clock struck midnight as the elves roared their approval.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Santa handed the bell to me, and I put it in my bathrobe pocket.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: The conductor helped me down from the sleigh.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Santa shouted out the reindeer's names and cracked his whip.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: His team charged forward and climbed into the air.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Santa circled once above us, then disappeared in the cold, dark polar sky.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: As soon as we were back inside the Polar Express, the other children asked to see the bell.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: I reached into my pocket but the only thing I felt was a hole.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: I had lost the silver bell from Santa Claus's sleigh.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Let's hurry outside and look for it, one of the children said.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: But the train gave a sudden lurch and started moving.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: We were on our way home.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: It broke my heart to lose the bell.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: When the train reached my house, I sadly left the other children.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: I stood at my doorway and waved good-bye.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: The conductor said something from the moving train, but I couldn't hear him.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: What? I yelled out.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: He cupped his hands around his mouth.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: MERRY CHRISTMAS, he shouted.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: The Polar Express let out a loud blast from its whistle and sped away.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: On Christmas morning my little sister Sarah and I opened our  presents.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: When it looked as if everything had been unwrapped, Sarah found one last small box behind the tree.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: It had my name on it.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Inside was the silver bell!

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: There was a note: Found this on the seat of my sleigh.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Fix that hole in your pocket. Signed, Mr. C.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: I shook the bell.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: It made the most beautiful sound my sister and I had ever heard.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: But my mother said, Oh, that's too bad.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Yes, said my father, it's broken.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: When I'd shaken the bell, my parents had not heard a sound.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: At one time most of my friends could hear the bell, but as  years passed, it fell silent for all of them.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Even Sarah found one Christmas that she could no longer hear its sweet sound.

title: THE POLAR EXPRESS
author: CHRIS VAN ALLSBURG
text: Though I've grown old, the bell still rings for me as it does for all who truly believe.

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: I wrote to the zoo to send me a pet.

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: They sent me an . . .

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: He was too big!

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: I sent him back.

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: So they sent me a . . .

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: He was too tall!

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: I sent him back.

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: So they sent me a . . .

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: He was too fierce!

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: I sent him back.

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: So they sent me a . . .

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: He was too grumpy!

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: I sent him back.

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: So they sent me a . . .

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: He was too scary!

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: I sent him back.

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: So they sent me a . . .

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: He was too naughty!

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: I sent him back.

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: So they sent me a . . .

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: He was too jumpy!

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: I sent him back.

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: So they thought very hard, and sent me a . . .

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: He was perfect!

title: DEAR ZOO
author: ROD CAMPBELL
text: I kept him.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Once upon a time there was a Little House way out in the country.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: She was a pretty Little House and she was strong and well built.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: The man who built her so well said, This Little House shall never be sold for gold or silver and she will live to see our great-great-grandchildren's great-great-grandchildren living in her.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: The Little House was very happy as she sat on the hill and watched the countryside around her.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: She watched the sun rise in the morning and she watched the sun set in the evening.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Day followed day, each one a little different form the one before . . . but the Little House stayed just the same.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: In the nights she watched the moon grow from a thin new moon to a full moon, then back again to a thin old moon; and when there was no moon she watched the stars.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Way off in the distance she could see the lights of the city.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: The Little House was curious about the city and wondered what it would be like to live there.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Time passed quickly for the Little House as she watched the countryside slowly change with the seasons.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: In the Spring, when the days grew longer and the sun warmer, she waited for the first robin to return from the South.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: She watched the grass turn green.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: She watched the buds on the trees swell and the apple trees burst into blossom.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: She watched the children playing in the brook.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: In the long Summer days she sat in the sun and watched the trees cover themselves with leaves and the white daisies cover the hill.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: She watched the gardens grow, and she watched the apples turn red and ripen.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: She watched the children swimming in the pool.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: In the Fall, when the days grew shorter and the nights colder, she watched the first frost turn the leaves to bright yellow and orange and red.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: She watched the harvest gathered and the apples picked.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: She watched the children going back to school.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: In the Winter, when the nights were long and the days short, and the countryside covered with snow, she watched the children coasting and skating.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Year followed year.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: The apple trees grew old and new ones were planted.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: The children grew up and went away to the city . . . and now at night the lights of the city seemed brighter and closer.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: One day the Little House was surprised to see a horseless carriage coming down the winding country road.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Pretty soon there were more of them on the road and fewer carriages pulled by horses.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Pretty soon along came some surveyors and surveyed a line in front of the Little House.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Pretty soon along came a steam shovel and dug a road through the hill covered with daisies.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Then some trucks came and dumped big stones on the road, then some trucks with little stones, then some trucks with tar and sand, and finally a steam roller came and rolled it all smooth, and the road was done.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Now the Little House watched the trucks and automobiles going back and forth to the city.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Gasoline stations . . . roadside stands . . . and small houses followed the new road.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Everyone and everything moved much faster now than before.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: More roads were made, and the countryside was divided into lots.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: More houses and bigger houses . . . apartment houses and tenement houses . . . schools . . . stores . . . and garages spread over the land and crowded around the Little House.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: No one wanted to live in her and take care of her any more.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: She couldn't be sold for gold or silver, so she just stayed there and watched.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Now it was not so quiet and peaceful at night.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Now the lights of the city were bright and very close, and the street lights shone all night.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: This must be living in the city, thought the Little House, and didn't know whether she liked it or not.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: She missed the field of daisies and the apple trees dancing in the moonlight.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Pretty soon there were trolley cars going back and forth in front of the Little House.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: They went back and forth all day and part of the night.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Everyone seemed to be very busy and everyone seemed to be in a hurry.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Pretty soon there was an elevated train going back and forth above the Little House.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: The air was filled with dust and smoke, and the noise was so loud that it shook the Little House.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Now she couldn't tell when Spring came, or Summer or Fall, or Winter.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: It al seemed about the same.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Pretty soon there was a subway going back and forth underneath the Little House.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: She couldn't see it, but she could feel and hear it.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: People were moving faster and faster.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: No one noticed the Little House any more.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: They hurried by without a glance.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Pretty soon they tore down the apartment houses and tenement houses around the Little House and started digging big cellars . . . one on each side.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: The steam shovels dug down three stories on one side and four stories on the other side.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Pretty soon they started building up . . .

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: They built up twenty-five stories on one side and thirty-five stories on the other.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Now the Little House only saw the sun at noon, and didn't see the moon or starts at night at all because the lights of the city were too bright.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: She didn't like living in the city.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: At night she used to dream of the country and the field of daisies and the apple trees dancing in the moonlight.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: The Little House was very sad and lonely.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Her paint was cracked and dirty . . .

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Her windows were broken and her shutters hung crookedly.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: She looked shabby . . . though she was just as good a house as ever underneath.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Then one fine morning in Spring along came the great-great-granddaughter of the man who built the Little House so well.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: She saw the shabby Little House, but she didn't hurry by.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: There was something about the Little House that made her stop and look again.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: She said to her husband, That Little House looks just like the Little House my grandmother lived in when she was a little girl, only that Little House was way out in the country on a hill covered with daisies and apple trees growing around.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: The found out it was the very same house, so the went to the Movers to see if the Little House could be moved.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: The Movers looked the Little House all over and said, Sure, this house is as good as ever.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: She's build so well we could move her anywhere.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: So they jacked up the Little House and put her on wheels.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Traffic was held up for hours as they slowly moved her out of the city.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: At first the Little House was frightened, but after she got used to it she rather liked it.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: They rolled along the big road, and they rolled along the little roads, until they were way out in the country.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: When the Little House saw the green grass and heard the birds singing, she didn't feel sad any more.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: They went along and along, but they couldn't seem to find just the right place.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: They tried the Little House here, and they tried her there.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Finally they saw a little hill in the middle of the field . . . and apple trees growing around.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: There, said the great-great-granddaughter, that's just the place.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Yes, it is, said the Little House to herself.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: A cellar was dug on top of the hill and slowly they moved the house from the road to the hill.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: The windows and shutters were fixed and once again they painted her a lovely shade of pink.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: As the Little House settled down on her new foundation, she smiled happily.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Once again she could watch the sun and moon and stars.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Once again she could watch Spring and Summer and Fall and Winter come and go.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Once again she was lived in and taken care of.

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Never again would she be curious about the city . . .

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Never again would she want to live there . . .

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: The stars twinkled above her . . .

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: A new moon was coming up . . .

title: THE LITTLE HOUSE
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: It was Spring . . . and all was peaceful in the country.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: At the far end of town where Grickle-grass grows and the wind smells slow-and-sour when it blows and no birds ever sing expecting old crows . . . is the street of the Lifted Lorax.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And deep in the Grickle-grass, some people say, if you look deep enough you can still see, today, where the Lorax once stood just as long as it could before somebody lifted the Lorax away.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: What was the Lorax?

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And why was it there?

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And why was it lifted and taken somewhere from the far end of town where the Grickle-grass grows?

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: The old Once-ler still lives here.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Ask him.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: He knows.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: You won't see the Once-ler.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Don't knock at his door.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: He stays in his Lerkim on top of his store.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: He lurks in his Lerkim, cold under the roof, where he makes his own clothes out of miff-muffered moof.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And on special dank midnights in August, he peeks out of the shutters and sometimes he speaks and tells how the Lorax was lifted away.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: He'll tell you, perhaps . . . if you're willing to pay.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: On the end of a rope he lets down a tin pail and you have to toss in fifteen cents and a nail and the shell of a great-great-great-grandfather snail.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Then he pulls up the pail, makes a most careful count to see if you've paid him the proper amount.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Then he hides what you paid him away in his Snuvv, his secret strange hole in his gruvvulous glove.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Then he grunts, I will call you by Whisper-ma-Phone, for the secrets I tell are for your ears alone.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Slupp!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Down slupps the Whisper-ma-Phone to your ear and the old Once-ler's whispers are not very clear, since they have to come down through a snergelly hose, and he sounds as if he had smallish bees up his nose.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Now I'll tell you, he says, with his teeth sounding gray, how the Lorax got lifted and taken away . . .

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: It all started way back . . . such a long, long time back . . .

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: What back in the days when the grass was still green and the pond was still wet and the clouds were still clean, and the song of the Swomee-Swans rang out in space . . . one morning, I came to this glorious place.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And I first saw the trees!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: The Truffula Trees!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: The bright-colored tufts of the Truffula Trees!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Mile after mile in the fresh morning breeze.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And under the trees, I saw Brown Bar-ba-loots frisking about in their Bar-ba-loot suits as they played in the shade and ate Truffula Fruits.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: From the rippulous pond came the comfortable sound of the Humming-Fish humming while splashing around.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: But those trees!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Those trees!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Those Truffula Trees!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: All my life I'd been searching for trees such as these.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: The touch of their tufts was much softer than silk.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And they had the sweet smell of fresh butterfly milk.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I felt a great leaping of joy in my heart.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I knew just what I'd do!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I unloaded my cart.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: In no time at all, I had built a small shop.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Then I chopped down a Truffula Tree with one chop.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And with great skillful skill and with great speedy speed, I took the soft tuft.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And I knitted a Thneed!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: The instant I'd finished, I heard a ga-Zump!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I looked.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I saw something pop out of the stump of the tree I'd chopped down.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: It was sort of a man.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Describe him? . . .

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: That's hard.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I don't know if I can.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: He was shortish.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And oddish.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And brownish.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And mossy.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And he spoke with a voice that was sharpish and bossy.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Mister! he said with a sawdusty sneeze, I am the Lorax.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I speak for the trees.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I speak for the trees, for the trees have no tongues.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And I'm asking you, sir, at the top of my lungs – he was very upset as he shouted and puffed – What's that thing you've made out of my Turffula tuft?

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Look, Lorax, I said.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: There's no cause for alarm.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I chopped just one tree.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I am doing no harm.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I'm being quite useful.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: This thing is a Thneed.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: A Thneed's a Fine-Something-That-All-People-Need!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: It's a shirt.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: It's a sock.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: It's a glove.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: It's a hat.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: But it has other uses.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Yes, far beyond that.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: You can use it for carpets.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: For pillows!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: For sheets!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Or curtains!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Or covers for bicycle seats!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: The Lorax said, Sir! You are crazy with greed.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: There is no one on earth who would buy that fool Thneed!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: But the very next minute I proved he was wrong.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: For, just at the minute, a chap came along, and he thought that the Thneed I had knitted was great.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: He happily bought it for three ninety-eight.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I laughed at the Lorax, You poor stupid guy!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: You never can tell what some people will buy.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I repeat, cried the Lorax, I speak for the trees!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I'm busy, I told him.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Shut up, if you please.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I rushed 'cross the room, and in no time at all, built a radio-phone.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I put in a quick call.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I called all my brothers and uncles and aunts and I said, Listen here! Here's a wonderful chance for the whole Once-ler Family to get mighty rich!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Get over here fast!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Take the road to North Nitch.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Turn left at Weehawken.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Sharp right at South Stitch.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And, in no time at all, in the factory I built, the whole Once-ler Family was working full tilt.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: We were all knitting Thneeds just as busy as bees, to the sound of the chopping of Truffula Trees.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Then . . .

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Oh!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Baby!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Oh!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: How my business did grow!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Now, chopping one tree at a time was too slow.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: So I quickly invented my Super-Axe-Hacker which whacked off four Truffula Trees at one smacker.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: We were making Thneeds four times as fast as before!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And that Lorax? . . .

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: He didn't show up any more.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: But the next week he knocked on my new office door.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: He snapped, I'm the Lorax who speaks for the trees which you seem to be chopping as fast as you please.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: But I'm also in charge of the Brown Bar-ba-loots who played in the shade in their Bar-ba-loot suits and happily lived, eating Truffula Fruits.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Now . . . thanks to your hacking my trees to the ground, there's not enough Truffula Fruit to go 'round.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And my poor Bar-ba-loots are all getting the crummies because they have gas, and no food, in their tummies!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: They loved living here.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: But I can't let them stay.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: They'll have to find food.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And I hope that they may.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Good luck, boys, he cried.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And he sent them away.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I, the Once-ler, felt sad as I watched them all go.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: But . . . business is business!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And businesses must grow regardless of crummies in tummies, you know.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I meant no harm.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I most truly did not.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: But I had to grow bigger.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: So bigger I got.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I biggered by factory.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I biggered my roads.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I biggered my wagons.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I biggered the loads of the Thneeds I shipped out.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I was shipping them forth to the South!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: To the East!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: To the West!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: To the North!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I went right on biggering . . . selling more Thneeds.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And I biggered my money, which everyone needs.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Then again he came back!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I was fixing some pipes with that old-nuisance Lorax came back with more gripes.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I am the Lorax, he coughed and he whiffed.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: He sneezed and he snuffled.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: He snarggled.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: He sniffed.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Once-ler! he cried with a cruffulous croak.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Once-ler!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: You're making such smogulous smoke!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: My poor Swomee-Swans . . . why, they can't sing a note!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: No on can sign who has smog in his throat.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And so, said the Lorax, - please pardon my cough – they cannot live here.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: So I'm sending them off.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Where will they go? . . .

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I don't hopefully know.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: They may have to fly for a month . . . or a year . . .

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: To escape from the smog you've smogged-up around here.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: What's more, snapped the Lorax.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: (His dander was up.)

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Let me say a few words about Gluppity-Glupp.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Your machinery chugs on, day and night without stop making Gluppity-Glupp.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Also Schloppity-Schlopp.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And what do you do with this leftover goo? . . .

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I'll show you.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: You dirty old Once-ler man, you!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: You're glumping the pond where the Humming-Fish hummed!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: No more can they hum, for their gills are all gummed.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: So I'm sending them off.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Oh, their future is dreary.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: They'll walk on their fins and get woefully weary in search of some water that isn't so smeary.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And then I got mad.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I got terribly mad.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I yelled at the Lorax, Now listen here, Dad!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: All you do is yap-yap and say, 'Bad! Bad! Bad! Bad!'

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Well, I have my rights, sir, and I'm telling you I intend to go on doing just what I do!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And, for your information, you Lorax, I'm figgering on biggering and biggering and biggering and biggering, turning more Truffula Trees into Thneeds which everyone, everyone, everyone needs!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And at that very moment, we heard a loud whack!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: From outside in the fields came a sickening smack of an axe on a tree.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Then we heard the tree fall.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: The very last Truffula Tree of them all!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: No more trees.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: No more Thneeds.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: No more work to be done.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: So, in no time, my uncles and aunts, every one, all waved me good-bye.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: They jumped into my cars and drove away under the smoke-smuggered stars.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Now all that was left ‘neath the bad-smelling sky was my big empty factory . . . the Lorax . . . and I.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: The Lorax said nothing.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Just gave me a glance . . . just gave me a sad, sad backward glance . . . as he lifted himself by the seat of his pants.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And I'll never forget the grim look on his face when he heisted himself and took leave of this place, through a hole in the smog, without leaving a trace.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And all the Lorax left here in this mess was a small pile of rocks, with one word . . . unless.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Whatever that meant, well, I just couldn't guess.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: That was long, long, ago.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: But each day since that day I've sat here and worried and worried away.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Through the years, while my buildings have fallen apart, I've worried about it with all of my heart.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: But now, says the Once-ler, Now that you're here, the word of the Lorax seems perfectly clear.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Unless someone like you cares a while awful lot, nothing is going to get better.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: It's not.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: So . . .

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Catch! calls the Once-ler.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: He lets something fall.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: It's a Truffula Seed.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: It's the last one of all!

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: You're in charge of the last of the Truffula Seeds.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And Truffula Trees are what everyone needs.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Plant a new Truffula.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Treat it with care.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Give it clean water.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And feed it fresh air.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Grow a forest.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Protect it from axes that hack.

title: THE LORAX
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Then the Lorax and all of his friends may come back.

title: THE RUNAWAY BUNNY
author: MARGARET WISE BROWN
text: Once there was a little bunny who wanted to run away.

title: THE RUNAWAY BUNNY
author: MARGARET WISE BROWN
text: So he said to his mother, I am running away.

title: THE RUNAWAY BUNNY
author: MARGARET WISE BROWN
text: If you run away said, his mother, I will run after you.

title: THE RUNAWAY BUNNY
author: MARGARET WISE BROWN
text: For you are my little bunny.

title: THE RUNAWAY BUNNY
author: MARGARET WISE BROWN
text: If you run after me, said the little bunny, I will become a fish in a trout stream and I will swim away from you.

title: THE RUNAWAY BUNNY
author: MARGARET WISE BROWN
text: If you become a fish in a trout stream, said his mother,

title: THE RUNAWAY BUNNY
author: MARGARET WISE BROWN
text: I will become a fisherman and I will fish for you.

title: THE RUNAWAY BUNNY
author: MARGARET WISE BROWN
text: If you become a fisherman, said the little bunny, I will become a rock on the mountain, high above you.

title: THE RUNAWAY BUNNY
author: MARGARET WISE BROWN
text: If you become a rock on the mountain high above me, said his mother, I will be a mountain climber, and I will climb to where you are.

title: THE RUNAWAY BUNNY
author: MARGARET WISE BROWN
text: If you become a mountain climber, said the little bunny, I will be a crocus in a hidden garden.

title: THE RUNAWAY BUNNY
author: MARGARET WISE BROWN
text: If you become a crocus in a hidden garden, said his mother, I will be a gardener.

title: THE RUNAWAY BUNNY
author: MARGARET WISE BROWN
text: And I will find you.

title: THE RUNAWAY BUNNY
author: MARGARET WISE BROWN
text: If you are a gardener and find me, said the little bunny, I will be a bird and fly away from you.

title: THE RUNAWAY BUNNY
author: MARGARET WISE BROWN
text: If you become a bird and fly away from me, said his mother, I will be a tree that you come home to.

title: THE RUNAWAY BUNNY
author: MARGARET WISE BROWN
text: If you become a tree, said the little bunny, I will become a little sailboat, and I will sail away from you.

title: THE RUNAWAY BUNNY
author: MARGARET WISE BROWN
text: If you become a sailboat and sail away from me, said his mother, I will become the wind and blow you where I want you to go.

title: THE RUNAWAY BUNNY
author: MARGARET WISE BROWN
text: If you become the wind and blow me, said the little bunny, I will join a circus and fly away on a flying trapeze.

title: THE RUNAWAY BUNNY
author: MARGARET WISE BROWN
text: If you go flying on a flying trapeze, said his mother, I will be a tightrope walker, and I will walk across the air to you.

title: THE RUNAWAY BUNNY
author: MARGARET WISE BROWN
text: If you become a tightrope walker and walk across the air, said the bunny, I will become a little boy and run into a house.

title: THE RUNAWAY BUNNY
author: MARGARET WISE BROWN
text: If you become a little boy and run into a house, said the mother bunny, I will become your mother and catch you in my arms and hug you.

title: THE RUNAWAY BUNNY
author: MARGARET WISE BROWN
text: Shucks, said the bunny, I might just as well stay where I am and be your little bunny.

title: THE RUNAWAY BUNNY
author: MARGARET WISE BROWN
text: And so he did.

title: THE RUNAWAY BUNNY
author: MARGARET WISE BROWN
text: Have a carrot, said the mother bunny.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: I went to sleep with gum in my mouth and now there's gum in my hair and when I got out of bed this morning I tripped on the skateboard and by mistake I dropped my sweater in the sink while the water was running and I could tell it was going to be a terrible, horrible, no good, very bad day.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: At breakfast Anthony found a corvette Sting Ray car kit in his breakfast cereal box and Nick found a junior undercover Agent code ring in his breakfast cereal box but in my breakfast cereal box all I found was breakfast cereal.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: I think I'll move to Australia.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: In the car pool Mrs. Gibson let Becky have a sear by the window.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: Audrey and Elliott got seats by the window too.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: I said I was being scrunched.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: I said I was being smushed.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: I said, if I don't get a seat by the window I am going to be carsick.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: No one even answered.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: I could tell it was going to be a terrible, horrible, no good, very bad day.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: At school Mrs. Dickens liked Paul's picture of the sailboat better than my picture of the invisible castle.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: At singing time she said I sang too loud.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: At counting time she said I left out sixteen.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: Who needs sixteen?

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: I could tell it was going to be a terrible, horrible, no good, very bad day.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: I could tell because Paul said I wasn't his best friend anymore.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: He said that Philip Parker was his best friend and that Albert Moyo was his next best friend and that I was only his third best friend.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: I hope you sit on a tack, I said to Paul.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: I hope the next time you get a double decker strawberry ice-cream cone the ice cream part falls off the cone part and lands in Australia.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: There were two cupcakes in Philip Parker's lunch bag and Albert got a Hershey bar with almonds and Paul's mother gave him a piece of jelly roll that had little coconut sprinkles on the top.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: Guess whose mother forgot to put in dessert?

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: It was a terrible, horrible, no good, very bad day.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: That's what it was, because after school my mom took us all to the dentist and Dr. Fields found a cavity just in me.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: Come back next week and I'll fix it, said Dr. Fields.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: Next week, I said, I'm going to Australia.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: On the way downstairs the elevator door closed on my foot and while we were waiting for my mom to go get the car Anthony made me fall where it was muddy and then when I started crying because of the mud Nick said I was a crybaby and while I was punching Nick for saying crybaby my mom came back with the car and scolded me for being muddy and fighting.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: I am having a terrible, horrible, no good, very bad day, I told everybody.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: No one even answered.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: So then we went to the shoe store to buy some sneakers.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: Anthony chose white ones with blue stripes.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: Nick chose red ones with white stripes.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: I chose blue ones with red stripes but then the shoe man said, we're all sold out.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: They made me buy plain old white ones, but they can't make me wear them.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: When we picked up my dad at his office he said I couldn't play with his copying machine, but I forgot.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: He also said to watch out for the books on his desk, and I was careful as could be except for my elbow.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: He also said don't fool around with his phone, but I think I called Australia.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: My dad said please don't pick him up anymore.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: It was a terrible, horrible, no good, very bad day.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: There were lima beans for dinner and I hate limas.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: There was kissing on TV and I hate kissing.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: My bath was too hot, I got soap in my eyes, my marble went down the drain, and I had to wear my railroad-train pajamas.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: I hate my railroad-train pajamas.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: When I went to bed Nick took back the pillow he said I could keep and the Mickey Mouse night light burned out and I bit my tongue.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: The cat wants to sleep with Anthony, not me.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: It has been a terrible, horrible, no good, very bad day.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: My mom says some days are like that.

title: ALEXANDER AND THE TERRIBLE, HORRIBLE, NO GOOD, VERY BAD DAY
author: JUDITH VIORST
text: Even in Australia

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Camilla Cream loved lima beans.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: But she never ate them.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: All of her friends hated lima beans, and she wanted to fit in.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Camilla was always worried about what other people thought of her.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Today she was fretting even more than usual.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: It was the first day of school, and she couldn't decide what to wear.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: There were so many people to impress!

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: She tried on forty-two outfits, but none seemed quite right.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: She put on a pretty red dress and looked in the mirror.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Then she screamed.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Her mother ran into the room, and she screamed, too.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Oh my heavens! she cried.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: You're completely covered with stripes!

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: This was certainly true.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Camilla was striped from head to toe.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: She looked like a rainbow.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Mrs. Cream felt Camilla's forehead.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Do you feel all right? she asked.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: I feel fine, Camilla answered, but just look at me!

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: You get back in bed this instant, her mother ordered.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: You're not going to school today.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Camilla was relieved.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: She didn't want to miss the first day of school, but she was afraid of what the other kids would say.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: And she had no idea what to wear with those crazy stripes.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: That afternoon, Dr. Bumble came to examine Camilla.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Most extraordinary! he exclaimed.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: l've never seen anything like it.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Are you having any coughing, sneezing, runny nose, aches, pains, chills, hot flashes, dizziness, drowsiness, shortness of breath, or uncontrollable twitching?

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: No, Camilla told him.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: I feel fine.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Well then, Dr. Bumble said, turning to Mrs. Cream, l don't see any reason why she shouldn't go to school tomorrow.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Here's some ointment that should help clear up those stripes in a few days.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: If it doesn't, you know where to reach me.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: And off he went.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: The next day was a disaster.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Everyone at school laughed at Camilla.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: They called her Camilla Crayon and Night of the Living Lollipop.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: She tried her best to act as if everything were normal, but when the class said the Pledge of Allegiance, her stripes turned red, white, and blue, and she broke out in stars!

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: The other kids thought this was great.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: One yelled out, Let's see some purple polka dots!

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Sure enough, Camilla turned all purple polka-dotty.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Someone else shouted, Checkerboard! and a pattern of squares covered her skin.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Soon everyone was calling out different shapes and colors, and poor Camilla was changing faster than you can change channels on a T.V.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: That night, Mr. Harms, the school principal, called.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: l'm sorry, Mrs. Cream, he said.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: I'm going to have to ask you to keep Camilla home from school.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: She's just too much of a distraction, and I've been getting calls from the other parents.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: They're afraid those stripes may be contagious.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Camilla was so embarrassed.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: She couldn't believe that two days ago everyone liked her.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Now, nobody wanted to be in the same room with her.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Her father tried to make her feel better.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Is there anything I can get you, sweetheart? he asked.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: No, thank you, sighed Camilla.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: What she really wanted was a nice plate of lima beans, but she had been laughed at enough for one day.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Hmm, well, yes, I see, Dr. Bumble mumbled when Mr. Cream phoned the next day.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: I think I'd better bring in the Specialists.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: We'll be right over.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: About an hour later, Dr. Bumble arrived with four people in long white coats.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: He introduced them to the Creams.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: This is Dr. Grop, Dr. Sponge, Dr. Cricket, and Dr. Young.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Then the Specialists went to work on Camilla.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: They squeezed and jabbed, tapped and tested.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: It was very uncomfortable.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Well, it's not the mumps, concluded Dr. Grop.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Or the measles, said Dr. Sponge.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Definitely not chicken pox, put in Dr. Cricket.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Or sunburn, said Dr. Young.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Try these, said the Specialists.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: They each handed her a bottle filled with different colored pills.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Take one of each before bed, said Dr. Grop.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Then they filed out the front door, followed by Dr. Bumble.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: That night, Camilla took her medicine.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: It was awful.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: When she woke up the next morning, she did feel different, but when she got dressed, her clothes didn't fit right.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: She looked in the mirror, and there, staring back at her, was a giant, multi colored pill with her face on it.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Dr. Bumble rushed over as soon as Mrs. Cream called.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: But this time, instead of the Specialists, he brought the Experts.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Dr. Gourd and Mr. Mellon were the finest scientific minds in the land.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Once again, Camilla was poked and prodded, looked at and listened to.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: The Experts wrote down lots of numbers.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Then they huddled together and whispered.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Dr. Gourd finally spoke.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: It might be a virus, he announced with authority.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Suddenly, fuzzy little virus balls appeared all over Camilla.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Or possibly some form of bacteria, said Mr. Mellon.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Out popped squiggly little bacteria tails.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Or it could be a fungus, added Dr. Gourd.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Instantly, Camilla was covered with different colored fungus blotches.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: The Experts looked at Camilla, then at each other.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: We need to go over these numbers again back at the lab, Dr. Gourd explained.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: We'll call you when we know something.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: But the experts didn't have a clue, much less a cure.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: By now, the T.V. news had found out about Camilla.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Reporters from every channel were outside her house, telling the story of The Bizarre Case of the Incredible Changing Kid.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Soon a huge crowd was camped out on the front lawn.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: The Creams were swamped with all kinds of remedies from psychologists, allergists, herbalists, nutritionists, psychics, an old medicine man, a guru, and even a veterinarian.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Each so-called cure only added to poor Camilla's strange appearance until it was hard to even recognize her.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: She sprouted roots and berries and crystals and feathers and a long furry tail.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: But nothing worked.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: One day, a woman who called herself an Environmental Therapist claimed she could cure Camilla.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Close your eyes, she said.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Breathe deeply, and become one with your room.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: I wish you hadn't said that, Camilla groaned.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Slowly, she started to melt into the walls of her room.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Her bed became her mouth, her nose was a dresses, and two paintings were her eyes.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: The therapist screamed and ran from the house.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: What are we going to do? cried Mrs. Cream.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: It just keeps getting worse and worse! She began to sob.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: At that moment, Mr. Cream heard a quiet little knock at the front door.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: He opened it, and there stood an old woman who was just as plump and sweet as a strawberry.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Excuse me, she said brightly.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: But I think I can help.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: She went into Camilla's room and looked around.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: My goodness, she said with a shake of her head.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: What we have here is a bad case of stripes.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: One of the worst I've ever seen!

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: She pulled a container of small green beans from her bag.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Here, she said.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: These might do the trick.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Are those magic beans? asked Mrs. Cream.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Oh my, ho, replied the kind old woman.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: There's no such thing. These are just plain old lima beans.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: I'll bet you'd like some, wouldn't you? she asked Camilla.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Camilla wanted a big, heaping plateful of lima beans more than just about anything, but she was still afraid to admit it.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Yuck! she said.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: No one likes lima beans, especially me!

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Oh, dear, the old woman said sadly.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: l guess I was wrong about you.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: She put the beans back in her bag and started toward the door.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Camilla watched the old woman walk away.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Those beans would taste so good.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: And being laughed at for eating them was nothing, compared to what she'd been going through.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: She finally couldn't stand it.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Wait! she cried.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: The truth is . . . I really love lima beans.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: l thought so, the old woman said with a smile.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: She took a handful of beans and popped them into Camilla's mouth.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Mmmm, said Camilla.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Suddenly the branches, feathers, and squiggly tails began to disappear.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Then the whole room swirled around.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: When it stopped, there stood Camilla, and everything was back to normal.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: I'm cured! she shouted.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Yes, said the old woman.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: I knew the real you was in there somewhere.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: She patted Camilla on the head.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Then she went outside and vanished into the crowd.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Afterward, Camilla wasn't quite the same.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: Some of the kids at school said she was weird, but she didn't care a bit.

title: A BAD CASE OF STRIPES
author: DAVID SHANNON
text: She ate all the lima beans she wanted, and she never had even a touch of stripes again.

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Hi! I'm the

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: bus driver. Listen,

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: I've got to leave

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: for a little while,

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: so can you watch

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: things for me until

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: I get back? Thanks.

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Oh, and remember:

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Don't Let

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: the Pigeon

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Drive the Bus!

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: I thought he'd never leave.

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Hey, can I drive the bus?

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Please?

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: I'll be careful.

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: I tell you what: I'll just steer.

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: My cousin Herb drives a bus almost every day!

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: True story.

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: VROOM-VROOM VROOMY VROOM-VROOM!

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: PIGEON AT THE WHEEL!

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: No?

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: I never get to do anything!

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Hey, I've got an idea.

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Let's play Drive the Bus!

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: I'll go first!

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: C'mon!

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Just once around the block!

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: I'll be your best friend!

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: How ‘bout I give you five bucks?

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: No fair!

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: I bet your mom would let me.

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: What's the big deal!?

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: It's just a bus!!!

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: I have dreams, you know!

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Fine.

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: LET ME DRIVE THE BUS!!!

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: I'm back!

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: You didn't let the pigeon drive the bus, did you?

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Great!

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Thanks a lot.

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Bye!

title: DON'T LET THE PIGEON DRIVE THE BUS
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Hey. . .

title: THE NAPPING HOUSE
author: AUDREY WOOD
text: There is a house, a napping house, where everyone is sleeping.

title: THE NAPPING HOUSE
author: AUDREY WOOD
text: And in that house there is a bed, a cozy bed in a napping house, where everyone is sleeping.

title: THE NAPPING HOUSE
author: AUDREY WOOD
text: And on that bed there is a granny, a snoring granny on a cozy bed in a napping house, where everyone is sleeping.

title: THE NAPPING HOUSE
author: AUDREY WOOD
text: And on that granny there is a child, a dreaming child on a snoring granny on a cozy bed in a napping house, where everyone is sleeping.

title: THE NAPPING HOUSE
author: AUDREY WOOD
text: And on that child there is a dog, a dozing dog on a dreaming child on a snoring granny on a cozy bed in a napping house, where everyone is sleeping.

title: THE NAPPING HOUSE
author: AUDREY WOOD
text: And on that dog there is a cat, a snoozing cat on a dozing dog on a dreaming child on a snoring granny on a cozy bed in a napping house, where everyone is sleeping.

title: THE NAPPING HOUSE
author: AUDREY WOOD
text: And on that cat there is a mouse, a slumbering mouse on a snoozing cat on a dozing dog on a dreaming child on a snoring granny on a cozy bed in a napping house where everyone is sleeping.

title: THE NAPPING HOUSE
author: AUDREY WOOD
text: And on that mouse there is a flea. . .

title: THE NAPPING HOUSE
author: AUDREY WOOD
text: Can it be?

title: THE NAPPING HOUSE
author: AUDREY WOOD
text: A wakeful flea on a slumbering mouse on a snoozing cat on a dozing dog on a dreaming child on a snoring granny on a cozy bed in a napping house, where everyone is sleeping.

title: THE NAPPING HOUSE
author: AUDREY WOOD
text: A wakeful flea who bites the mouse, who scares the cat, who claws the dog, who thumps the child, who bumps the granny, who breaks the bed, in the napping house, where no one now is sleeping.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Mike Mulligan had a steam shovel, a beautiful red steam shovel.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Her name was Mary Anne.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Mike Mulligan was very proud of Mary Anne.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: He always said that she could dig as much in a day as a hundred men could dig in a week, but he had never been quite sure that this was true.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne had been digging together for years and years.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Mike Mulligan took such good care of Mary Anne she never grew old.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: It was Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne and some others who dug the great canals for the big boats to sail through.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: It was Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne and some others who cut through the high mountains so that trains could go through.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: It was Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne and some others who lowered the hills and straightened the curves to make the long highways for the automobiles.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: It was Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne and some others who smoothed out the ground and filled in the holes to make the landing fields for the airplanes.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: And it was Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne and some others who dug the deep holes for the cellars of the tall skyscrapers in the big cities.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: When people used to stop and watch them, Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne used to dig a little faster and a little better.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: The more people stopped, the faster and better they dug.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Some days they would keep as many as thirty-seven trucks busy taking away the dirt they had dug.
