title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Then along came the new gasoline shovels and the new electric shovels and the new Diesel motor shovels and took all the jobs away from the steam shovels.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne were VERY SAD.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: All the other steam shovels were being sold for junk, or left out in old gravel pits to rust and fall apart.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Mike loved Mary Anne.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: He couldn't do that to her.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: He had taken such good care of her that she could still dig as much in a day as a hundred men could dig in a week; at least he thought she could but he wasn't quite sure.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Everywhere they went the new gas shovels and the new electric shovels and the new Diesel motor shovels had all the jobs.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: No one wanted Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne any more.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Then one day Mike read in a newspaper that the town of Popperville was going to build a new town hall.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: We are going to dig the cellar of that town hall, said Mike to Mary Anne, and off they started.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: They left the canals and the railroads and the highways and the airports and the big cities where no one wanted them anymore and went away out in the country.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: They crawled along slowly up the hills and down the hills till they came to the little town of Popperville.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: When they got there they found that the selectmen were just deciding who should dig the cellar for the new town hall.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Mike Mulligan spoke to Henry B. Swap, one of the selectmen.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: I heard, he said, that you are going to build a new town hall.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Mary Anne and I will dig the cellar for you in just one day.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: What! said Henry B. Swap.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Dig a cellar in a day!

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: It would take a hundred men at least a week to dig the cellar for our new town hall.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Sure, said Mike, but Mary Anne can dig as much in a day as a hundred men can dig in a week.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Though he had never been quite sure that this was true.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Then he added, If we can't do it, you won't have to pay.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Henry B. Swap thought that this would be an easy way to get part of the cellar dug for nothing, so he smiled in rather a mean way and gave the job of digging the cellar of the new town hall to Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: They started in early the next morning just as the sun was coming up.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Soon a little boy came along.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Do you think you will finish by sundown? he said to Mike Mulligan.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Sure, said Mike, if you stay and watch us.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: We always work faster and better when someone is watching us.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: So the little boy stayed to watch.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Then Mrs. McGillicuddy, Henry B. Swap, and the Town Constable came over to see what was happening, and they stayed to watch.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne dug a little faster and a little better.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: This gave the little boy a good idea.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: He ran off and told the postman with-the morning mail, the telegraph boy on his bicycle, the milkman with his cart and horse, the doctor on his way home, and the farmer and his family coming into town for the day, and they all stopped and stayed to watch.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: That made Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne dig a little faster and a little better.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: They finished the first corner neat and square. . .  but the sun was getting higher.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Clang!

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Clang!

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Clang!

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: The Fire Department arrived.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: They had seen the smoke and thought there was a fire.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Then the little boy said, Why don't you stay and watch?

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: So the Fire Department of Popperville stayed to watch Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: When they heard the fire engine, the children in the school across the street couldn't keep their eyes on their lessons.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: The teacher called a long recess and the whole school came out to watch.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: That made Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne dig still faster and still better.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: They finished the second corner neat and square, but the sun was right up in the top of the sky.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Now the girl who answers the telephone called up the next towns of Bangerville and Bopperville and Kipperville and Kopperville and told them what was happening in Popperville.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: All the people came over to see if Mike Mulligan and his steam shovel could dig the cellar in just one day.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: The more people came, the faster Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne dug.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: But they would have to hurry.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: They were only halfway and the sun was beginning to go down.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: They finished the third corner. . .  neat and square.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Never had Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne had so many people to watch them; never had they dug so fast and so well; and never, had the sun seemed to go down so fast.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Hurry, Mike Mulligan! Hurry! Hurry!' shouted the little boy.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: There's not much more time!

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Dirt was flying everywhere, and the smoke and steam were so thick that the people could hardly see anything.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: But listen!

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Bing!

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Bang!

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Crash!

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Slam!

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Faster and faster.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Then suddenly it was quiet.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Slowly the dirt settled down.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: The smoke and steam cleared away, and there was the cellar all finished.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Four corners. . .  neat and square; four walls. . .  straight down, and Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne at the bottom, and the sun was just going down behind the hill.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Hurray! shouted the people.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Hurray for Mike Mulligan and his steam shovel!

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: They have dug the cellar in just one day.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Suddenly the little boy said, How are they going to get out?

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: That's right, said Ms. McGillicuddy to Henry B. Swap.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: How is he going to het his steam shovel out?

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Henry B. Swap didn't answer, but he smiled in rather a mean way.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Then everybody said, How are they going to get out?

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Hi!

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Mike Mulligan!

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: How are you going to get your steam shovel out?

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Mike Mulligan looked around at the four square walls and four square corners, and he said, We've dug so fast and we've dug so well that we've quite forgotten to leave a way out!

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Nothing like this had ever happened to Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne before and they didn't know what to do.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Nothing like this had ever happened before in Popperville.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Everybody started talking at once, and everybody had a different idea, and everybody thought that his idea was the best.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: They talked and they talked and they argued and they fought till they were worn out, and still no one knew how to get Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne out of the cellar they had dug.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Then Henry B. Swap said, The job isn't finished because Mary Anne isn't out of the cellar, so Mike Mulligan won't get paid.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: And he smiled again in a rather mean way.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Now the little boy, who had been keeping very quiet, had another good idea.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: He said, why couldn't we leave Mary Anne in the cellar and build the new town hall above her?

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Let her be the furnace for the new town hall and let Mike Mulligan be the janitor.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Then you wouldn't have to buy a new furnace, and we could pay Mike Mulligan for digging the cellar in just one day.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Why not? said Henry B. Swap, and smiled in a way that was not quite so mean.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Why not? said the Town Constable.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Why not? said all the people.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: So they found a ladder and climbed down into the cellar to ask Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Why not? said Mike Mulligan.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: So it was decided, and everybody was happy.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: They built the new town hall right over Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: It was finished before winter.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Every day the little boy goes over to see Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne and Mrs. McGillicuddv takes him nice hot apple pies.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: As for Henry B. Swap, he spends most of his time in the cellar of the new town hall listening to the stories that Mike Mulligan has to tell and smiling in a way that isn't mean at all.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Now when you go to Popperville, be sure to go down in the cellar of the new town hall.

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: There they'll be, Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne. . .

title: MIKE MULLIGAN AND HIS STEAM SHOVEL
author: VIRGINIA LEE BURTON
text: Mike in his rocking chair smoking his pipe, and Mary Anne beside him warming up his meetings in the new town hall.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: In the great forest a little elephant is born.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: His name is Babar.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: His mother loves him very much.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: She rocks him to sleep with her trunk while singing softly to him.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Babar has grown bigger.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: He now plays with the other little elephants.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: He is a very good little elephant.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: See him digging in the sand with his shell.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Babar is riding happily on his mother's back when a wicked hunter, hidden behind some bushes, shoots at them.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: The hunter has killed Babar's mother!

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: The monkey hides, the birds fly away, Babar cries.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: The hunter runs up to catch Babar.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Babar runs away because he is afraid of the hunter.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: After several days, very tired indeed, he comes to a town. . .

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: He hardly knows what to make of it because this is the first time that he has seen so many houses.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: So many things are new to him!

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: The broad streets!

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: The automobiles and buses!

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: However, he is especially interested in two gentlemen he notices on the street.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: He says to himself: Really, they are very well dressed.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: I would like to have some fine clothes, too!

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: I wonder how I can get them?

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Luckily, a very rich Old Lady who has always been fond of little elephants understands right away that he is longing for a fine suit.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: As she likes to make people happy, she gives him her purse.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Babar says to her politely: Thank you, Madam.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Without wasting any time, Babar goes into a big store.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: He enters the elevator.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: It is such fun to ride up and down in this funny box, that he rides all the way up ten times and all the way down ten times.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: He did not want to stop but the elevator boy finally said to him: This is not a toy, Mr. Elephant.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: You must get out and do your shopping.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Look, here is the floorwalker.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Babar then buys himself: a shirt with a collar and a tie, a suit of a becoming shade of green, then a handsome derby hat, and also shoes with spats.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Well satisfied with his purchases and feeling elegant indeed, Babar now goes to the photographer to have his picture taken.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: And here is his photograph.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Babar dines with his friend the Old Lady.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: She thinks he looks very smart in his new clothes.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: After dinner, because he is tired, he goes to bed and falls asleep very quickly.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Babar now lives at the Old Lady's house.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: In the mornings, he does setting-up exercises with her, and then takes his bath.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: He goes out for an automobile ride every day.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: The Old Lady has given him a car.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: She gives him whatever he wants.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: A learned professor gives him lessons.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Babar pays attention and does well in his work.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: He is a good pupil and makes rapid progress.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: In the evening, after dinner, he tells the Old Lady's friends about his life in the great forest.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: However, Babar is not quite happy, for he misses playing in the great forest with his little cousins and his friends, the monkeys.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: He often stands at the window, thinking sadly of his childhood, and cries when he remembers his mother.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Two years have passed.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: one day during his walk he sees two little elephants coming toward him.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: They have no clothes on.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Why, he says in astonishment to the Old Lady, it's Arthur and Celeste, my little cousins!

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Babar kisses them affectionately and hurries off with them to buy them some fine clothes.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: He takes them to a pastry shop to eat some good cakes.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Meanwhile, in the forest, the elephants are searching high and low for Arthur and Celeste, and their mothers are worried.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Fortunately, in flying over the town, an old marabou bird has seen them and comes back quickly to tell the news.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: The mothers of Arthur and Celeste have come to the town to fetch them back but they scold them just the same because they ran away.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Babar makes up his mind to go back with Arthur and Celeste and their mothers to see the great forest again,

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: The Old Lady helps him to pack his trunk.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: They are all ready to start.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Babar kisses the Old Lady good-bye.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: He would be quite happy to go if it were not for leaving her.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: He promises to come back some day.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: He will never forget her.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: They have gone. . . .

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: There is no room in the car for the mothers, so they run behind, and lift up their trunks to avoid breathing the dust.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: The Old Lady is left alone.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Sadly she wonders: When shall I see my little Babar again?

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Alas, that very day, the King of the elephants had eaten a bad mushroom.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: It poisoned him and he became ill, so ill that he died.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: This was a great calmity.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: After the funeral the oldest elephants were holding a meeting to choose a new king.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Just then they hear a noise.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: They turn around.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Guess what they see!

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Babar arriving in his car and all the elephants running and shouting:  Here they are!

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Here they are!

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Hello, Babar!

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Hello, Arthur!

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Hello, Celeste!

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: What beautiful clothes!

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: What a beautiful car!

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Then Cornelius, the oldest of all the elephants, spoke in his quavering voice: My good friends we are seeking a King.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Why not choose Babar?

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: He has just returned from the big city, he has learned so much among living men.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Let us crown him King.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: All the other elephants thought that Cornelius had spoken wisely and eagerly await Babar's reply.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: I want to thank you one and all, said Babar, but before accepting your proposal, I must explain to you that, while traveling in the car, Celeste and I became engaged.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: If I become your King, she will be your Queen.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Long live Queen Celeste!

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Long live King Babar!, cry all the elephants without a moment's hesitation.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: And thus it was that Babar became King.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: You have good ideas, said Babar to Cornelius.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: I will therefore make you a general, and when I get my crown, I will give you my hat.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: In a week I shall marry Celeste.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: We will have a spendid party in honor of our marriage and our coronation.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Then, turning to the birds, Babar asks them to go and invite all the animals to the festivities, and he tells the dromedary to go to the town and buy some beautiful wedding clothes.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: The wedding guests begin to arrive.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: The dromedary returns with the bridal costumes just in the nick of time for the ceremony.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: After the wedding and the coronation everybody dances merrily.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: The festivities are over, night has fallen, the stars have risen in the sky.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: King Babar and Queen Celeste are indeed very happy.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: Now the world is asleep.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: The guests have gone home, happy, though tired from too much dancing.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: They will long remember this great celebration.

title: THE STORY OF BABAR
author: JEAN DE BRUNHOFF
text: And now King Babar and Queen Celeste, both eager for further adventures, set out on their honeymoon in a gorgeous yellow balloon.

title: WHERE THE WILD THINGS ARE
author: MAURICE SENDAK
text: The night Max wore his wolf suit and made mischief of one kind and another his mother called his Wild Thing! and Max said I'll eat you up! so he was sent to bed without eating anything.

title: WHERE THE WILD THINGS ARE
author: MAURICE SENDAK
text: That night in Max's room a forest grew and grew- and grew until his ceiling hung with vines and the walls became the world all around and an ocean tumbled by with a private boat for Max and he sailed off through the night and day and in and out of weeks and almost over a year to where the wild things are.

title: WHERE THE WILD THINGS ARE
author: MAURICE SENDAK
text: And when he came to the place where the wild things are they roared their terrible roars and gnashed their terrible teeth and rolled their terrible eyes and showed their terrible claws till Max said Be still! and tamed them with the magic trick of staring into all their yellow eyes without blinking once and they were frightened and called him the most wild thing of all and made him king of all the wild things.

title: WHERE THE WILD THINGS ARE
author: MAURICE SENDAK
text: And now, cried Max, let the wild rumpus start!

title: WHERE THE WILD THINGS ARE
author: MAURICE SENDAK
text: Now stop! Max said and sent all the wild things off to bed without their supper.

title: WHERE THE WILD THINGS ARE
author: MAURICE SENDAK
text: And Max king of all the wild things was lonely and wanted to be where someone loved him best of all.

title: WHERE THE WILD THINGS ARE
author: MAURICE SENDAK
text: Then all around from far away across the world he smelled good things to eat so he gave up being king of where the wild things are.

title: WHERE THE WILD THINGS ARE
author: MAURICE SENDAK
text: But the wild things cried, Oh please don't go-we'll eat you up- we love you so!

title: WHERE THE WILD THINGS ARE
author: MAURICE SENDAK
text: And Max said, No!

title: WHERE THE WILD THINGS ARE
author: MAURICE SENDAK
text: The wild things roared their terrible roars and gnashed their terrible teeth and rolled their terrible eyes and showed their terrible claws but Max stepped into his private boat and wave good-bye and sailed back over a year and in and out of weeks and through a day and into the night of his very own room where he found his supper waiting for him and it was still hot.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Once upon a time there were four little Rabbits and their names were – Flopsy, Mopsy, Cottontail, and Peter.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: They lived with their mother in a sandbank, underneath the root of a very big fir tree.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Now, my dears, said old Mrs. Rabbit one morning, you may go into the fields or down the lane, but don't go into Mr. McGregor's garden: your father had an accident there; he was put in a pie by Mrs. McGregor.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Now run along, and don't get into mischief.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: I am going out.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Then old Mrs. Rabbit took a basket and her umbrella, and went through the wood to the baker's.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: She bought a loaf of brown bread and five currant buns.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Flopsy, Mopsy, and Cottontail, who were good little bunnies, went down the lane to gather blackberries.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: But Peter, who was very naughty, ran straight away to Mr. McGregor's garden, and squeezed under the gate!

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: First he ate some lettuces and some French beans; and then he ate some radishes; and then, feeling rather sick, he went to look for some parsley.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: But round the end of a cucumber frame, whom should be meet but Mr. McGregor!

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Mr. McGregor was on his hands and knees planting out young cabbages, but he jumped up and ran after Peter, waving a rake and calling out, Stop thief!

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Peter was most dreadfully frightened; he rushed all over the garden, for he had forgotten the way back to the gate.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: He lost one of his shoes among the cabbages, and the other shoe amongst the potatoes.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: After losing them, he ran on four legs and went faster, so that I think he might have got away altogether if he had not unfortunately run into a gooseberry net, and got caught by the large buttons on his jacket.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: It was a blue jacket with brass buttons, quite new.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Peter gave himself up for lost, and shed big tears; but his sobs were overheard by some friendly sparrows, who flew to him in great excitement, and implored him to exert himself.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Mr. McGregor came up with a sieve, which he intended to pop upon the top of Peter; but Peter wriggled out just in time, leaving his jacket behind him, and rushed into the toolshed, and jumped into a can.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: It would have been a beautiful thing to hide in, if it had not had so much water in it.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Mr. McGregor was quite sure that Peter was somewhere in the toolshed, perhaps hidden underneath a flowerpot.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: He began to turn them over carefully, looking under each.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Presently Peter sneezed – Kertyschoo!

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Mr. McGregor was after him in no time, and tried to put his foot upon Peter, who jumped out of a window, upsetting three plants.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: The window was too small for Mr. McGregor, and he was tired of running after Peter.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: He went back to his work.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Peter sat down to rest.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: He was out of breath and trembling with fright, and he had no the least idea which way to go.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Also, he was very damp with sitting in that can.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: After a time began to wander about, going lippity – lippity – not very fast, and looking all around.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: He found a door in a wall; but it was locked, and there was no room for a fat little rabbit to squeeze underneath.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: An old mouse was running in and out over the stone doorstep, carrying peas and beans to her family in the wood.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Peter asked her the way to the gate, but she had such a large pea in her mouth that she could not answer.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: She only shook her head at him.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Peter began to cry.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Then he tried to find his way straight across the garden, but he became more and more puzzled.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Presently, he came to a pond where Mr. McGregor filled his water cans.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: A white cat was staring at some goldfish; she sat very, very still, but now and then the tip of her tail twitched as if it were alive.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Peter thought it best to go away without speaking to her; he had heard about cats from his cousin, little Benjamin Bunny.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: He went back towards the toolshed, but suddenly, quite close to him, he heard the noise of a hoe – scr-r-ritch, scratch, scratch, scritch.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Peter scuttered underneath the bushes.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: But presently, as nothing happened, he came out, and climbed upon a wheelbarrow, and peeped over.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: The first thing he saw was Mr. McGregor hoeing his onions.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: His back was turned towards Peter, and beyond him was the gate.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Peter got down very quietly off the wheelbarrow, and started running as fast as he could go, along a straight walk behind some black-currant bushes.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Mr. McGregor caught sight of him at the corner, but Peter did not care.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: He slipped underneath the gate, and was safe at last in the wood outside the garden.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Mr. McGregor hung up the little jacket and the shoes for a scarecrow to frighten blackbirds.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: Peter never stopped running or looked behind him till he got home to the big fir tree.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: He was so tired that he flopped down upon the nice soft sand on the floor of the rabbit hole, and shut his eyes.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: His mother was busy cooking; she wondered what he had done with his clothes.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: It was the second little jacket and pair of shoes that Peter had lost in a fortnight!

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: I'm sorry to say that Peter was not very well during the evening.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: His mother put him to bed, and made some chamomile tea; and she gave a dose of it to Peter!

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: One tablespoonful to be taken at bedtime.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: But Flopsy, Mopsy, and Cottontail had bread and milk and blackberries for supper.

title: THE TALE OF PETER RABBIT
author: BEATRIX POTTER
text: The End.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: Once upon a time in Spain there was a little bull and his name was Ferdinand.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: All the other little bulls he lived with would run and jump and butt their heads together, but not Ferdinand.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: He liked to sit just quietly and smell the flowers.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: He had a favorite spot out in the pasture under a cork tree.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: It was his favorite tree and he would sit in its shade all day and smell the flowers.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: Sometimes his mother, who was a cow, would worry about him.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: She was afraid he would be lonesome all by himself.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: Why don't you run and play with the other little bulls and skip and butt your head? she would say.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: But Ferdinand would shake his head.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: I like it better here where I can sit just quietly and smell the flowers.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: His mother saw that he was not lonesome, and because she was an understanding mother, even though she was a cow, she let him just sit there and be happy.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: As the years went by Ferdinand grew and grew until he was very big and strong.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: All the other bulls who had grown up with him in the same pasture would fight each other all day.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: They would butt each other and stick each other with their horns.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: What they wanted most of all was to be picked to fight at the bull fights in Madrid.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: But not Ferdinand - he still liked to sit just quietly under the cork tree and smell the flowers.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: One day five men came in very funny hats to pick the biggest, fastest, roughest bull to fight in the bull fights in Madrid.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: All the other bulls ran around snorting and butting, leaping and jumping so the men would think that they were very very strong and fierce and pick them.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: Ferdinand knew that they wouldn't pick him and he didn't care.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: So he went out to his favorite cork tree to sit down.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: He didn't look where he was sitting and instead of sitting on the nice cool grass in the shade he sat on a bumble bee.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: Well, if you were a bumble bee and a bull sat on you what would you do?

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: You would sting him.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: And that is just what this bee did to Ferdinand.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: Wow!

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: Did it hurt!

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: Ferdinand jumped up with a snort.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: He ran around puffing and snorting, butting and pawing the ground as if he were crazy.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: The five men saw him and they all shouted with joy.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: Here was the largest and fiercest bull of all.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: Just the one for the bull fights in Madrid!

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: So they rook him away for the bull fight day in a cart.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: What a day it was!

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: Flags were flying, bands were playing . . . and all the lovely ladies had flowers in their hair.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: They had a parade into the bull ring.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: First came the Banderilleros with long sharp pins with ribbons on them to stick in the bull and make him mad.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: Next came the Picadores who rode skinny horses and they had long spears to stick in the bull and make him madder.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: Then came the Matador, the proudest of all - he thought he was very handsome, and bowed to the ladies.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: He had a red cape and a sword and was supposed to stick the bull last of all.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: Then came the bull, and you know who that was don't you?

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: Ferdinand.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: They called him Ferdinand the Fierce and all the Banderilleros were afraid of him and the Picadores were afraid of him and the Matador was scared stiff.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: Ferdinand ran to the middle of the ring and everyone shouted and clapped because they thought he was going to fight fiercely and butt and snort and stick his horns around.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: But not Ferdinand.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: When he got to the middle of the ring he saw the flowers in all the lovely ladies' hair and he just sat down quietly and smelled.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: He wouldn't fight and be fierce no matter what they did.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: He just sat and smelled.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: And the Banderilleros were mad and the Picadores were madder and the Matador was so mad he cried because he couldn't show off with his cape and sword.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: So they had to take Ferdinand home.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: And for all I know he is sitting there still, under his favorite cork tree, smelling the flowers just quietly.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: He is very happy.

title: THE STORY OF FERDINAND
author: MUNRO LEAF
text: The end

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: A mother bird sat on her egg.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: The egg jumped.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Oh oh! said the mother bird.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: My baby will be here!

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: He will want to eat.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: I must get something for my baby bird to eat! she said.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: I will be back!

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: So away she went.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: The egg jumped.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: It jumped, and jumped, and jumped!

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Out came the baby bird!

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Where is my mother? he said.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: He looked for her.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: He looked up.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: He did not see her.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: He looked down.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: He did not see her.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: I will go and look for her, he said.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: So away he went.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Down, out of the tree he went.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Down, down, down!

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: It was a long way down.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: The baby bird could not fly.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: He could not fly, but he could walk.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Now I will go and find my mother, he said.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: He did not know what his mother looked like.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: He went right by her.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: He did not see her.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: He came to a kitten.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Are you my mother? he said to the kitten.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: The kitten just looked and looked.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: It did not say a thing.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: The kitten was not his mother, so he went on.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Then he came to a hen.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Are you my mother? he said to the hen.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: No, said the hen.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: The kitten was not his mother.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: The hen was not his mother.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: So the baby bird went on.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: I have to find my mother! he said.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: But where? Where is she? Where could she be?

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Then he came to a dog.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Are you my mother? he said to the dog.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: I am not your mother.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: I am a dog, said the dog.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: The kitten was not his mother.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: The hen was not his mother.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: The dog was not his mother.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: So the baby bird went on.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Now he came to a cow.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Are you my mother? he said to the cow.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: How could I be your mother? said the cow.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: I am a cow.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: The kitten and the hen were not his mother.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: The dog and the cow were not his mother.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Did he have a mother?

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: I did have a mother, said the baby bird.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: I know I did.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: I have to find her.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: I will.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: I WILL!

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Now the baby bird did not walk.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: He ran!

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Then he saw a car.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Could that old thing be his mother?

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: No, it could not.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: The baby bird did not stop.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: He ran on and on.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Now he looked way, way down.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: He saw a boat.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: There she is! said the baby bird.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: He called to the boat, but the boat did not stop.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: The boat went on.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: He looked way, way up.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: He saw a big plane.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Here I am, Mother, he called out.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: But the plane did not stop.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: The plane went on.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Just then, the baby bird saw a big thing.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: This must be his mother!

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: There she is! he said.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: There is my mother!

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: He ran right up to it.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Mother, Mother! Here I am, Mother! he said to the big thing.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: But the big thing just said, Snort.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Oh, you are not my mother, said the baby bird. You are a Snort.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: I have to get out of here!

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: But the baby bird could not get away.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: The Snort went up.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: It went way, way up.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: And up, up, up went the baby bird.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: But now, where was the Snort going?

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Oh, oh, oh!

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: What is this Snort going to do to me?

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Get me out of here!

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Just then, the Snort came to a stop.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Where am I? said the baby bird.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: I want to go home!

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: I want a mother!

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Then something happened.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: The Snort put that baby bird right back in the tree.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: The baby bird was home!

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Just then the mother bird came back to the tree.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Do you know who I am? she said to her baby.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: Yes, I know who you are, said the baby bird.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: You are not a kitten.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: You are not a hen.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: You are not a dog.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: You are not a cow.

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: You are not a boat, or a plane, or a Snort!

title: ARE YOU MY MOTHER?
author: P.D. EASTMAN
text: You are a bird, and you are my mother.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: The day she was born was the happiest day in her parents' lives.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: She's perfect, said her mother.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Absolutely, said her father.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: And she was.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: She was absolutely perfect.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Her name must be everything she is, said her mother.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Her name must be absolutely perfect, said her father.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: And it was.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Chrysanthemum.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Her parents named her Chrysanthemum.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Chrysanthemum grew and grew and grew.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: And when she was old enough to appreciate it, Chrysanthemum loved her name.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: She loved the way it sounded when her mother woke her up.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: She loved the way it sounded when her father called her for dinner.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: And she loved the way it sounded when she whispered it to herself in the bathroom mirror.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Chrysanthemum, Chrysanthemum, Chrysanthemum.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Chrysanthemum loved the way her name looked when it was written with ink on an envelope.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: She loved the way it looked when it was written with icing on her birthday cake.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: And she loved the way it looked when she wrote it herself with her fat orange crayon.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Chrysanthemum, Chrysanthemum, Chrysanthemum.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Chrysanthemum thought her name was absolutely perfect.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: And then she started school.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: On the first day, Chrysanthemum wore her sunniest dress and her brightest smile.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: She ran all the way.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Hooray!  said Chrysanthemum.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: School!

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: But when Mrs. Chud took roll call, everyone giggled upon hearing Chrysanthemum's name.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: It's so long, said Jo.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: It scarcely fits on your name tag, said Rita, pointing.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: I'm named after my grandmother, said Victoria.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: You're named after a flower!

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Chrysanthemum wilted.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: She did not think her name was absolutely perfect.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: She thought it was absolutely dreadful.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: The rest of the day was not much better.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: During naptime Victoria raised her hand and informed Mrs. Chud that Chrysanthemum's name was spelled with thirteen letters.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: That's exactly half as many letters as there are in the entire alphabet! Victoria explained.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Thank you for sharing that with us, Victoria, said Mrs. Chud.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Now put your head down.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: If I had a name like yours, I'd change it, Victoria said as the students lined up to go home.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: I wish I could, thought Chrysanthemum miserably.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Welcome home! said her mother.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Welcome home! said her father.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: School is no place for me, said Chrysanthemum.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: My name is too long.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: It scarcely fits on my name tag.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: And I'm named after a flower!

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Oh pish, said her mother.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Your name is beautiful.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: And her precious and priceless and fascinating and winsome, said her father.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: It's everything you are, said her mother.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Absolutely perfect, said her father.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Chrysanthemum felt much better after her favorite dinner (macaroni and cheese with ketchup) and an evening filled with hugs and kisses and Parcheesi.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: That night Chrysanthemum dreamed that her name was Jane.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: It was an extremely pleasant dream.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: The next morning Chrysanthemum wore her most comfortable jumper.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: She walked to school as slowly as she could.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: She dragged her feet in the dirt.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Chrysanthemum, Chrysanthemum, Chrysanthemum, she wrote.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: She even looks like a flower, said Victoria, as Chrysanthemum entered the playground.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Let's pick her, said Rita, pointing.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Let's smell her, said Jo.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Chrysanthemum wilted.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: She did not think her name was absolutely perfect.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: She thought it was absolutely dreadful.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: The rest of the day was not much better.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: During naptime Victoria raised her hand and said, A chrysanthemum is a flower.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: It lives in a garden with worms and other dirty things.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Thank you for sharing that with us, Victoria, said Mrs. Chud.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Now put your head down.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: I just cannot believe your name, Victoria said as the students lined up to go home.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Neither can I, thought Chrysanthemum miserably.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: 'Welcome home! said her mother.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: 'Welcome home! said her father.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: School is no place for me, said Chrysanthemum.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: They said I even looked like a flower.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: They pretended to pick me and smell me.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Oh, pish, said her mother.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: They're just jealous.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: And envious and begrudging and discontented and jaundiced, said her father.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: 'Who wouldn't be jealous of a name like yours? said her mother.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: After all, it's absolutely perfect, said her father.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Chrysanthemum felt a trifle better after her favorite dessert (chocolate cake with buttercream frosting) and another evening filled with hugs and kisses and Parcheesi.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: That night Chrysanthemum dreamed that she really was a chrysanthemum.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: She sprouted leaves and petals.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Victoria picked her and plucked the leaves and petals one by one until there was nothing left but a scrawny stem.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: It was the worst nightmare of Chrysanthemum's life.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Chrysanthemum wore her outfit with seven pockets the next morning.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: She loaded the pockets with her most prized possessions and her good-luck charms.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Chrysanthemum took the longest route possible to school.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: She stopped and stared at each and every flower.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Chrysanthemum, Chrysanthemum, Chrysanthemum, the flowers seemed to say.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: That morning the students were introduced to Mrs. Twinkle, the music teacher.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Her voice was like something out of a dream, as was everything else about her.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: The students were speechless.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: They thought Mrs. Twinkle was an indescribable wonder.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: They went out of their way to make a nice impression.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Mrs. Twinkle led the students in scales.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Then she assigned roles for the class musicale.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Victoria was chosen as the dainty Fairy Queen.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Rita was chosen as the spiffy Butterfly Princess.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Jo was chosen as the all-important Pixie-messenger.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: And Chrysanthemum was chosen as a daisy.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Chrysanthemum's a daisy! Chrysanthemum's a daisy! Jo, Rita, and Victoria chanted, thinking it was wildly funny.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Chrysanthemum wilted.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: She did not think her name was absolutely perfect.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: She thought it was absolutely dreadful.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: What's so humorous? asked Mrs. Twinkle.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Chrysanthemum! was the answer.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Her name is so long, said Jo.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: It scarcely fits on her name tag, said Rita, pointing.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: I'm named after my grandmother, said Victoria.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: She's named after a flower!

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: My name is long, said Mrs. Twinkle.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: It is? said Jo.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: My name would scarcely fit on a name tag, said Mrs. Twinkle.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: lt would? said Rita, pointing.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: And- said Mrs. Twinkle, l'm named after a flower, too!

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: You are? said Victoria.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Yes, said Mrs. Twinkle.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: My name is Delphinium.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Delphinium Twinkle.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: And if my baby is a girl, I'm considering Chrysanthemum as a name.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: I think it is absolutely perfect.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Chrysanthemum could scarcely believe her ears.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: She blushed.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: She beamed.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: She bloomed.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Chrysanthemum, Chrysanthemum, Chrysanthemum.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Jo, Rita, and Victoria looked at Chrysanthemum longingly.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Call me Marigold, said Jo.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: I'm Carnation, said Rita, pointing.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: My name is Lily of the Valley, said Victoria.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Chrysanthemum did not think her name was absolutely perfect.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: She knew it!

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: EPILOGUE:

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Overall, the class musical was a huge success.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Chrysanthemum was absolutely perfect as a daisy.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Victoria made the only mistake: She completely forgot her lines as the dainty Fuity Queen.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Chrysanthemum thought it was wildly funny, and she giggled throughout the entire Dance of the Flowers.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: Eventually, Mrs. Twinkle gave birth to a healthy baby girl.

title: CHRYSANTHEMUM
author: KEVIN HENKES
text: And, of course, she named her Chrysanthemum.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Hey, kid!

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Did you know that dragons love tacos?

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: They love beef tacos and chicken tacos.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: They love really big gigantic tacos and tiny little baby tacos as well.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Why do dragons loves tacos?

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Maybe it's the smell from the sizzling pan.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Maybe it's the crunch of the crispy tortillas.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Maybe it's a secret.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Either way, if you want to make friends with dragons, tacos are key.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Hey dragon, why do you guys love tacos so much?

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: But wait!

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: As much as dragons love tacos, they hate spicy salsa even more.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: They hate spicy green salsa and spicy red salsa.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: They hate spicy chunky salsa and spicy smooth salsa.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: If the salsa is spicy at all, dragons can't stand it.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Why do dragons hate spicy salsa?

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Well, just one drop of hot sauce makes a dragon's ears smoke.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Just one single speck of hot pepper makes a dragon snort spark.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Spicy salsa gives dragons the tummy troubles, and when dragons get the tummy troubles – oh boy. . .

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: If you want to make tacos for dragons, keep the toppings mild.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Tomatoes, lettuce, cheese, these are all good toppings for tacos for dragons.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Hey dragon, how do you feel about spicy taco toppings?

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Dragons love parties.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: They like costume parties and pool parties.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: They like big gigantic parties with accordions and tiny little parties with charades.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Why do dragons love parties?

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Maybe it's the conversation.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Maybe it's the dancing.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Maybe it's the comforting sound of a good friend's laughter.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: The only thing dragons love more than parties or tacos, is taco parties (taco parties are parties with lots of tacos).

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: If you want to have some dragons over for a taco party, you'll need buckets of tacos.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Pantloads of tacos.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: The best way to judge is to get a boat and fill the boat with tacos.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: That's about how many tacos dragons need for a taco party.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: After all, dragons love tacos.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Hey dragon, are you excited for the big taco party?

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Just remember: Dragons hate spicy salsa.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Before you host your taco party with dragons, get rid of all the spicy salsa.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: In fact, bury the spicy salsa in the backyard so the dragons can't find it.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: These dragons love your taco party!

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: They love the music.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: They love the decorations.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: They especially love the tacos.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Congratulations!

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: It's a good thing you got rid of all that spicy. . .

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Wait a second – what are those little green things in the salsa?

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: You didn't read the fine print?!

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Dragons, listen to me: Do not eat those tacos.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Those little green specs in the salsa?

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Those are jalapeno peppers-they are super-spicy!

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: I know you love tacos, dragons, but you are not gonna love those tacos.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: DO NOT LET THOSE DRAGONS EAT THOSE TACOS!!!

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Crunch, crunch, crunch. . .

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Too late. . .

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Why would dragons help you rebuild your house?

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Maybe they're good Samaritans.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Maybe they feel bad for wrecking it.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: Maybe they're just in it for the taco breaks.

title: DRAGONS LOVE TACOS
author: ADAM RUBIN
text: After all, dragons love tacos.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Horn went Beep!

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Engine purred.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Friendliest sounds you ever heard.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Little Blue Truck rolled into the city.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Beep!

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Beep!

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Beep!

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Isn't it pretty?

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Towering buildings scraped the sky.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Beep! said Blue.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: The city is high!

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: ZOOOM! roared trucks down the avenue.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: The city is fast! said Little Blue.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Shove on, Shorty! yelled a double-decker bus with big red letters: RIDES-R-US.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: A grocery truck gave his horn a blast.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: MOVE IT, BUD-I'M FIRST, YOU'RE LAST!

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Wooeeee. . .  went a siren.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Coming through!

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Busy police car, things to do!

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Swish! Swash! Swoosh! went a big street sweeper, hollering, HEY!

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: BETTER MOVE, LITTLE BEEPER!

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: MAKE WAY! yelled a limousine (the longest car you've ever seen).

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: I've got His Honor the mayor inside.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: I'm important!

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Move aside!

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Cars and trucks were all in a tangle.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Everyone started to shout and wrangle.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Up roared a taxi.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Screech, went the brakes.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: STOP! yelled Blue.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: For goodness' sakes!

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: You might be fast and I might be slow, but one at a time is the way to go.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Me first! said the limo, all puffed with pride.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Then he gave a cough and his engine died.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: He was stuck right there with the mayor inside.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Beep! said Blue.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Would you like a ride?

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Everybody watching gave a shout when the door swung open and the mayor stepped out.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: His Honor climbed right up on Blue and gave a speech (the way mayors do).

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: My friends, he said, what wonderful luck–this good advice from a little blue truck!

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: One at a time is what we'll do, so single file, folks-FOLLOW BLUE!

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: Trucks and buses got in line with vans and taxis, and it all went fine.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: A taxi let a van go past.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: The double-decker bus said, I'll go last.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: A marching band joined the big parade.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: BOOM! went the drums, and the trumpets played.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: They rolled along the avenue and everyone waved to Little Blue.

title: LITTLE BLUE TRUCK LEADS THE WAY
author: ALICE SCHERTLE
text: They clapped their hands and yelled, HOORAY! for the little blue truck who led the way.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOUSE A COOKIE
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: If you give a mouse a cookie, he's going to ask for a glass of milk.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOUSE A COOKIE
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: When you give him the milk, he'll probably ask you for a straw.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOUSE A COOKIE
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: When he's finished, he'll ask for a napkin.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOUSE A COOKIE
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: Then he'll want to look in a mirror to make sure he doesn't have a milk mustache.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOUSE A COOKIE
