text: So I walked down the street to ask my neighbor for a cup of sugar.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: Now this neighbor was a pig.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: And he wasn't too bright either.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: He had built his whole house out of straw.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: Can you believe it?

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: I mean who in his right mind would build a house of straw?

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: So of course the minute I knocked on the door, it fell right in.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: I didn't want to just walk into someone else's house.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: So I called, Little Pig, Little Pig, are you in?

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: No answer.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: I was just about to go home without the cup of sugar for my dear old granny's birthday cake.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: That's when my nose started to itch.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: I felt a sneeze coming on.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: Well I huffed.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: And I snuffed.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: And I sneezed a great sneeze.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: And you know what?

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: That whore darn straw house fell down.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: And right in the middle of the pile of straw was the First Little Pig-dead as a doornail.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: He had been home the whole time.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: It seemed like a shame to leave a perfectly good ham dinner lying there in the straw.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: So I ate it up.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: Think of it as a big cheeseburger just lying there.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: I was feeling a little better.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: But I still didn't have my cup of sugar.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: So I went to the next neighbor's house.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: This neighbor was the First Little pig's brother.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: He was a little smarter, but not much.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: He had built his house of sticks.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: I rang the bell on the stick house.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: Nobody answered.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: I called, Mr. Pig, Mr. Pig, are you in?

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: He yelled back, Go away wolf.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: You can't come in.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: I'm shaving the hairs on my chinny chin chin.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: I had just grabbed the doorknob when I felt another sneeze coming on.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: I huffed.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: And I snuffed.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: And I tried to cover my mouth, but I sneezed a great sneeze.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: And you're not going to believe it, but this guy's house fell down just like his brother's.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: When the dust cleared, there was the Second Little Pig-dead as a doornail.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: Wolf's honor.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: Now you know food will spoil if you just leave it out in the open.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: So I did the only thing there was to do.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: I had dinner again.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: Think of it as a second helping.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: I was getting awfully full.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: But my cold was feeling a little better.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: And I still didn't have that cup of sugar for my dear old granny's birthday cake.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: So I went to the next house.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: This guy was the First and Second Little Pigs' brother.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: He must have been the brains of the family.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: He had built his house of bricks.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: I knocked on the brick house.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: No answer.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: I called, Mr. Pig, Mr. Pig, are you in?

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: And do you know what that rude little porker answered?

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: Get out of here, Wolf.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: Don't bother me again.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: Talk about impolite!

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: He probably had a whole sackful of sugar.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: And he wouldn't give me even one little cup for my dear sweet old granny's birthday cake.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: What a pig!

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: I was just about to go home and maybe make a nice birthday card instead of a cake, when I felt my cold coming on.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: I huffed.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: And I snuffed.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: And I sneezed once again.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: Then the Third little pig yelled, And your old granny can sit on a pin!

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: Now I'm usually a pretty calm fellow.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: But when somebody talks about my granny like that, I go a little crazy.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: When the cops drove up, of course I was trying to break down this Pig's door.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: And the whole time I was huffing and puffing and sneezing and making a real scene.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: The rest, as they say, is history.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: The news reporters found out about the two pigs I had for dinner.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: They figured a sick guy going to borrow a cup of sugar didn't sound very exciting.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: So they jazzed up the story with all of that Huff and puff and blow your house down.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: And they made me the Big Bad Wolf.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: That's it.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: The real story.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: I was framed.

title: THE TRUE STORY OF THE 3 LITTLE PIGS!
author: JON SCIESZKA
text: But maybe you could loan me a cup of sugar.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Mr. Gilly is a trashman.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: In the morning, Mr. Gilly puts on his heavy gloves.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: He climbs into his big trash truck.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: He turns the key.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: He drives his empty truck down the street.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: He is looking for trash.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: STOP!

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: There are trash cans by the school.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Mr. Gilly empties the cans into the truck.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Dump it in, smash it down, drive around the Trashy Town!

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Is the trash truck full yet?

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: No.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Mr. Gilly drives on.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: STOP!

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: There are trash cans in the park.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Mr. Gilly empties the cans into the truck.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Dump it in, smash it down, drive around the Trashy Town!

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Is the trash truck full yet?

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: No.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Mr. Gilly drives on.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: STOP!

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: There are trash cans behind the pizza parlor.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Mr. Gilly empties the cans into the truck.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Dump it in, smash it down, drive around the Trashy Town!

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Is the trash truck full yet?

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: No.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Mr. Gilly drives on.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: STOP!

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: There are trash cans next to the doctor's office.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Mr. Gilly empties the cans into the truck.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Dump it in, smash it down, drive around the Trashy Town!

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Is the trash truck full yet?

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: No.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Mr. Gilly drives on.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: STOP!

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: There are trash cans by the fire station.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Mr. Gilly empties the cans into the truck.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Dump it in, smash it down, drive around the Trashy Town!

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Is the trash truck full yet?

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: No.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Mr. Gilly drives down all the streets in Trashy Town.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: He empties all the trash cans into the truck.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Dump it in, smash it down, drive around the Trashy Town!

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Is the trash truck full yet?

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: YES!

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Mr. Gilly has cleaned up the whole town!

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Mr. Gilly drives the full trash truck to the dump.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Up, up, up goes the truck.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Down, down, down goes the trash.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: I dumped it in.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: I smashed it down.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: I love to clean up Trashy Town!

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Mr. Gilly turns off the key.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: He takes off his gloves.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Then he goes home.

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Now there's only one more thing to clean up. . .

title: TRASHY TOWN
author: ANDREA ZIMMERMAN AND DAVID CLEMESHA
text: Time for a bath, Mr. Gilly!

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: One day in class, Duncan went to take out his crayons and found a stack of letters with his name on them.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Hey Duncan,

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: It's me, RED Crayon.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: WE NEED to talk.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: You make me work harder than any of your other crayons.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: All year long I wear myself out coloring FIRE ENGINES, Apples, strawberries and EVERYTHING ELSE that's RED.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: I even work on Holidays!

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: I have to color all the santas at christmas and all the hearts on Valentine's day!

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: I NEED A REST!

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Your overworked friend,

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: RED Crayon.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Dear Duncan,

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: All right, LISTEN.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: I love that I'm your favorite crayon for grapes, dragons, and wizard's hats, but it makes me crazy that so much of my gorgeous color goes outside the lines.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: If you DON'T START COLORING INSIDE the lines soon . . .

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: I'm going to COMPLETELY LOSE IT

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Your very neat friend,

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Purple Crayon

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Dear Duncan,

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: I'm tired of being called light brown or Dark tan because I am neither.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: I am BEIGE and I am proud.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: I'm also tired of being second place to Mr. Brown Crayon.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: It's not fair that Brown gets all the bears, ponies and puppies while the only things I get are turkey dinners (if I'm lucky) and wheat, and let's be honest–when was the last time you saw a kid excited about coloring wheat?

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Your BEIGE friend,

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Beige Crayon

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Duncan, GRAY Crayon here.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: You're KILLING ME!

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: I know you love Elephants And I know that elephants are gray. . .  but that's a LOT of space to color in all by myself.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: And don't even get me started on your rhinos, hippos and HUMPBACK WHALES. . .  you know how tired I am after handling one of those big things?

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Such BIG animals. . .

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Baby penguins are gray, you know.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: So are very tiny rocks.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Pebbles.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: How about one of those once in a while to give me a break?

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Your very tired friend,

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Gray Crayon

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Dear Duncan,

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: You color with me, but why?

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Most of the time I'm the same color as the page you are using me on–WHITE.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: If I didn't have a black outline, you wouldn't even know I was THERE!

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: I'm not even in the rainbow.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: I'm only used to color SNOW or to fill in empty space between other things.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: And it leaves me feeling. . .  well. . .  empty.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: We need to talk.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Your empty friend,

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: White Crayon

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Hi, Duncan,

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: I HATE being used to draw the outline of things. . .

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: . . .  things that are colored in by other colors, all of which think they're brighter than me!

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: It's NOT FAIR when you use me to draw a nice beach ball and then fill in the colors of the ball with ALL THE OTHER CRAYONS.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: How about a BLACK Beach ball sometime?

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Is that too much to ask?

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Your Friend,

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Black Crayon

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Dear Duncan,

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: As Green Crayon, I am writing for two reasons.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: One is to say that I like my workloads of crocodiles, trees, dinosaurs, and frogs.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: I have no problem and wish to congratulate you on a very successful coloring things Green career so far.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: The second reason I write is for my friends, Yellow Crayon and Orange Crayon, who are no longer speaking to each other.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Both crayons feel THEY should be the color of the sun.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Please settle this soon because they're driving the rest of us CRAZY!

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Your happy friend,

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Green Crayon

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Dear Duncan,

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Yellow Crayon here.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: I need you to tell orange crayon that I am the color of the sun.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: I would tell him but we are no longer speaking.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: And I can PROVE I'm the color of the sun too!

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Last Tuesday, you used me to color in the sun on your HAPPY FARM coloring book.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: In case you've forgotten, it's on page 7.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: You CAN'T MISS me.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: I'm shining down brilliantly on a field of YELLOW corn!

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Your pal (and the true color of the sun),

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Orange Crayon

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Dear Duncan,

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: I see Yellow Crayon already talked to you, the BIG WHINER.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Anyway, could you please tell Mr. Tattletale that he IS NOT the color of the sun?

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: I would, but we are no longer speaking.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: We both know that I am clearly the color of the SUN because, on Thursday, you used me to color the sun on BOTH the Monkey Island and the Meet the Zookeeper pages in your DAY AT THE ZOO coloring book.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Orange you glad I'm here?

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Ha!

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Your pal (and the real color of the sun),

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Orange Crayon

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Dear DUNCAN,

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: It has been great being your FAVORITE color this PAST Year.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: And the Year before THAT!

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: I have really enjoyed all those OCEANS, LAKES, Rivers, raindrops, rain CLOUDS and CLEAR skies.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: But the BAD NEWS is that I am so short and stubby, I can't even see over the railing in the CRAYON BOX anymore!

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: I need a BREAK!

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Your very stubby friend.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Blue Crayon

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Duncan, Okay, LISTEN HERE, KID!

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: You have not used me ONCE in the past year.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: It's because you think I am a GIRLS' color, isn't it?

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Speaking of which, please tell your little sister I said thank you for using me to color in her little princess coloring book.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: I think she did a fabulous job of staying inside the lines!

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Now, back to us.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Could you PLEASE use me sometime to color the occasional PINK dinosaur or MONSTER or cowboy?

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Goodness knows they could use a splash of color.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Your unused friend,

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Pink Crayon

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Hey Duncan,

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: It's me, PEACH CRAYON.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: WHY did you peel off my paper wrapping??

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Now I'm NAKED and too embarrassed to leave the crayon box.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: I don't even have any underwear!

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: How would You like to go to school naked?

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: I need some clothes.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: HELP!

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Your naked friend,

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: PEACH Crayon

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Well, poor Duncan just wanted to color . . .

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: And of course he wanted his crayons to be happy.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: And that gave him an idea.

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: Then Duncan showed his teacher his new picture, she gave him an A for coloring. . .

title: THE DAY THE CRAYONS QUIT
author: DREW DAYWALT
text: And an A+ for creativity!

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Arthur's teacher, Mr. Rathburn, explained the homework.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: What should the story be about? Arthur asked.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Anything, Mr. Rathburn said.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Write about something that is important to you.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Arthur started his story the minute he got home.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: He knew exactly what he wanted to write about.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: How I got my Puppy Pal.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: I always wanted a dog, but first I had to prove I was responsible.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: So I started Arthur's Pet Business.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: My mom made me keep all the animals in the basement.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: It was a lot of work, but it was fun until I thought I lost perky.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: But then I found her, and she had three puppies!

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: And I got to keep one of them.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: That's how I got my dog Pal

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: The End

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Arthur read his story to DW.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: That's a boring story, D.W. said.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Does it have to be real life?

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Because your life is so dull.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: I don't want to write a boring story, Said Arthur.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: If it were me, D.W. suggested, I'd make the story about getting an elephant.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: The next day, Arthur read his new story to Buster.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Did you like the part about the elephant puppies? he asked.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: It's okay, I guess, said Buster.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: I'm writing a cool story about outer space.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Maybe my story should take place on the moon thought Arthur.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: On Wednesday, Arthur read his newest story to the Brain.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Scientifically speaking, elephants would weigh less on the moon, but wouldn't float that high, Said the brain

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: So you don't like it? asked Arthur.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: A good story should be well researched, Said the Brain.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Like mine: ‘If I Had a Pet Stegosaurus in the Jurassic Period.'

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Arthur hurried to the library.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: What are all those books for? asked Francine.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Research, said Arthur.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: I'm writing about my pet five-toed mammal of the genus Loxodonta.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Your what? asked Francine.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: My elephant! Arthur explained.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Oh, said Francine.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: I'm putting jokes in my story.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: All through dinner, Arthur worried about his story.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Please pass the corn, asked Father.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Corn!

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: That's it! said Arthur.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Purple corn and blue elephants!

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: On Planet Shmellafint!

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Now that's funny.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Arthur is acting weirder than usual, said D.W.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: On Thursday, everyone at the Sugar Bowl was talking about their stories.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Last year, a kid wrote a country-western song for her story, Said Prunella.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: And she got an A+

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: How do you know? asked Arthur.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: That kid was me, explained Prunella.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Mr. Ratburn said I should send it to a record company.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: It was that good.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Wow! said Arthur.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: That night, Arthur's imagination went wild.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: He decided to turn his story into a song.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: He even made up a dance to go with it.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Later, he tried it out on his family.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: . . . Now this little boy can go home and enjoy his own personal striped elephant.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: And you will see How happy he will be here on Planet. . .  Shmellafint!

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Well, said Arthur. What do you think?

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Mother and Father smiled.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: It's nice, said Grandma Thora.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: But a little confusing.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Too bad you can't dance, said D.W.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: What am I going to do? said Arthur.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: My story is due tomorrow.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: That night Arthur didn't sleep very well.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: The next day, Arthur worried until Mr. Ratburn finally called on him.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: When Arthur's song and dance was over, the classroom was so quiet it was almost spooky.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Blinky raised his hand.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Did that really happen?

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Sort of, said Arthur.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: It started as the story of how I got my dog.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: I'd like to hear that story, said Mr. Ratburn.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: The title was ‘How I Got My Puppy Pal, said Arthur.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Arthur told how proud he was of his pet business and how scared he was when Perky disappeared.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: And he told how happy he was to find her under his bed and how surprised he was to see her three puppies.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: And the best part is, said Arthur, I got to keep one!

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Buster said, I like that story better than your other one.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Great story! said Blinky.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: I think Arthur's story was the best! said Francine.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Good work, said Mr. Ratburn.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Of course, I expect you to write it all down by Monday.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Then Mr. Ratburn gave Arthur a gold sticker.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Oh, and one more thing, he said.

title: ARTHUR WRITES A STORY
author: MARC BROWN
text: Leave out the dancing!

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: Max, said Max's sister, Ruby.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: It's time for Grandma's birthday party!

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: Max wound up his Jellyball Shooter Spider.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: The spider shot red, blue, and yellow jellyballs.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: I sent out 10 party invitations, Max, said Ruby.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: All the guests wrote back and checked the Yes box.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: Will you help me put out the name cards?

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: 1 is Rapunzel.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: 2 is Curly Shirley Shirley.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: 3 is the Tooth Fairy.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: 4 and 5 are Mr. and Mrs. Quack.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: 6 is Pinocchio, and 7 is walky-talky Teddy Bear.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: Then there's me, you, and Grandma.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: But Max did not like any of Ruby's guests.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: He wanted to put his Jellyball Shooter Spider, his Ear-splitter Space Cadet, and his Can't-Sit-Up Slug in the chairs next to Grandma's place.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: No, Max, said Ruby.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: Grandma hates spiders and slugs and space cadets.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: Grandma wants to sit between Rapunzel and the Tooth Fairy.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: Max pushed the red button on the Space Cadet's Ear-Splitter Space Siren.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: Ruby put all the guests in their chairs.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 stuffed guests, Max, said Ruby.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: Ruby went to get snappers and candy kisses.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: Max took the crown and wig off Rapunzel and put them on his spider.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: Then Max put Rapunzel in his own seat and the Jellyball shooter in Rapunzel's seat.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: Ruby filled the favor baskets with Kisses.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: She did not notice the spider.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: That's funny, Mam, said Ruby.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: All the guests are in their seats.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: But there are only two chairs left for Grandma, you, and me.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: I must have counted wrong, Max! said Ruby.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: Ruby did not know where the extra guest had come from.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: I will have to set another place, Max, said Ruby.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: Max fetched his Can't-Sit-Up Slug.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: He put the Tooth Fairy's magic wand and wings on the Slug.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: Then he sat the Slug in the Tooth Fairy's seat and moved the Tooth Fairy to another seat.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: Ruby came back with a new place setting.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: She did not notice the slug.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: Something's wrong, Max, said Ruby.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: Somewhere there are 2 extra guests.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: It must be a bad counting day.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: We need another chair!

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: Max took his Ear-Splitter Space Cadet and dressed him in Mrs. Quack's sun hat and veil.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: Then he put the Space Cadet into Grandma's seat.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: How many people at this table, Max? said Ruby.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: 9, 3, 2, said Max.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: There are 10 guests now! said Ruby.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: Suddenly Grandma knocked at the door.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: Max introduced Grandma to the Jellyball Shooter Spider and the Ear-Splitter Space Cadet.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: The Can't-Sit-Up Slug slumped in its chair.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: I have just discovered 3 uninvited guests! said Ruby.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: How exciting! said Grandma.

title: BUNNY PARTY
author: ROSEMARY WELLS
text: Grandma made sure that the uninvited guests all had their snappers and their candy Kisses and their favorite flavors of ice cream

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: If you give a moose a muffin, he'll want some jam to go with it.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: So you'll bring out some of your mother's homemade blackberry jam.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: When he's finished eating the muffin, he'll want another.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: And another.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: And another.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: When they're all gone, he'll ask you to make more.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: You'll have to go to the store to get some muffin mix.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: He'll want to go with you.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: When he opens the door and feels how chilly it is, he'll ask to borrow a sweater.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: When he puts the sweater on, he'll notice one of the buttons is loose.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: He'll ask for a needle and thread.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: He'll start sewing.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: The button will remind him of the puppets his grandmother used to make.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: So he'll ask for some old socks.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: He'll make sock puppets.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: When they're done, he'll want to put on a puppet show.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: He'll need some cardboard and paints.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: Then he'll ask you to help make the scenery.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: When the scenery is finished, he'll get behind the couch.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: But his antlers will stick out.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: So he'll ask for something to cover them up.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: You'll bring him a sheet from your bed.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: When he sees the sheet, he'll remember he wants to be a ghost for Halloween.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: He'll try it on and shout, BOO!

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: It'll scare him so much; he'll knock over the paints.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: So he'll use the sheet to clean up the mess.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: Then he'll ask for some soap to wash it out.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: He'll probably want to hang the sheet up to dry.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: He'll go outside to put it on the clothesline.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: When he's out in the yard, he'll see your mother's blackberry bushes.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: Seeing the blackberries will remind him of her jam.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: He'll probably ask you for some.

title: IF YOU GIVE A MOOSE A MUFFIN
author: LAURA JOFFE NUMEROFF
text: And chances are. . .  if you give him the jam, he'll want a muffin to go with it.

title: THAT IS NOT A GOOD IDEA!
author: MO WILLEMS
text: What luck!

title: THAT IS NOT A GOOD IDEA!
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Dinner!

title: THAT IS NOT A GOOD IDEA!
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Excuse me.

title: THAT IS NOT A GOOD IDEA!
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Would you care to go for a stroll?

title: THAT IS NOT A GOOD IDEA!
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Hmm. . .  sure!

title: THAT IS NOT A GOOD IDEA!
author: MO WILLEMS
text: That is NOT a good idea!

title: THAT IS NOT A GOOD IDEA!
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Would you care to continue our walk into the deep, dark woods?

title: THAT IS NOT A GOOD IDEA!
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Sounds fun!

title: THAT IS NOT A GOOD IDEA!
author: MO WILLEMS
text: That is REALLY NOT a good idea!

title: THAT IS NOT A GOOD IDEA!
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Would you care to visit my nearby kitchen?

title: THAT IS NOT A GOOD IDEA!
author: MO WILLEMS
text: I would love to!

title: THAT IS NOT A GOOD IDEA!
author: MO WILLEMS
text: That is REALLY REALLY NOT a good idea!

title: THAT IS NOT A GOOD IDEA!
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Would you care to boil some water for soup?

title: THAT IS NOT A GOOD IDEA!
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Certainly, I do love soup!

title: THAT IS NOT A GOOD IDEA!
author: MO WILLEMS
text: That is REALLY REALLY REALLY NOT a good idea!

title: THAT IS NOT A GOOD IDEA!
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Would you care to look at my soup?

title: THAT IS NOT A GOOD IDEA!
author: MO WILLEMS
text: A key ingredient is missing.

title: THAT IS NOT A GOOD IDEA!
author: MO WILLEMS
text: That is REALLY REALLY REALLY REALLY NOT a good idea!

title: THAT IS NOT A GOOD IDEA!
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Oh- a key ingredient is missing.

title: THAT IS NOT A GOOD IDEA!
author: MO WILLEMS
text: YOU!

title: THAT IS NOT A GOOD IDEA!
author: MO WILLEMS
text: Well, we DID try to warn him.

title: THAT IS NOT A GOOD IDEA!
author: MO WILLEMS
text: More soup, children?

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: It was a happy time in the big tree house down a sunny dirt road in Bear Country- a happy birthday time.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: It was Brother Bear's birthday, and he was getting some very fine presents.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Brother wasn't exactly having a party, but Cousin Fred, Lizzy Bruin, and Babs Bruno were there.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: And, Gramps and Gran, of course.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Wow! said Brother when he opened his Present from Gramps.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: It was an aluminum bat.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Thanks, Gramps.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: I'll hit twenty home runs with this!

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Gran's Present was a great-looking warm-up jacket.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Brother tried it on and looked in the mirror.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Thank You, Gran.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: It's really neat, he said.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: His other presents were a fielder's glove from Cousin Fred, a sports video from Lizzy Bruin, and a mystery book from Babs Bruno.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Sister's very thoughtful gift was a package of balsa wood, the special wood Brother used for making model airplanes.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Thank you!

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Thank you!

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Thank you all! he said.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: You're welcome and happy birthday! said the gift givers.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Sister's gift was thoughtful.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: But she was being thoughtful in another way, too.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: It isn't always easy when your brother gets a lot of presents and you don't.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Sister understood that she had gotten presents when it was her birthday and would again.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Besides, she wasn't that interested in aluminum bats, warm-up jackets, fielder's gloves, sports videos, or balsa wood, anyway.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: But all that changed when Mama and Papa Bear gave Brother their present.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: It was the biggest, most beautiful racing bike Sister had ever seen.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: It had a hand brake, three speeds, and super-sport wheels.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: When Sister saw that beautiful bike, it was no longer, Happy birthday, Brother! It was, I gotta have that bike!

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: I gotta!

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: I gotta!

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: I gotta!

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Mama saw that I-gotta-have-it look in Sister's eyes.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: She took her aside and reminded her about all the wonderful presents she had gotten on her last birthday.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: But Sister didn't hear a word Mama said.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: She just stared at that big, beautiful bike with the hand brake and the super-sport wheels.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Oh, dear, said Mama.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: I think you've been taken over by the green-eyed monster.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Green-eyed monster? said Sister.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: What's that?

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Oh, said Mama.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: That's just a way folks have of talking about jealousy and envy.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: You know what it means to be jealous.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Envy is when you want something that belongs to somebody else.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: But, Mama, said Sister.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: It's such a great beautiful bike!

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Please listen to me, Sister, said Mama.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Even if you had a bike like that, you couldn't ride it.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: You're not big enough.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Your feet wouldn't reach the pedals.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Besides, look what Papa's got for you.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Papa was wheeling in Brother's junior-size bike with its training wheels attached.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: It's yours now, he said.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Sister looked at the bike Brother had outgrown.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: It was okay, but it didn't have a hand brake, three speeds, and super-sport wheels.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Come on now, said Mama.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Our guests are leaving.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: It's time to say good-bye.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Good-bye! said Brother.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Thank you all for the wonderful presents!

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Bye, said Sister.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Gramps and Gran got into their pickup truck and headed for home.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Lizzy Bruin got into her dad's car with the others.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Mr. Bruin had agreed to come for them and drive them home.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Then papa helped carry the new bike down the front steps.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Mama and papa watched proudly as Brother climbed on and tried it out.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: First Brother rode big, fast circles around the tree house.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Then he did a few wheelies.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: When he started riding with his feet up on the handlebars, Mama got worried.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Now let's not be reckless! she said.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Sister watched, too.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: She had gone inside and was watching from a window.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: As she did so she became filled with envy.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: From the tips of her pink hair bow down to the tips of her toenails, Sister really wanted that big, beautiful racing bike.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: That night Sister was having trouble falling asleep because she was still thinking about the bike.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Then just as her eyes were closing the strangest thing happened.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: She had a visitor.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: The visitor looked exactly like Sister, except she was green and had little horns on her head.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: I know who you are, Sister said.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: You're the green-eyed monster.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Sister was having a dream, of course.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: But she didn't know that.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: That's the thing about dreams.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: They're so real.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Come, said the green-eyed monster.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: If you want a bike like Brother's, all you have to do is prove you're big enough to ride it.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Before she quite knew what was happening, she was up on the bike and the green-eyed monster was giving her a big push.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: The bike was much too big for her.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Her feet couldn't even almost reach the pedals.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Then, as so often happens in dreams, things began to change.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: The bike got bigger and bigger and BIGGER!

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Now Sister was speeding down a hill.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: At the bottom was a great rock.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: She smashed into it.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: There was a huge crash!

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Brother's beautiful new birthday bike flew into a thousand pieces.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: What have I done? she screamed.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: What have I done?

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Mama and Papa, who had just fallen asleep, came running into the cubs' room.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Oh, Mama! cried Sister.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: I just smashed Brother's beautiful birthday bike into a thousand pieces!

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: A thousand pieces!

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Try to calm down, sweetie, said Mama.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Brother's bike is perfectly safe.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: You were having a dream.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: What's going on? said Brother, rubbing his eyes.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: I'll go downstairs and get us all some warm milk, said Papa.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: It'll help us get back to sleep.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: And it did.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: The next day Sister's best friend, Lizzy, came over to play.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: She and Sister had a fun time riding around the yard.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Brother's old bike turned out to be just right for Sister.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Lizzy had a good time on Sister's old trike.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: And Brother rode circles around them on his birthday bike.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Later, when Mr. Bruin came over to pick up Lizzy, he had a very big surprise for everybody.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: He had just traded in his old car for a beautiful brand-new one.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: And what a car it was!

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: It had wire wheels, leather seats, and racing stripes.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Mama, Brother, Sister, and Lizzy congratulated Mr. Bruin on his fine new car.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: But not Papa.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: He just stood and stared.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: He had the same I-gotta-have-it look that Sister had when she first saw Brother's new bike.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Papa, said Sister.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: I think you better watch out for ‘you know who'!

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Papa did know who.

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: Mr. Bruin, he said, congratulations on a fine new car!

title: THE BERENSTAIN BEARS AND THE GREEN-EYED MONSTER
author: STAN & JAN BERENSTAIN
text: After the Bruins drove away, Mama and Papa sat on the tree house steps and watched Brother and Sister do some plain and fancy bike riding.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: Elizabeth was a beautiful princess.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: She lived in a castle and had expensive princess clothes.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: She was going to marry a prince named Ronald.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: Unfortunately, a dragon smashed her castle, burned all her clothes with his fiery breath, and carried off Prince Ronald.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: Elizabeth decided to chase the dragon and get Ronald back.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: She looked everywhere for something to wear, but the only thing she could find that was not burnt was a paper bag.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: So she put on the paper bag and followed the dragon.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: He was easy to follow because he left a trail of burnt forests and horses' bones.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: Finally, Elizabeth came to a cave with a large door that had a huge knocker on it.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: She took hold of the knocker and banged on the door.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: The dragon stuck his nose out of the door and said, Well, a princess!

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: I love to eat princesses, but I have already eaten a whole castle today.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: I am a very busy dragon.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: Come back tomorrow.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: He slammed the door so fast that Elizabeth almost got her nose caught.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: Elizabeth grabbed the knocker and banged on the door again.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: The dragon stuck his nose out of the door and said, Go away.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: I love to eat princesses, but I have already eaten a whole castle today.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: I am a very busy dragon.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: Come back tomorrow.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: Wait, shouted Elizabeth.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: Is it true that you are the smartest and fiercest dragon in the whole world?

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: Yes, said the dragon.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: Fantastic, said Elizabeth, and the dragon took another huge breath and breathed out so much fire that he burnt up one hundred forests.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: Magnificent, said Elizabeth, and the dragon took another huge breath, but this time nothing came out.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: The dragon didn't even have enough fire left to cook a meatball.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: Elizabeth said, Dragon, is it true that you can fly around the world in just ten seconds?

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: Why, yes, said the dragon, and jumped up and flew all the way around the world in just ten seconds.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: He was very tired when he got back, but Elizabeth shouted, Fantastic, do it again!

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: So the dragon jumped up and flew around the whole world in just twenty seconds.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: When he got back he was too tired to talk, and he lay down and went straight to sleep.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: Elizabeth whispered, very softly, Hey, dragon.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: The dragon didn't move at all.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: She lifted up the dragon's ear and put her head right inside.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: She shouted as loud as she could, Hey, dragon!

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: The dragon was so tired he didn't even move.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: Elizabeth walked right over the dragon and opened the door to the cave.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: There was Prince Ronald.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: He looked at her and said, Elizabeth, you are a mess!

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: You smell like ashes, your hair is all tangled and you are wearing a dirty old paper bag.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: Come back when you are dressed like a real princess.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: Ronald, said Elizabeth, your clothes are really pretty and your hair is very neat.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: You look like a real prince, but you are a bum.

title: THE PAPER BAG PRINCESS
author: ROBERT N. MUNSCH
text: They didn't get married after all.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Once upon a time, a little girl named Laura lived in the Big Woods of Wisconsin in a little house made of logs.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Laura lived in the little house with her Pa, her Ma, her big sister Mary, her baby sister Carrie, and their good old bulldog Jack.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Winter was coming to the Big Woods.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Soon the little house would be covered with snow.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Pa went hunting every day so that they would have meat during the long, cold winter.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Ma, Laura, and Mary gathered potatoes and carrots, beets and turnips, cabbages and onions, and peppers and pumpkins from the garden next to the little house.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: By the time winter came, the little house was full of good things to eat.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Laura and Mary thought the attic was a lovely place to play.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: They played house by using the round orange pumpkins as tables and chairs, and everything was snug and cozy.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Soon the first snow came, and it was very cold.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: In the mornings the windows were covered with beautiful frost pictures of trees and flowers and fairies.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Ma said that Jack Frost came in the night and made the pictures while everyone was asleep.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Laura and Mary were allowed to use Ma's thimble to make pretty patterns of circles in the frost.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: In the mornings Laura and Mary helped Ma wash the dishes and make the beds.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: After this was done, Ma began the work that belonged to that day.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Each day had its own proper work.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Ma would say

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Wash on Monday, Iron on Tuesday, mend on Wednesday, churn on Thursday, clean on Friday, bake on Saturday, rest on Sunday.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Laura liked the churning and baking days best of all.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Ma had to churn the cream for a long time until it turned into butter.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Mary could sometimes churn while Ma rested, but Laura was too little.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: On Saturdays, when Ma made the bread, Laura and Mary each had a little piece of dough to make into a little loaf.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Ma even gave them a bit of cookie dough to make little cookies.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: After the day's work was done, Ma would sometimes cut out paper dolls for Laura and Mary.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: She drew their faces on with a pencil, and cut dresses, hats, and ribbons out of colored paper so that Mary and Laura could dress their dolls beautifully.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: But the best time of all was at night, when Pa came home.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: He would throw off his fur cap and coat and mittens and call, Where's my little half-pint of sweet cider half drunk up?

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: That was Laura, because she was so small.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Sometimes Pa would take down his fiddle and sing.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Pa would keep time with his foot.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Laura and Mary would clap their hands to the music when he sang:

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Yankee Doodle went to town, He wore his striped trousies, he swore he couldn't see the town, there was so many houses.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Other times Pa would tell stories.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: When Laura and Mary begged him for a story, he would take them on his knees and tickle their faces with his long whiskers until they laughed out loud.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: His eyes were blue and merry.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Outside it was cold and snowy, but the little log cabin was snug and cozy.

title: WINTER DAYS IN THE BIG WOODS
author: LAURA INGALLS WILDER
text: Pa, Ma, Laura, Mary, and Baby Carrie were comfortable and happy in their little house in the Big Woods.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Angelina absolutely loved snowy winter days when she could ice skate with her friends on Miller's Pond.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: The ice sparkled like glass and they raced across it in pairs, practicing spins and twirls and figure-eights.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Everyone in the village was getting ready for New Year's Eve, and Angelina was preparing a special ice skating show.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Her little cousin Henry wanted to be in the show, too, even though he often tumbled off the ice and fell into the snowbanks.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: We'll need someone to be the Snow King, said Angelina's friend Flora, pirouetting across the ice as the Snow Princess.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: I'll be the King! shouted Henry, but then he tripped and slid into Alice, who was going to be the Snow Fairy.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: You'd be a better snow shovel! said Alice crossly as she dusted off her skates.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Don't worry, Henry, said Angelina.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Hold on to me and let's practice skating together.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: They linked their tails and tried to skate in a circle, but it wasn't easy on the slippery ice.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Just then Spike and Sammy, two big boys from school, raced by playing hockey and almost knocked them all over.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: HEY! shouted Felicity, but the boys were already gone, laughing and yelling across the ice.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Never mind, said Angelina, helping Felicity get her balance.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Let me show you how to skate backwards.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: But, before long, Spike and Sammy tore past again, spraying snow in all directions.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: When they zipped through Angelina's rehearsal a third time, she got angry.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Please stop interrupting us! she scolded.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: But the boys just laughed, grabbed Angelina's scarf, and tweaked Flora's whiskers.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Little ballerinas can't catch us! they shouted as they zoomed away.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Angelina and her friends chased Spike and Sammy all across the ice, and then Angelina made a huge snowball and hurled it at the boys.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Great!

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: A snowball fight! Spike yelled, throwing one back at Angelina.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Then everybody started throwing snowballs everywhere, and soon Miller's Pond was a blizzard of flying snow and shouting skaters.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: They had so much fun, they stayed until Flora got ice down her neck and Alice's toes began to freeze.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Then they trudged back to Angelina's house, feeling tired and frozen.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: What's wrong? asked Angelina's mother.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Our New Year's Eve Ice Dance is a mess, said Angelina sadly.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: We haven't got costumes or scenery and Spike and Sammy keep bothering us.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: I can help you with costumes, said Mrs. Mouseling.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: And maybe the boys are teasing you because they want you to pay attention to them.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Angelina was surprised.
