title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: That gives me an idea.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: The next day Angelina put on her skates and whizzed past Spike and Sammy, snatched their caps, and raced off laughing with the boys just behind her.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: They were very fast, but Angelina could do all sorts of tricky twists and spins and, just as Spike and Sammy thought they would grab her, she spun out of reach and they smashed into each other, collapsing on the ice.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Spike gazed at Angelina in admiration.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: You ballerinas are fast!

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Would you like to be in our show? asked Angelina, tossing back their caps.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Spike and Sammy leapt up.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Yes! they shouted, skating in circles around her.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Sammy loved doing funny tricks and Spike, who could skate backwards, was proud to be the Snow King.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Best of all, they helped Henry build a huge snow fort.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: It will make a nice snow palace for our show, said Henry enthusiastically.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: What a great idea! admired Angelina.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: On New Year's Eve, the whole village dressed up and came to celebrate.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Miller's Pond looked magical as the performers skated on to the ice in Mrs. Mouseling's costumes, and Henry's snow fort gleamed in the moonlight.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: When Angelina danced into the spotlight that night, she felt just like a real snow queen.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: Spike and Sammy did exciting leaps and jumps together and Henry was thrilled to be the King's attendant, while Felicity, Flora, and Alice seemed to fly across the ice like delicate snowflakes.

title: ANGELINA ICE SKATES
author: KATHARINE HOLABIRD
text: At the end of the performance, as the magic hour of midnight approached and fireworks sparkled in the sky, Angelina and her friends wished everyone joy and peace, and they all sang and danced together to welcome in the New Year.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: On the fifteenth of May, in the Jungle of Nool, in the heat of the day, in the cool of the pool, He was splashing. . .  enjoying the jungle's great joys. . .  When Horton the elephant heard a small noise.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: So Horton stopped splashing.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: He looked toward the sound.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: That's funny, thought Horton.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: There's no one around.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Then he heard it again!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Just a very faint yelp as if some tiny person were calling for help.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I'll help you, said Horton.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: But who are you? Where? He looked and looked.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: He could see nothing there but a small speck of dust blowing past through the air.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I say! murmured Horton.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I've never heard tell of a small speck of dust that is able to yell.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: So you know what I think? . . .

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Why, I think that there must be someone on top of that small speck of dust!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Some sort of a creature of very small size, too small to be seen by an elephant's eyes. . .  some poor little person who's shaking with fear that he'll blow in the pool!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: He has no way to steer!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I'll just have to save him.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Because, after all, a person's a person, no matter how small.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: So, gently, and using the greatest of care, The elephant stretched his great trunk through the air, and he lifted the dust speck and carried it over and placed it down, safe, on a very soft clover.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Humpf! humpfed a voice.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: ‘Twas a sour kangaroo.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And the young kangaroo in her pouch said Humpf! too.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Why, that speck is as small as the head of a pin.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: A person on that?

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Why, there never has been!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Believe me, said Horton.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I tell you sincerely, my ears are quite keen and I heard him quite clearly.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I know there's a person down there.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And, what's more, quite likely there's two.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Even three.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Even four.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Quite likely. . .  a family, for all that we know!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: A family with children just starting to grow.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: So, please, Horton said, as a favor to me, try not to disturb them.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Just please let them be.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I think you're a fool! laughed the sour kangaroo and the young kangaroo in her pouch said, Me, too!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: You're the biggest blame fool in the Jungle of Nool!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And the kangaroos plunged in the cool of the pool.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: What terrible splashing! the elephant frowned.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I can't let my very small persons get drowned!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I've got to protect them.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I'm bigger than they.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: So he plucked up the clover and hustled away.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Through the high jungle tree tops, the news quickly spread:

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: He talks to a dust speck!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: He's out of his head!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Just look at him walk with that speck on that flower!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And Horton walked, worrying, almost an hour.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Should I put this speck down?. . .  Horton thought with alarm.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: If I do, these small persons may come to great harm.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I can't put it down.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And I won't!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: After all a person's a person.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: No matter how small.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Then Horton stopped walking.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: The speck-voice was talking!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: The voice was so faint he could just barely hear it.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Speak up, please, said Horton.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: He put his ear near it.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: My friend, came the voice, you're a very fine friend.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: You've helped all us folks on this dust speck no end.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: You've saved all our houses, our ceilings and floors.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: You've saved all our churches and grocery stores.''

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: You mean. . .  Horton gasped, you have buildings there, too?

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Oh, yes, piped the voice. We most certainly do.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I know, called the voice, I'm too small to be seen but I'm Mayor of a town that is friendly and clean.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Our buildings, to you, would seem terribly small but to us, who aren't big, they are wonderfully tall.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: My town is called Who-ville, for I am a who and we whos are all thankful and grateful to you.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And Horton called back to the Mayor of the town, You're safe now.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Don't worry.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I won't let you down.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: But, just as he spoke to the Mayor of the speck, three big jungle monkeys climbed up Horton's neck!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: The Wickersham brothers came shouting, What rot!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: This elephant's talking to Whos who are not!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: There aren't any Whos!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And they don't have a Mayor!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And we're going to stop all this nonsense!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: So there!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: They snatched Horton's clover!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: They carried it off to a black-bottomed eagle named Vlad Vlad-i-koff, A mighty strong eagle, of very swift wing, And they said, Will you kindly get rid of this thing?

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And, before the poor elephant even could speak, that eagle flew off with the flower in his beak.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: All that late afternoon and far into the night that black-bottomed bird flapped his wings in fast flight, while Horton chased after, with groans, over stones that tattered his toenails and battered his bones, and begged, please don't harm all my little folks, who have as much right to live as us bigger folks do!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: But far, far beyond him, that eagle kept flapping and over his shoulder called back, Quit your yapping.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I'll fly the night through.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I'm a bird.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I don't mind it.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And I'll hid this, tomorrow, where you'll never find it!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And at 6:56 the next morning he did it.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: It sure was a terrible place that he hid it.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: He let that small clover drop somewhere inside of a great patch of clovers a hundred miles wide!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Find that! sneered the bird.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: But I think you will fail.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And he left with a flip of his black-bottomed tail.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I'll find it! cried Horton.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I'll find it or bust!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I shall find my friends on my small speck of dust!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And clover, by clover, by clover he found that the one that he sought for was just not around.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And by noon poor old Horton, more dead than alive, had picked, searched, and piled up, nine thousand and five.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Then, on through the afternoon, hour after hour. . .

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Till he found them at last!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: On the three millionth flower!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: My friends! cried the elephant.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Tell me! Do tell!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Are you safe?

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Are you sound?

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Are you whole?

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Are you well?

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: From down on the speck came the voice of the Mayor:

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: We've really had trouble!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Much more than our share.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: When that black-bottomed birdie let go and we dropped, we landed so hard that our clocks have all stopped.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Our tea-pots are broken.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Our rocking-chairs smashed.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And our bicycle tires all blew up when we crashed.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: So, Horton, please! pleaded that voice of the Mayor's, Will you stick by us Whos while we're making repairs?

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Of course, Horton answered.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Of course I will stick.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I'll stick by you small folks through thin and through thick!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Humpf! humpfed a voice!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: For almost two days you've run wild and insisted on chatting with persons who've never existed.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Such carryings-on in our peaceable jungle!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: We've had quite enough of your bellowing bungle!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And I'm here to state, snapped the big kangaroo, That your silly nonsensical game is all through!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And the young kangaroo in her pouch said, Me, too!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: With the help of the wickersham brothers and dozens of wickersham uncles and wickersham cousins and wickersham in-laws, whose help I've engaged, you're going to be roped!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And you're going to be caged!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And, as for your dust speck. . .  hah!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: That we shall boil in a hot steaming kettle of beezle-nut oil!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Boil it?. . .  gasped Horton!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Oh, that you can't do!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: It's all full of persons!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: They'll prove it to you!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Mr. Mayor!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Mr. Mayor! Horton called.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Mr. Mayor! You've got to Prove now that you really are there!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: So call a big meeting.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Get everyone out'

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Make every who holler!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Make every Who shout!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Make every Who scream!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: If you don't, every Who is going to end up in a Beezle-Nut stew!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And, down on the dust speck, the scared little Mayor Quick called a big meeting in Who-ville Town square.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And his people cried loudly.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: They cried out in fear:

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: We are here!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: We are here!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: We are here!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: We are here!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: The elephant smiled:

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: That was clear as a bell.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: You kangaroos surely heard that very well.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: All I heard, snapped the big kangaroo, was the breeze, and the faint sound of wind through the far-distant trees.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I heard no small voices.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And you didn't either.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And the young kangaroo in her pouch said, Me, neither.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Grab him! they shouted.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And cage the big dope!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Lasso his stomach with ten miles of rope!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Tie the knots tight so he'll never shake loose!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Then dunk that dumb speck in the Beezle-Nut juice!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Horton fought back with great vigor and vim but the wickersham gang was too many for him.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: They beat him!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: They mauled him!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: They started to haul

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Him into his cage!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: But he managed to call To the Mayor:

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Don't give up!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: I believe in you all!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: A Person's a Person, no matter how small!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And you very small persons will not have to die if you make yourselves heard!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: So come on, now, and TRY!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: The Mayor grabbed a tom-tom.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: He started to smack it.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And, all over Who-ville, they whooped up a racket.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: They rattled tin kettles!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: They beat on brass pans, On garbage pail tops and old cranberry cans!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: They blew on bazookas and blasted great toots on clarinets, oom-pahs and boom-pahs and flutes!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Great gusts of loud racket rang high through the air.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: They rattled and shook the whole sky!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And the Mayor called up through the howling mad hullabaloo:

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Hey, Horton! How's this?

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Is our sound coming through?

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And Horton called back, I can hear you just find.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: But the kangaroos' ears aren't as strong, quite, as mine.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: They don't hear a thing!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Are you sure all your boys are doing their best?

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Are they ALL making noise?

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Are you sure every who down in Who-ville is working?

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Quick!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Look through your town!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Is there anyone shirking?

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Through the town rushed the Mayor, from the east to the west.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: But everyone seemed to be doing his best.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Everyone seemed to be yapping or yipping!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Everyone seemed to be beeping or bipping!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: But it wasn't enough, all this ruckus and roar!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: He HAD to find someone to help him make more.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: He raced through each building!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: He searched floor-to-floor!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And, just as he felt he was getting nowhere, and almost about to give up in despair, he suddenly burst through a door and that Mayor discovered one shirker!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Quite hidden away in the Fairfax apartments (Apartment 12-J) A very small, very small shirker named Jo-jo was standing, just standing, and bouncing a yo-yo!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Not making a sound!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Not a yipp!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Not a chirp!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And the mayor rushed inside and he grabbed the young twerp!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And he climbed with the lad up the Eiffelberg Tower.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: This, cried the Mayor, is your town's darkest hour!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: The time for all Whos who have blood that is red to come to the aid of their country! he said.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: We've GOT to make noises in greater amounts!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: So, open your mouth, lad!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: For every voice counts!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Thus he spoke as he climbed.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Whey they got to the top, the lad cleared his throat and he shouted, Yopp!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And that Yopp. . .

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: That one small, extra Yopp put it over!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Finally, at last!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: From that speck on that clover their voices were heard!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: They rang out clear and clean.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And the elephant smiled.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Do you see what I mean?. . .

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: They've proved they are persons, no matter how small.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And their whole world was saved by the smallest of all!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: How true!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: Yes, how true, said the big Kangaroo.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And, from now on, you know what I'm planning to do?. . .

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: From now on, I'm going to protect them with you!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: And the young kangaroo in her pouch said, ME, TOO!

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: From sun in the summer.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: From rain in when it's fall-ish, I'm going to protect them.

title: HORTON HEARS A WHO!
author: DR. SEUSS
text: No matter how small-ish!

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: It was breakfast time, and everyone was at the table.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Father was eating his egg.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Mother was eating her egg.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Gloria was sitting in a high chair and eating her egg too.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Frances was eating bread and jam.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: What a lovely egg! said Father.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: If there is one thing I am fond of for breakfast, it is a soft-boiled egg.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Yes, said Mother, spooning up egg for the baby. it is just the thing to start the day off right.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Ah! said Gloria, and ate up her egg.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Frances did not eat her egg.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: She sang a little song to it.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: She sand the song very softly:

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: I do not like the way you slide,

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: I do not like your soft inside,

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: I do not like you lots of ways,

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: And I could do for many days

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Without eggs.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: What did you say, Frances? Asked Father.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Nothing, said Frances, spreading jam on another slice of bread.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Why do you keep eating bread and jam, asked Father, when you have a lovely soft-boiled egg?

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: One of the reasons I like bread and jam, said Frances, is that it does not slide off your spoon in a funny way.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Well, of course, said Father.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: not everyone is fond of soft-boiled eggs for breakfast.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: But there are other kinds of eggs.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: There are sunny-side-up and sunny-side-down eggs.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Yes, said Frances.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: But sunny-side-up eggs lie on the plate and look up at you in a funny way.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: And sunny-side-down eggs just lie on their stomachs and wait.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: What about scrambled eggs? said Father.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Scrambled eggs fall off the fork and roll under the table. Said Frances.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: I think it is time for you to go to school now, said Mother.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Frances picked up her books, her lunch box, and her skipping rope.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Then she kissed Mother and Father good-bye and went to the bus stop.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: While she waited for the bus she skipped and sang:

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Jam on biscuits, jam on toast, Jam is the thing that I like most.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Jam is sticky, jam is sweet,

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Jam is tasty, jam's a treat-

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Raspberry, strawberry, gooseberry, I'm very FOND . . . OF . . . JAM!

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: That evening for dinner, Mother cooked breaded veal cutlets with string beans and baked potatoes.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Ah! said Father.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: What is there handsomer on a plate and tastier to eat than breaded veal cutlet!

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: It is a nice dish, isn't it? said Mother.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Eat up the string bean, Gloria.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Oh! said Gloria, and ate it up.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: She had already eaten her dinner of strained beef and sweet potatoes, but she liked to practice with a string bean when she could.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Where do breaded veal cutlets come from? asked Frances.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: And why are French-cut stringless beans called string beans?

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: We can talk about that another time, said Father.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Now it is time to eat our dinner.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Frances looked at her plate and sang:

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: What do cutlets wear before they're breaded?

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Flannel nightgowns?

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Cowboy boots?

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Furry jackets?

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Sailor suits?

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Then she spread jam on a slice of bread and took a bite.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: She won't try anything new, said Mother to Father.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: She just eats bread and jam.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: How do you know what you'll like if you won't even try anything? asked Father.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Well,' said Frances,

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: there are many different things to eat, and they taste many different ways.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: But when I have bread and jam I always know what I am getting, and I am always pleased.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: You try new things in your school lunches, said Mother.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Today I gave you a chicken-salad sandwich.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: There, now! said Father to Frances.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Wasn't it good?

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Well, said Frances, I traded it to Albert.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: For what? said Father.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Bread and jam, said Frances.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: The next morning at breakfast Father sat down and said, Now I call that a pretty sight!

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Fresh orange juice and poached eggs on toast.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: There's a proper breakfast for you!

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Thank you for saying so, said Mother.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Poached eggs on toast do have a cheery look, I think.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Frances began to sing a poached-egg song:

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Poached eggs on toast, why do you shiver With such  a funny little quiver?

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Then she looked down and saw that she did not have a poached egg.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: I have no poached egg, said Frances.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: I have nothing but orange juice.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: I know, said Mother.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Why is that? said Frances.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Everybody else has a poached egg.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Even Gloria has a poached egg and she is nothing but a baby.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: But you do not like eggs, said Mother, and that is why I did not poach one for you.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Have some bread and jam if you are hungry.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: So Frances ate bread and jam and went to school.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: When the bell rang for lunch Frances sat down next to her friend Albert.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: What do you have today? said Frances.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: I have a cream cheese-cucumber-and-tomato sandwich on rye bread, said Albert.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: And a pickle to go with it.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: And a hard-boiled egg and a little cardboard shaker of salt to go with that.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: And a thermos bottle of milk.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: And a bunch of grapes and a tangerine.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: And a cup custard and a spoon to eat it with.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: What do you have?

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Frances opened her lunch.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Bread and jam, she said, and milk.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: You're lucky, said Albert.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: That's just what you like.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: You don't have to trade now.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: That's right, said Frances.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: And I had bread and jam for dinner last night and for breakfast this morning.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: You certainly are lucky, said Albert.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Yes, said Frances.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: I am a very lucky girl, I guess.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: But I'll trade you if you want to.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: That's all right, said Albert.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: I like cream cheese with cucumbers and tomatoes on rye.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Albert took two napkins from his lunch box.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: He tucked one napkin under his chin.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: He spread the other one on his desk like a tablecloth.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: He arranged his lunch neatly on the napkin.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: With his spoon he cracked the shell of the hard-boiled egg.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: He peeled away the shell and bit off the end of the egg.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: He sprinkled salt on the yolk and set the egg down again.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: He unscrewed his thermos-bottle cup and filled it with milk.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Then he was ready to eat his lunch.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: He took a bite of sandwich, a bite of pickle, a bite of hard-boiled egg, and a drink of milk.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Then he sprinkled more salt on the egg and went around again.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Albert made the sandwich, the pickle, the egg, and the milk come out even.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: He ate his bunch of grapes and his tangerine.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Then he cleared away the crumpled-up waxed paper, the eggshell, and the tangerine peel.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: He set the cup custard in the middle of the napkin on his desk.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: He took up his spoon and ate up all the custard.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Then Albert folded up his napkins and put them away.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: He put away his cardboard saltshaker and his spoon.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: He screwed the cup on top of his thermos bottle.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: He shut his lunch box, put it back inside his desk, and sighed.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: I like to have a good lunch, said Albert.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Frances ate her bread and jam and drank her milk.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Then she went out to the playground and skipped rope.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: She did not skip as fast and she had skipped in the morning, and she sang:

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Jam in the morning, jam at noon,

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Bread and jam by the light of the moon.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Jam . . . is . . . very . . . nice.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: When Frances got home from school, Mother said, I know you like to have a little snack when you get home from school, 'and I have one all ready for you.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: I do like snacks! said Frances, running to the kitchen.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Here it is, said Mother.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: A glass of milk and some nice bread and jam for you.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Aren't you worried that maybe I will get sick and all my teeth will fall out from eating so much bread and jam? asked Frances.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: I don't think that will happen for quite a while, said Mother.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: So eat it all up and enjoy it.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Frances ate up most of her bread and jam, but she did not eat all of it.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: After her snack she went outside to skip rope.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Frances skipped a little more slowly than she had skipped at noon, and she sang:

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Jam for snacks and jam for meals, I know how a jam jar feels-

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: FULL . . . OF . . . JAM!

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: That evening for dinner Mother cooked spaghetti and meatballs with tomato sauce.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: I am glad to see there will be enough for second helpings, said Father.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Because spaghetti and meatballs is one of my favorite dishes.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Spaghetti and meatballs is a favorite with everybody, said Mother.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Try a little spaghetti, Gloria.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Um, said Gloria, and tried the spaghetti.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Frances looked down at her plate and saw that there was no spaghetti and meatballs on it.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: There was a slice of bread and a jar of jam.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Frances began to cry.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: My goodness! said Mother.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Frances is crying!

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: What is the matter? asked Father.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Frances looked down at her plate and sang a little sad song.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: She sang so softy that Mother and Father could scarcely hear her:

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: What I am

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Is tired of jam.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: I want spaghetti and meatballs, said Frances.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: May I have some, please?

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: I had no idea you liked spaghetti and meatballs! said Mother.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: How do you know what I'll like if you won't even try me? asked Frances, wiping her eyes.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: So Mother gave Frances spaghetti and meatballs, and she ate it all up.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: The next day when the bell rang for lunch, Albert said, What do you have today?

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: Well, said Frances, laying a paper doily on her desk and setting a tiny vase of violets in the middle of it, let me see.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: She arranged her lunch on the doily.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: I have a thermos bottle with cream of tomato soup, she said.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: And a lobster-salad sandwich on thin slices of white bread.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: I have celery, carrot sticks, and black olives, and a little cardboard shaker of salt for the celery.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: And two plums and a tiny basket of cherries.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: And vanilla pudding with chocolate sprinkles and a spoon to eat it with.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: That's a good lunch, said Albert.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: I think it's nice that there are all different kinds of lunches and breakfasts and dinners and snacks.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: I think eating is nice.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: So do I, said Frances, and she made the lobster-salad sandwich, the celery, the carrot sticks, and the olives come out even.

title: BREAD AND JAM FOR FRANCES
author: RUSSELL HOBAN
text: The End

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: This is Princess.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: She is a show dog.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Here we see her practicing for a dog show competition.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Notice the perfect posture.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Strong back

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Perfect round puffy tail

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Lean stomach

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Groomed legs

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Serious attitude, serious haircut

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Shiny teeth (even though you can't see them, believe me, they are)

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Clean shampooed hair

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Clipped nails

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: This is Ed.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: He is a show dog too.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Look at his stage presence!

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Dirt

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Ferociously wagging tail

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Favorite chewed bone

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Mud

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Scruffy

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Brain which only thinks about chew toys, mud, food, tennis balls, and sometimes airplanes

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Protruding tongue

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Drool

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Spittle

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: More dirt

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Saliva-soaked ball

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Okay, okay, so Ed isn't a show dog.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: But his family, the Hubbles, love him anyway . . .

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Not a show dog

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Uncombed

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Mismatched earrings

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Wild hair

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Unshaven

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Tacky glasses

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Hole

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: ice cream

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Lopsided ponytail

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Plastic jewelry

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: The Hubbles

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: One day, the Hubbles seen an ad in the newspaper.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: County Fair Dog Show

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Saturday 2:00 p.m.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Only the best dogs should enter, but beginners are welcome!

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: The Hubbles think Ed is the best dog ever.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Ed can . . .

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: spin in circles

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: get the newspaper

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: give big, wet kisses

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: He will make a great show dog.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Show dog!

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Your dog isn't a show dog! the Hubbles' neighbor, Mr. Pitt, grumbles.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: My princess is a show dog.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: That is a mangy mutt.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: The Hubbles don't listen.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: After all, Ed has a very good chance of winning, don't you think?

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: But they need to get Ed ready.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: There's just one problem . . . .

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: They're not exactly sure what makes a dog a show dog.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: So they decide to find out.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: They watch Princess do tricks.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Sit up and beg

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Roll over

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Jump through hoops

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Ed does tricks too.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Sit up and beg

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Roll over

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Jump through hoops

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Princess eats champion dog food that makes her coat nice and shiny.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Ed does too.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Princess gets shampooed and groomed.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: She looks very nice and pretty, indeed.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Ed gets shampooed and groomed too.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: The long-awaited dog show competition arrives!

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Ed and the Hubbles are very excited.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: The dogs parade into the arena in a perfectly straight line.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Ed does too . . . sort of.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: It's time for the dogs to strut their stuff.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Mr. Pitt and Princess go first.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: But Ed is a bit eager.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: He thinks it's time to play . . . .

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Watch out, Mr. Pitt!

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Your dog has ruined the show! shouts Mr. Pitt.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Of course, the Hubbles don't listen.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: They think Ed is a great dog.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: He can still win, right?

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Wrong!

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: The judge announces the winners.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Sheila the Shih Tzu wins third place.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Miss Lisa the Afghan Hound wins second, and Princess the Poodle wins first . . . but, hey!

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Where is Princess?

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Where is Ed?

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Where are the Hubbles?

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Where could they possibly be?

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Out celebrating of course!

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Princess deserves a festive first-place dinner.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: And Ed does too, since he's still the best dog ever.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: At least the Hubbles think so.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Princess and Ed and the Hubbles now live happily every after.

title: SHOW DOG
author: MEGHAN MCCARTHY
text: Mr. Pitt does NOT live happily ever after, but that's another story.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Five stories about two great friends

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Story number one

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Split pea soup

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Martha was very fond of making split pea soup.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Sometimes she made it all day long.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Pots and pots of split pea soup.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: If there was one thing that George was not fond of, it was split pea soup.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: As a matter of fact, George hated split pea soup more than anything else in the world.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: But it was so hard to tell Martha.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: One day after George had eaten ten bowls of Martha's soup, he said to himself,  I just can't stand another bowl.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Not even another spoonful.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: So, while Martha was out in the kitchen, George carefully poured the rest of his soup into his loafers under the table.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Now she will think I have eaten it.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: But Martha was watching from the kitchen.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: How do you expect to walk home with your loafers full of split pea soup? she asked George.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Oh dear, said George.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: You saw me.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: And why didn't you yell me that you hate my split pea soup?

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: I didn't want to hurt your feelings, said George.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: That's silly, said Martha.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Friends should always tell each other the truth.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: As a matter of fact, I don't like split pea soup very much myself.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: I only like to make it.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: From now on, you'll never have to eat that awful soup again.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: What a relief! George sighed.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Would you like some chocolate chip cookies instead? asked Martha.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Oh, that would be lovely, said George.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Then you shall have them, said his friend.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Story Number Two

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: The Flying Machine

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: I'm going to be the first of my species to fly! said George.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: They why aren't you flying? asked Martha.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: It seems to me that you are still on the ground.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: You are right, said George.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: I don't seem to be going anywhere at all.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Maybe the basket is too heavy, said Martha.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Yes, said George, I think you are right again.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Maybe if I climb out, the basket will be lighter.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Oh dear! cried George.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Now what have I done?

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: There goes my flying machine!

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: That's all right, said Martha.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: I would rather have you down here with me.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Story number three

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: George was fond of peeking in windows.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: One day George peeked in on Martha.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: He never did that again.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: We are friends, said Martha.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: But there is such a thing as privacy!

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Story number four

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: The mirror

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: How I love to look at myself in the mirror, said Martha.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Every chance she got, Martha looked at herself in the mirror.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Sometimes Martha even woke up during the night to look at herself.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: The is fun.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: She giggled.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: But George was getting tired of watching Martha look at herself in the mirror.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: One day, George pasted a silly picture he had drawn of Martha onto the mirror.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: What a scare it gave Martha.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Oh dear! she cried.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: What has happened to me?

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: That's what happens when you look at yourself too much in the mirror, said George.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Then I won't do it ever again, said Martha.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: And she didn't.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: The last story

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: The tooth

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: One day when George was skating to Martha's house, he tripped and fell.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: And he broke off his right front tooth.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: His favorite tooth too.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: When he got to Martha's, George cried his eyes out.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: Oh dear me! he cried.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: I look so funny without my favorite tooth!

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: There, there, said Martha.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: The next day George went to the dentist.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: The dentist replaced George's missing tooth with a lovely gold one.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: When Martha saw George's lovely new golden tooth, she was very happy.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: George! she exclaimed.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: You look so handsome and distinguished with your new tooth!

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: And George was happy too.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: That's what friends are for, he said.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: They always look on the bright side and they always know how to cheer you up.

title: GEORGE AND MARTHA
author: JAMES MARSHALL
text: But they also tell you the truth, said Martha with a smile.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: The Lupine Lady lives in a small house overlooking the sea.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: In between the rocks around her house grow blue and purple and rose-colored flowers.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: The Lupine Lady is little and old.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: But she has not always been that way.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: I know.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: She is my great-aunt, and she told me so.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Once upon a time she was a little girl named Alice, who lived in a city by the sea.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: From the front stoop she could see the wharves and the bristling masts of tall ships.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Many years ago her grandfather had come to America on a large sailing ship.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Now he worked in the shop at the bottom of the house, making figureheads for the prows of ships, and carving Indians out of wood to put in front of cigar stores.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: For Alice's grandfather was an artist.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: He pained pictures, too, of sailing ships and places across the sea.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: When he was very busy, Alice helped him put in the skies.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: In the evening Alice sat on her grandfather's knee and listened to his stories of faraway places.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: When he had finished, Alice would say, When I grow up, I too will go to faraway places, and when I grow old, I too will live beside the sea.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: That is all very well, little Alice, said her grandfather, but there is a third thing you must do.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: What is that? asked Alice.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: You must do something to make the world more beautiful, said her grandfather.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: All right, said Alice.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: But she did not know what that could be.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: In the meantime Alice got up and washed her face and ate porridge for breakfast.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: She went to school and came home and did her homework.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: And pretty soon she was grown up.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Then my Great-aunt Alice set out to do the three things she had told her grandfather she was going to do.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: She left home and went to live in another city far from the sea and the salt air.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: There she worked in a library, dusting books and keeping them from getting mixed up, and helping people find the ones they wanted.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Some of the books told her about faraway places.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: People called her Miss Rumphius now.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Sometimes she went to the conservatory in the middle of the park.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: When she stepped inside on a wintry day, the warm moist air wrapped itself around her, and the sweet smell of jasmine filled her nose.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: This is almost like a tropical isle, said Miss Rumphius.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: But not quite.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: So Miss Rumphius went to a real tropical island, where people kept cockatoos and monkeys as pets.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: She walked on long beaches, picking up beautiful shells.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: One day she met the Bapa Raja, king of a fishing village.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: You must be tired,  he said.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Come into my house and rest.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: So Miss Rumphius went in and met the Bapa Raja's wife.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: The Bapa Raja himself fetched a green coconut and cut a slice off the top so that Miss Rumphius could drink the coconut water inside.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Before she left, the Bapa Raja gave her a beautiful mother-of-pearl shell on which he had painted a bird of paradise and the words, You will always remain in my heart.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: You will always remain in mine too, said Miss Rumphius.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: My great-aunt Miss Alice Rumphius climbed tall mountains where the snow never melted.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: She went through jungles and across deserts.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: She saw lions playing and kangaroos jumping.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: And everywhere she made friends she would never forget.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Finally she came to the Land of the Lotus-Eaters, and there, getting off a camel, she hurt her back.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: What a foolish thing to do, said Miss Rumphius.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Well, I have certainly seen faraway places.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Maybe it is time to find my place by the sea.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: And it was, and she did.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: From the Porch of her new house Miss Rumphius watched the sun come up; she watched it cross the heavens and sparkle on the water; and she saw it set in glory in the evening.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: She started a little garden among the rocks that surrounded her house, and she planted a few flower seeds in the stony ground.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Miss Rumphius was almost perfectly happy.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: But there is still one more thing I have to do, she said.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: I have to do something to make the world more beautiful.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: But what?

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: The world already is pretty nice, she thought, looking out over the ocean.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: The next spring Miss Rumphius was not very well.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Her back was bothering her again, and she had to stay in bed most of the time.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: The flowers she had planted the summer before had come up and bloomed in spite of the stony ground.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: She could see them from her bedroom window, blue and purple and rose-colored.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Lupines, said Miss Rumphius with satisfaction.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: I have always loved lupines the best.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: I wish I could plant more seeds this summer so that I could have still more flowers next year.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: But she was not able to.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: After a hard winter spring came.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Miss Rumphius was feeling much better.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Now she could take walks again.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: One afternoon she started to go up and over the hill, where she had not been in a long time.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: I don't believe my eyes! she cried when she got to the top.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: For there on the other side of the hill was a large patch of blue and purple and rose-colored lupines!

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: It was the wind, she said as she knelt in delight.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: It was the wind that brought the seeds from my garden here!

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: And the birds must have helped!

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Then Miss Rumphius had a wonderful ideal

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: She hurried home and got out her seed catalogues.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: She sent off to the very best seed house for five bushels of lupine seed.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: All that summer Miss Rumphius, her pockets full of seeds, wandered over fields and headlands, sowing lupines.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: She scattered seeds along the highways and down the country lanes.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: She flung handfuls of them around the schoolhouse and back of the church.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: She tossed them into hollows and along stone walls.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Her back didn't hurt her any more at all.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Now some people called her That Crazy Old Lady.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: The next spring there were lupines everywhere.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Fields and hillsides were covered with blue and purple and rose-colored flowers.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: They bloomed along the highways and down the lanes.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Bright patches lay around the schoolhouse and back of the church.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Down in the hollows and along the stone walls grew the beautiful flowers.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Miss Rumphius had done the third, the most difficult thing of all!

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: My Great-aunt Alice, Miss Rumphius, is very old now.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Her hair is very white.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Every year there are more and more lupines.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Now they call her the Lupine Lady.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Sometimes my friends stand with me outside her gate, curious to see the old, old lady who planted the fields of lupines.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: When she invites us in, they come slowly.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: They think she is the oldest woman in the world.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: Often she tells us stories of faraway places.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: When I grow up, I tell her, I too will go to faraway places and come home to live by the sea.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: That is all very well, little Alice, says my aunt, but there is a third thing you must do.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: What is that? I ask.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: You must do something to make the world more beautiful.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: All right, I say.

title: MISS RUMPHIUS
author: BARBARA COONEY
text: But I do not know yet what that can be.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: August 27, 1935

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Dear Uncle Jim,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Grandma told us after supper that you want me to come to the city and live with you until things get better.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Did she tell you that Papa has been out of work for a long time, and no one asks Mama to make dresses anymore?

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: We all cried, even Papa.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: But them Mama made us laugh with her stories about your chasing her up trees when you were both little.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Did you really do that?

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: I'm small, but strong, and I'll help all I can.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: However, Grandma said to finish my schoolwork before doing anything else.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Your niece,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Lydia Grace Finch

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: September 3, 1935

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Dear Uncle Jim,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: I'm mailing this from the train station.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: I forgot to tell you in the last letter three important things that I'm too shy to say to your face:

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: 1. I know a lot about gardening but nothing about baking.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: 2. I'm anxious to learn to bake, but is there any place to plant seeds?

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: 3. I like to be called Lydia Grace - just like Grandma.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Your niece,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Lydia Grace Finch

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: On the train

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: September 4, 1935

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Dear Mama,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: I feel so pretty in your dress that you made over for me.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: I hope you don't miss it too much.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Dear Papa,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: I haven't forgotten what you said about recognizing Uncle Jim:

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Just look for Mama's face with a big nose and a mustache!

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: I promise not to tell him.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: (Does he have a sense of humor?)

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: And, dearest Grandma,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Thank you for the seeds.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: The train is rocking me to sleep, and every time I doze off, I dream of gardens.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Love to all,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Lydia Grace

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: September 5, 1935

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Dear Mama and Papa and Grandma,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: I'm so excited!!!

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: There are window boxes here!

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: They look as if they've been waiting for me, so now we'll both wait for spring.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: And, Grandma, the sun shines down on the corner where I'll live and work.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Love to all,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Lydia Grace

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: P.S. Uncle Jim doesn't smile.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: December 25, 1935

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Dear Mama, Papa and Grandma,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: I adore the seed catalogues you sent for Christmas.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: And, Grandma, thank you for all the bulbs.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: I hope you received my drawings.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: I wrote a long poem for Uncle Jim.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: He didn't smile, but I think he liked it.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: He read it aloud, then put it in his shirt pocket and patted it.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Love to all,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Lydia Grace

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: February 12, 1936

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Dearest Grandma,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Thank you again for those bulbs you sent at Christmas.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: You should see them now!

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: I really like Ed and Emma Beech, Uncle Jim's friends who work here.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: When I first arrived, Emma told me she'd show me how to knead bread if would teach her the Latin names of all the flowers I know.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Now, just half a year later, I'm kneading bread and she's speaking Latin!

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: More good news: We have a store cat named Otis who at this very moment is sleeping at the foot of my bed.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Love to all,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Lydia Grace

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: P.S. Uncle Jim isn't smiling yet, but I'm hoping for a smile soon.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: March 5, 1936

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Dear Mama, Papa, and Grandma,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: I've discovered a secret place.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: You can't imagine how wonderful it is.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: No one else knows about it, but Otis.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: I have great plans.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Thank you for all the letters.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: I'll try to write more, but I'm really busy planting all your seeds in cracked teacups and bent cake pans!

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: And Grandma, you should smell the good dirt I'm bringing home from the vacant lot down the street.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Love to all,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Lydia Grace

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: April 27, 1936
