title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Dearest Grandma,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: All the seeds and roots are sprouting.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: I can hear you saying, April showers bring May flowers.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Emma and I are sprucing up the bakery and I'm playing a great trick on Uncle Jim.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: He sees me reading my mail, planting seeds in the window boxes, going to school, doing my homework, sweeping the floor.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: But he never sees me working in my secret Place.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Love to all,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Lydia Grace

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: P.S. I'm planning on a big smile from Uncle Jim in the near future.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Dear Mama, Papa, and Grandma,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: You should have heard Emma laugh today when I opened your letter and dirt fell out onto the sidewalk!

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Thank you for all the baby plants.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: They survived the trip in the big envelope.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: More about Emma: She's helping me with the secret place.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Hurrah!

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Love to all,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Lydia Grace

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: P.S. I saw Uncle Jim almost smile today.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: The store was full (well, almost full) of customers.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Dear Grandma,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Flowers are blooming all over the place.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: I'm also growing radishes, onions, and three kinds of lettuce in the window boxes.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Some neighbors have brought containers for me to fill with flowers, and a few customers even gave me plants from their gardens this spring!

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: They don't call me Lydia Grace anymore.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: They call me the gardener.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Love to all,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Lydia Grace

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: P.S. I'm sure Uncle Jim will smile soon.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: I'm almost ready to show him the secret place.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: July 4, 1936

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Dearest Mama, Papa, and Grandma,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: I am bursting with happiness!

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: The entire city seems so beautiful, especially this morning.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: The secret place is ready for Uncle Jim.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: At noon, the store will close for the holiday, and then we'll bring him up to the roof.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: I've tried to remember everything you ever taught me about beauty.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Love to all,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Lydia Grace

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: P.S. I can already imagine Uncle Jim's smile.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: You've arrived

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Please go up

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Dear Mama, Papa, and Grandma,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: My heart is pounding so hard I'm sure the customers can hear it downstairs!

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: At lunch today, Uncle Jim put the Closed sign on the door and told Ed and Emma and me to go upstairs and wait.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: He appeared with the most amazing cake I've ever seen – covered in flowers!

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: I truly believe that cake equals one thousand smiles.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: And then he took your letter out of his pocket with the news of Papa's job!

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: I'm coming home!

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Love to all, and see you soon,

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: Lydia Grace

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: P.S. Grandma, I've given all of my plants to Emma.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: I can't wait to help you in your garden again.

title: THE GARDENER
author: SARAH STEWART
text: We gardeners never retire.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Winter was on the way.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Lisa took her woolen clothes out of the chest and carried them outside.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: She was hanging them up in the fresh air, when a strong wind blew one of her stockings off the line.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Curious Hedgie found it and poked his nose in.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: When he pulled it out, the stocking was stuck on his prickles.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: How embarrassing, Hedgie thought.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: The mother hen came by with her chicks.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Cackle, cackle, she clucked, and laughed.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: What's that on your head, Hedgie?

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Why, it's me new hat, he told her.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Isn't it beautiful?

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: The mother hen cocked her head as if she had an idea.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: And off she ran.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Hedgie saw the noisy gander looking down at him.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Honk, honk!

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Ho, ho, ho! the gander laughed.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Look at that!

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: The hedgehog has flipped his gizzard.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Laugh today, Gander.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: But tomorrow when it rains, my hat will keep me dry.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: The gander thought for a moment.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: And off he ran.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: The barn cat was watching from a tree as Hedgie tugged at the stocking.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Meow, he called down.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: What a silly-looking hedgehog you are, with that thing on your head.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: But my ears will be warm in a snowstorm.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Hmmmmm, purred the cat.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: And off he ran.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: The farm dog and her puppies found Hedgie in a patch of brambles.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Hedgie, is that a hat you're wearing?

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: How funny you look, she barked, and her puppies yelped and giggled.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: But I'll be cozy and dry when it snows, Hedgie said.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: The farm dog's ears perked up.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: And off she ran.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Oink, oink! the piglets squealed.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: What are you up to, Hedgie? the mama pig asked.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Making sure my hat doesn't fall off if an icy wind blows up.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: I see, said the mama pig.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: And off she ran.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Hedgie, what is that ridiculous thing on your head? the pony snorted at Hedgie.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: That was the last straw.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: It's my hat, of course.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Don't you know that everyone should wear a hat in the winter when it's cold and snowy! Hedgie shouted.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: The pony looked startled.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Hedgie was usually so friendly.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: And off he ran.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Hedgie just wanted to be alone.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: He was tired of everyone laughing at him, and with this thing on his head, he wouldn't even fit in his den.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: He didn't see Lisa running after him, the other stocking in her hand.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Come back, you silly hedgehog, she called.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Oh, no, Hedgie thought.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Even the girl is laughing at me!

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Lisa caught up and pulled her stocking off Hedgie's head.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: You ridiculous little hedgehog, she laughed.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Don't you know that animals don't wear clothes!

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Hedgie headed for his den, and Lisa started back toward the clothesline.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: That's when she saw all of her missing woolens.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: The animals had taken them and each one was thinking, Now I am wearing a magnificent hat!

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Lisa was still chasing them when Hedgie reached his den.

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: How ridiculous they look!

title: THE HAT
author: JAN BRETT
text: Don't they know that animals should never wear clothes!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie turned out to be just the kind of doughnut he hoped he's be – chocolate-covered with bright-colored candy sprinkles.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Look at all my sprinkles – there must be a million of them!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Actually, there are only 135, but I'm not going to spoil it for him.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: He was made very early in the morning at the Downtown Bakery – Home of the Best Doughnuts A-‘Round'!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie was proud to be one of the best.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: He knew that people all over town made special trips to his bakery to buy doughnuts of their very own.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Get it?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: A-Round??

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: We're round.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Give me a minute – I'm good at these.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: As Arnie sat on the tray, which had just been placed in the doughnut case, he took a moment to reflect on the amazing things that had happened to him that morning.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I remember that . . . .

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: 1. cut into ring

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: 2. deep-fried

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: 3. cooled

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: 4. iced

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: 5. sprinkled

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: 6. named

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Ringy-dingy doughnut-making thingy

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Wheeeee!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Ouch!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Quit it!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I'm soaking in boiling grease, but I love it!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Your drink, sir.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Thanks.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Who's that handsome doughnut?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Hold still.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: That tickles!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Caution sprinkle area – must wear safety goggles.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Whatever I'm named, I'm going to go by cool iced-D

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I like it

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arlene

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie looked around and saw all sorts of doughnuts sitting nearby.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Crullers

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: (French)

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Monjour, madame.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: (plain)

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Howdy, Frenchy!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Powdered

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Oh dear, I'm so greasy.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: The extremely rare square doughnut

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Chocolate zebra

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Long John

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I prefer Long Jonathan

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Doughnut holes

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Hello Long John!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Jelly-filled

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: EEEOOO! His brains are oozing out!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: It's not brains, silly - it's jelly!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Double checking

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: OOO is it brain?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Nah, it's Jelly.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Cinnamon twist

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Éclair

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Iced chocolate

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Plain

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: You know, a little blue icing would be fabulous on you!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Cream-filled

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Bear claw

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: He tried to strike up a conversation with an apple fritter on the next tray over, but she didn't seem to want to talk.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Glazed

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Apple fritter

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: How ‘bout that deep fryer? . . .

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Any relation to Larry Fritter? . . .

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Want to count my sprinkles?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: It us rather early.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Maybe she's not a morning doughnut, Arnie supposed.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Various muffins

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Steel-belted radial doughnut

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Okay, now I get it . . . round

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: It was 6 a.m. and the baker had just hung the open sign in the window.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie was fascinated as he watched customers stream into the bakery.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: One by one, doughnuts were chosen, placed in paper bags, and whisked away with their new owners.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Some went by the dozen in giant boxes.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: RRRR- must be a day-old doughnut

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Must . . .have . . . doughnuts

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Oh she – he gives me the heavy end.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I've been sent to collect the tasty, fried, sweet crystal-coated cake disks.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Is this the proper coordinate?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Number 105!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Good-bye! Arnie yelled to each doughnut.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Have a great trip!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Do you promise to love, honor and cherish this doughnut until the very last bite?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I do.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Look, Grandma – this one matches your dress!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Doughnuts make good wheel.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: This is so exciting! I wonder who will choose me?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Just them, Arnie looked up and saw a man pointing right at him!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Moi?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Moi (pronounced mwah) is the French word for me.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: He learned it from moi.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Before he could say another word, he was pulled form the tray and placed in a paper bag of his very own.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Good-bye, everyone!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Thank you, Mr. Bing.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Have a nice day!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie heard the baker say to the man.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Mr. Bing . . . that's a fine name, Arnie decided.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I can hardly wait to meet him!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Good-bye Arnie!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: We'll miss you!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I should have talked to him while I had the chance.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: (the grand exit that Arnie's imagining)

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: The ride to Mr. Bing's apartment was a little bumpy.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie was grateful for the soft napkin the baker had so thoughtfully placed underneath him in the bag.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Jump!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: You're outta there!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Bumps

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: More Bumps

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Bumpy Humps

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: He had never ridden in a car and wished he could look out the window to see all the sights.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Nut more than anything, he wished he could meet Mr. Bing.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Why does he keep me in this bag? Arnie wondered.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Grump on a stump

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Get those words off my lawn!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Clumps of bumps

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Bumps and lumps

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Finally, the car came to a stop and they were home.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Mr. Bing carefully removed Arnie from his paper bag and placed him on a clean, shiny plate.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: What a handsome plate, Arnie said to himself.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I'm not crazy about the design – I prefer a more modern look.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: But it's nothing a little paint can't fix.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Chocolate Milk

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Mr. Bing gently lifted Arnie from his new plate.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Isn't that cute? thought Arnie, as he closed his eyes and smiled.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: He wants to hold me.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: As Arnie relaxed in Mr. Bing's hand, he felt himself moving higher and higher away from his plate.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: When he opened his eyes to see where he was going, he discovered that he was headed straight for Mr. Bing's open mouth!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: What are you doing? shouted Arnie.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Mr. Bing was stunned.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: He dropped Arnie back onto the plate.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I was going to . . . eat you, he replied in shock.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: EAT ME? Arnie shrieked, his sprinkles flying everywhere.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Why would you do a thing like that?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Do you make a habit of eating all your houseguests?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Nnnno . . . of course not.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: So, why then did it suddenly occur to you to eat ME? Arnie demanded.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Well . . . because . . . you're a doughnut.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: That's what doughnuts are for – to eat.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Do you mean to tell me you've done this before?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Yes . . . I eat a doughnut every day, Mr. Bing said sheepishly.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie froze.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: He felt sick and frightened and angry!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Ugggh!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I'd better get out of here before he tries to eat me again!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Well, That explains why my friends never write or call - they've probably all been EATEN!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: He thought to himself for a moment.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I must put a stop to this right away!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I'll call the bakery and warn the others.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Whoever's LEFT, that is!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie knew that there was no time to waste and that he needed to be very sneaky in order to keep his plan from Mr. Bing.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: He turned to Mr. Bing and said in his sweetest voice, Excuse me, sir, but I don't believe we've been properly introduced.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: My name is Arnie.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Um . . . hello . . . Arnie, Mr. Bing stammered.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: It's nice to eat you – I mean meet you.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Mr. Bing, would you be a dear and allow me to use your telephone?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie asked extra politely.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Oh . . . well . . . okay, said Mr. Bing, and he handed Arnie the phone.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: As quickly as he could, Arnie dialed the number of the bakery.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: (still shocked to actually be talking to a doughnut!)

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: The baker answered the phone.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Downtown Bakery, home of the best

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Mr. Baker Man! Arnie frantically whispered.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: This is Arnie the doughnut.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Do you remember me?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: You made me at 5:15 this morning, and I was bought about twenty minutes ago by a man who goes by the name of Br. Bing.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Yes, Arnie, the baker answered.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: ‘What can I do for you?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Now, I don't want to alarm you, but just moments ago, that man tried to eat me!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: And not only that – he claims to have eaten hundreds of us!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I'm going to make a run for it, but I wanted to warn you so that if you see him coming into the bakery again, you can stop him!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Oh my, Arnie-I thought you understood.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: That's why I make doughnuts . . . for people to eat.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I CAN'T BELIEVE IT! Arnie gasped.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Are the other doughnuts aware of this arrangement?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: well, I think so, the baker said.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Let me ask them to make sure.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Showing signs of doughnut shock

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Popped-up eyebrow sprinkles

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Bugged-out eyeballs

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Overall dazed expression

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Severe sprinkle loss

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Weak in the knees

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Feels like someone punched a hole right through him

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: The baker yelled to the other doughnuts, DO YOU DOUGHNUTS KNOW THAT YOU'RE GOING TO BE EATEN?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: YES, we know! the doughnuts shouted back.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: We're DELICIOUS!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: We're very popular!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: People love us!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: C'est magnifique

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Try us for yourself!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Is he going a little kooky?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Kooky or cookie?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Did you hear that Arnie? the baker asked.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie was crushed.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: The phone dropped from his hand.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: He'd heard all he needed to hear.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie forgot all about his plan to escape.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: He collapsed back onto the plate, glanced up at Mr. Bing, and muttered, All right then, let's get this over with.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Go ahead and eat me.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Mr. Bing gazed down at Arnie.  I'm not going to eat you, Arnie, he said reassuringly.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I just wouldn't feel right about it now.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: REALLY? Arnie said, with a huge sigh of relief.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Well, I'm glad to see that you've come to your senses!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: But since I'm not going to eat you, Mr. Bing continues, I'll have to figure our something else to do with you.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I paid good money for you – I don't want to be wasteful.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Of course not! Arnie agreed.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: What we need to do is each make a list of things I can do with you instead of eating you.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Between the two of us, I know we'll come up with something.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Good plan, Mr. Bing! Arnie said.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: This will be a breeze-I bet I'm good at lots of stuff!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: They both feverishly wrote down their ideas.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: When they were finished, Mr. Bing asked, Would you like to read yours first?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Sure thing, Mr. Bing! Arnie answered.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Things Mr. Bing can do with me instead of eating me

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Do you need a ballroom dance partner?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: No, I don't dance.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: You could use a personal fitness trainer.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Drop and give me 20!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Hmmmmm, I'd get too sweaty.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: How about a portrait painter?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: oh, heavens no!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Would you like me to entertain at your parties?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I wonder if he does weddings.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Doughnut make my brown eyes bluuuue . . .

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: He's fabulous!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Wherever did you find him?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I don't like throwing parties.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I could be your chauffeur.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Look out for that tree!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Relax.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: But you can't see over the steering wheel.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I'd make a great bodyguard!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Who could you protect me from – a cookie?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: That's close enough, Ma'am.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: All righty, Mr. Bing.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Let's hear what you came up with!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Okey-dokey, he replied.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I just know you'll like some of these.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Things I can do with Arnie instead of eating him

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I could use you as a pincushion.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Ouch!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Ooooh, too painful.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: How about an air freshener for my car?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Hi Arnie – you smell good enough to eat!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: How about not?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Would you like to be a picture frame?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I don't imagine so.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I need a new bowling ball.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Well, don't look at me!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Yea, Arnie!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: You'd make a fine paperweight.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Keep up the good work, Arnie!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: BORING!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Hat about a doorstop?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Thanks, Arnie!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Try again.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: But there was nothing else on Mr. Bing's list.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: They were both completely out of ideas.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie and Mr. Bing were exhausted.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: They felt terribly disappointed.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: After a few minutes of awkward silence, Mr. Bing finally spoke.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I'm sorry, Arnie- but it's clear that we can't agree on anything for you to do around here.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: This is difficult for me to say, but I think it would be best if you found another home.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I know, said Arnie, fighting back tears.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I'll just be on my way then.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Is it all right if I keep this napkin to pack up all my loose sprinkles?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Of course, Mr. Bing replied sadly.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: As soon as I get a job, I'll pay you back the money you spent on me.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: That's not necessary, Arnie.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Good-bye Arnie- we've got some lovely parting gifts for you.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie shook Mr. Bing's hand and thanked him for his kindness.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Mr. Bing opened the door, and as Arnie left he paused and said, I guess doughnuts really are only good for eating, aren't they?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: They both waved good-bye and Arnie was gone.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Mr. Bing stood at the window and watched as Arnie walked away.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: He walked past the flower beds, the mailboxes, and the apartment manager's office.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: You can have my limited-time offer for an interest-free credit card.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: No mail for me.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Office

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Now leasing

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Is there anything worse than a sad pastry?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Remember how happy I was at the beginning of the story?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I can't read, but you sure looked happy.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: He passed the tennis court, the swimming pool, and the clubhouse.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: But when Arnie reached the NO DOGS ALLOWED sign at the end of the driveway, Mr. Bing suddenly came up with a new idea.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Oopsie!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Sometimes life feels like a big bonk on the head.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Technically, I'm food - so I guess a quick dip in the pool is out.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: No food in pool area.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Is that a doughnut?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Yeah, whatever, anyway, about my trip abroad. . .

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: No dogs allowed

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Bye, Arnie

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: (the fastest Mr. Bing's moved in years)

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Wait up! yelled Mr. Bing as he ran after him.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie turned back and stopped.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: When Mr. Bing caught up with him, he was out of breath.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I can't believe I didn't think of this earlier! Mr. Bing panted.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie, I've always wanted a dog and could never have one because they're not allowed here.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: But there's no sign that says: NO DOUGHNUTS ALLOWED.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie perked up when he realized that Mr. Bing was thinking.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Keep talkin' big guy.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: NO DOGS ALLOWED

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Would you like to take walks and play fetch? Mr. Bing asked excitedly.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: You bet I would!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Can you do tricks, like rolling over?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Rolling over?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: LOOK AT ME- I was MADE For rolling over!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Well, then, there's only one thing left to ask.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie, will you be my doughnut-dog?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Oh, Mr. Bing- I would LOVE to be your doughnut-dog!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: It's a WACKY idea, but it just might work!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: From that moment on, Arnie and Mr. Bing were inseparable.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie liked being a doughnut-dog even better than he liked being a doughnot.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Get it, Arnie!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Take pine.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Pet groomers

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Bye Arnie!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Buy Mr. Bing!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I got the DELUXE package!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: He went through a short phase of chewing on furniture and barking at the mailman, but after a crash course in obedience school, he graduated first in his class.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Everywhere the two of them went, people would stop to pet Arnie.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: No one had ever seen a doughnut-dog before.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Congratulations Arnie!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Is that a doughnut-dog?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: What a darling man.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: What a darling dog!

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: You're so sticky, yes you are.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: I love that Arnie.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Got a napkin?

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie and Mr. Bing had so much fun together.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Arnie was the best pet Mr. Bing could ever have hoped for – and Mr. Bing was Arnie's best friend.

title: ARNIE THE DOUGHNUT
author: LAURIE KELLER
text: Beware of Doughnut.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Friday is errand day.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: My mom goes on boring errands, and I have to go with her.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: And this Friday seemed like every other Friday . . . until we got to the bakery.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: A sign above the doughnuts read: Buy a dozen get a dinosaur.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: I couldn't believe my eyes.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Neither could my mom.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: They must mean a toy, she said.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: But when I took the box of doughnuts, the lady behind the counter said, Hold on, little guy.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Don't forget your dinosaur.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: And there he was!

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Mom! I yelled.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: It was a triceratops.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: What! cried my mom.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: She did not look happy.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: How are we supposed to get that home?

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: The bakery lady smiled.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Oh, don't worry, he'll follow you.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: They always do.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: And he did . . . all the way to the doctor's office, where I had to go for my checkup.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: My mom shook her head.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: What are we going to do with him now?

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: She looked him up and down.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: That took a while.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: We can't bring him inside, she said finally.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: He'll have to stay in the parking lot.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: I told him not to talk to strangers.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: After my checkup, I asked for a sticker, like usual.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: No stickers today, said the nurse.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Just dinosaurs.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: With a shot, you get two.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: The nurse smiled.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Not today, buddy.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: But you can pick up your dinosaur at the front desk.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Mom! I yelled.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: There, at the front desk, was a stegosaurus.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: What on earth is going on? my mom cried.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: It's a special day, the nurse explained.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Today, dinosaurs come with everything!

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Yessss! I said.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Noooo, my mom groaned.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: We walked down the street, and my triceratops and my stegosaurus walked right behind us.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: THUD, THUD, THUD.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: They made friends right away.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Across the street, other kids had dinosaurs too.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: I saw an ankylosaur, a duckbill, and a velociraptor.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: We all waved at each other.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Our mothers glared and kept on walking.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: I think we'd better go home right now, my mom said.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: But what about my haircut?

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: The barber's waiting for me.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: My mom looked at the dinosaurs.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Then she looked at my bangs.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: The barber always gives you a balloon, doesn't he?

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: A nice balloon?

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Uh-huh, I said.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: I didn't want a balloon.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: I wanted a barosaur.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: At the barbershop, I gave my triceratops and my stegosaurus doughnuts for a snack.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: They waited outside and watched through the glass.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: The barber pumped the chair up high.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: He cut my hair too short, but I didn't mind, because then he patted my head and said, Wait right here, sport.'

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: He was gone for a long time.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: My mom tapped her foot.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: I don't like this, she said.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Where exactly do they keep the balloons?

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Just then, the barber came back with something flying over his head.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: It wasn't a balloon.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Mom! I yelled.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: It was a pterosaur.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: This is too much, my mom protested.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Now, listen, she said to the barber.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: I think a balloon will do just fine today.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Don't you have any balloons?

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Sorry, lady.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: No balloons.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: You get one of these instead.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: It was like that everywhere we went.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: At the shoe store, the sign read: BUY TWO PAIR, GET DINOSAUR FREE!

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: My mom decided my shoes would last a while longer.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: At the theater, we could hear the popcorn man shouting, Butter?

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: No butter?

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: You want a dinosaur with that?

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: My mom said we'd go to the movies another day.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: At the diner, I wanted to stop for a hamburger.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: But then a girl walked out with a Tyrannosaurus rex.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Okay, that's it! my mom cried.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: We are definitely not having lunch there.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: She looked at my triceratops, my stegosaurus, and my pterosaur.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: What are we supposed to do with all of these dinosaurs?

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: We don't have room for them!

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: We can't take care of them!

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: I hugged her leg.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Don't worry, Mom.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: They can live in the backyard!

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: My mom shook her head.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Sweetheart, they're not toys.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Dinosaurs are a lot of work.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: But, Mom, look!

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: They eat anything.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: And they sleep outside.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: I'll do everything, I promise.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Please, Mom?

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Please? My mom sighed.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Well, I suppose we can't just leave them here.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Thank heavens we didn't stop at the diner.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: We hurried home, and my dinosaurs hurried after us.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: THUD, THUD, THUD.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: FLAP, FLAP, FLAP.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: When we were almost there, we saw a little duckbill dinosaur, standing alone on the street corner.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: He looked lost.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Mom, that's a baby hadrosaur.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: He's all by himself!

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Sweetie, we've already got our hands full.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: The hadrosaur followed us.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: It wasn't my fault.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: When we got home, my mom needed to lie down, so I made lunch for the dinosaurs.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Then I showed them where to go to the bathroom.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: I told them to stay out of the neighbor's yard because of his mean dog.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: And I showed them my slide, my tire swing, and all the toys in the garage.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: They seemed to be having fun, but they really went wild when I took out my Frisbee.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: The hadrosaur had the first throw.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: The Frisbee landed on the roof.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: I saw my mom watching from the window.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Is everything all right out there? she asked.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Everything's fine, Mom.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: We can get it down.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: And my pterosaur flew up and plucked the Frisbee out of the gutter.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: My mom kept watching.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: She looked at him for a long time.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: The next thing I knew, she had him cleaning the gutters!

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Then she came out to the backyard with a pile of wet clothes.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: These spikes come in handy, don't they, she said.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: Pretty soon, my mom had thought of chores for all of my dinosaurs.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: But I knew they didn't mind.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: It just meant they were part of the family.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: When we were finished helping, my mom said I could invite some friends over.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: It was a bring-your-own-dinosaur party!

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: And guess what happened next?

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: I heard my mom on the phone to the bakery.

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: She asked, Do you have any doughnuts left?

title: WHEN DINOSAURS CAME WITH EVERYTHING
author: ELISE BROACH
text: And that's when I knew everything would be just fine.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The train leaves in minutes.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Passengers buy tickets and rush across the floor to where the train is humming on its tracks.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Conductors look up the platform.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: They check their watches.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: One minute. Hats wave, whistles blow.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: All aboard! Not all.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: A passenger jumps on at the last second.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The doors whoosh shut.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The train pulls out of the station . . ..  and out of the city.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The train is a red-striped Commuter Train.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The conductor swings down the aisle, shouts, Tickets please! and snaps holes in the tickets with his punch.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The train clatters past ball fields and bridges, past backyards and ponds.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Main streets flash by.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The view changes every second.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Hello town, good-bye town.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: On to the next town.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The Commuter Train slows with creaking brakes.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Announcements crackle.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Some words get lost: We are arriving at Ghblighrrfzze.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The train stops at a small station.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Passengers off, passengers on.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: As the Commuter Train waits, another train roars past on another track.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: A larger train.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: A bright blue Passenger Train hurrying between cities.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The train is late so up in the cab of the engine, the engineer pulls back the throttle.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The Passenger Train powers forward.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: It hurtles past barns and farmhouses.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The engine is so big it makes other big things look small.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The engineer sits very still but his fingers are always moving.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Pushing levers, turning dials.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: He taps a blue button -long, long, short, long-and the horn blares out across a valley of fields and steeples.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: As the train approaches a rail crossing, it sounds like a storm.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: As the train passes, it sounds like dropped pots and pans.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: As the train leaves, it sounds like the da dum da dum of a beating heart.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Then, silence.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: But up ahead the Passenger Train keeps going, thundering into the outskirts of a Midwestern city filled with smokestacks and factories and belching steam.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Tracks weave in and out.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Small animals scurry under the tracks.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The Passenger Train crawls over the tracks through a jungle of gravel, wires, and dirt.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Everything smells of grease and rust and burnt toast.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The train lurches up to the station.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Bells ring, doors open.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Passengers off, passengers on.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Tall men with red caps unload luggage and wheel it through the echoing hall.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: In the rail yard next to the station, another train works.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: An orange Freight Train loading up.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: It grumbles under its breath as railcars are hauled and hitched to its back.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The railcars are filled with steel, concrete, oil, wheat, corn, and lumber.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Things used to make other things.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Sturdy things.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: All crammed in containers the color of tomatoes and eggs.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Thick white letters cover the railcar sides.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Graffiti paints their sides, too.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: After the railcars are linked into one long train, the Freight Train creeps out of the city and across the Great Plains.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: It rolls past wheat and prairie grasses.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Past silos and barbed wire.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Past a lone hawk circling under a big western sky.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The Freight train rolls slower than slow.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: So slow it's hard to tell it's moving.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: As if the train and the clouds above were having a race to see which can go slower.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Slow, sloooow.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: And like the clouds, the train does not stop even as it inches up among low hills.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Then, another train passes.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: A dark green Overnight Train switchbacking westward.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: It climbs over the Rocky Mountains through snow flurries and pine forests.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The train curves along icy rivers and shoots through tunnels (where its chatter turns into a whisper).

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: There are no roads outside.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Just eagles, elk, and turkeys.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: As the sun lowers, passengers gather in the dining car, where the waiter sways down the aisle with her tray.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: She doesn't spill a thing.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Plates of meat loaf, potatoes, ice cream, and pie.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: A movable feast.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: In the sleeping car, two girls unfold seats into beds and make the room their own.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Little sink, little shower.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Everything little.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The girls sleep as the train curls through the mountains and into the night.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The moon rises.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Wherever the train goes, the moon follows.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: When the train stops, the moon stops.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: When the train starts, the moon starts.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Sometimes it hides behind a ridge.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Then-hello friend- reappears.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The train rests in small towns.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Passengers off, passengers on.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Stars blink in the cold air, lights blink on the horizon, and the Overnight Train pushes into the deep hours of the night and wakes to morning sun.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Passengers wake to biscuits, butter, jam, and coffee.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Outside, everything is different.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Mountains have turned into orchards, snow into grass, boulders into cattle.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Now, accelerating into view across a wide green valley, one last train passes.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: A sleek and white High-Speed Train, blurring a streak across the land.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Schwooosshhhh.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The High-Speed Train flies.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: It glides over bridges and marshes, by bays and highways.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Inside, it is cool and quiet.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The train is a small world moving through a larger world.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: Passengers read or type, One whispers in her phone: We're almost there.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: We'll see you soon.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: The High-Speed Train races toward the city on the coast and the passengers prepare for the end of their journey.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: They close their books, they pack their bags, they think about what's next.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: A clean bed, a warm dinner.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: They are almost home.

title: TRAIN
author: ELISHA COOPER
text: And with a slowing turn into the station and an easing of speed and a sigh of brakes and a gentle last thunk, the train stops.
